PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: ECONOMIC POLICIES OF THE FRASER GOVERNMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Fraser Government for continuing to pursue its restrictive economic policies, which have resulted in-
(a) the highest level of unemployment in Australia's history;
(b) a continuing high unemployment rate amongst teenagers, currently running at over 20 per cent of the work force;
(c) a fall in full-time teenage employment in the year ending January 1982 of some 23,200 jobs; and
(d) the demoralisation and alienation of this country's young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the fact that in recent times there have been numerous references to Australia suffering a recession. More recently the word 'depression' has been used in respect of the current economic difficulties. Can the Minister say at what point a recession becomes a depression so far as the Government's analysis is concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the Government has referred to recession in Australia. On the contrary, the Government has said that the world outside has suffered recessive tendencies arising out of the last nine years, particularly from the quadrupling of the oil price. The Government has pointed out that because of oil prices inflation occurred in other countries, the use of their foreign exchange was directed more and more towards buying oil, and therefore there was a shrinkage of trade and a recession occurred. That recession brought about a stagnant position of almost no growth; but in Australia we-however influenced by the outside world-still experienced real growth. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development considered that we would have a real growth rate this year of something like 3 per cent- that may be a mite high but it is of about that dimension-compared with less than half that figure for other countries. There is, in broad terms, a degree of recessive tendencies throughout the free world outside, resulting in less purchasing of many of our mineral products and, therefore, less of the buoyancy that we would normally have.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to say that the investment of capital in Australia for manufacturing purposes and for growth industry purposes has continued in strength and, indeed, in the last quarter-the December quarter-was stronger than in the previous year. The outside world believes that Australia will grow quickly. I will make those investment figures available to the honourable senator as they are of considerable interest. Australia cannot resist the outside world. To the extent that trade in the outside world shrinks, that will be reflected upon us. Everybody hopes that the outside world will move out of its recessive characteristics to better things in the months and years ahead. No one can disguise that in Western Europe in particular the unemployment rate is at very serious levels-much greater than in Australia. That must be reflected in the level of recession. Because of this recessive tendency in the outside world there is a depression of wages; wages are being reduced. That creates a problem for Australia in that as wages are reduced and inflation comes down in the outside world, while in Australia wages are increased and inflation can be pressed upwards, our capacity to trade in the future is not as good. But certainly in Australia we are not talking about a depression. The inflow of capital is such as to reinforce the expectation that we will be expanding in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. It is reported that the Minister for Primary Industry has written to the Western Australian company which is Australia's largest livestock shipper, ordering it to reduce its exports of livestock. Is the report true? Is the Minister aware that the profitability of many livestock owners is almost entirely dependent on that trade and that if livestock exports were substantially reduced many producers would be forced to change to other enterprises? Is he aware that the livestock trade has been successfully managed by exporters and the Western Australian Government for many years and that any further intrusion by the Commonwealth beyond its obvious responsibilities is totally unwarranted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the very brief report to which the honourable senator referred. I understand there has been some correspondence between the Minister for Primary Industry and the company referred to in the report. I am not aware of the details of the correspondence and will refer the question to Mr Nixon for consideration and reply. I am certainly aware that the livestock trade has been a very important element of the meat trade in Australia over recent years. In the State which Senator Thomas and I represent it has been a very significant market for many producers. My clear understanding is that the Commonwealth has moved in a number of respects to facilitate that trade and to get over some of the difficulties which have arisen with respect to the conflict between the industry and trade unions over the desirability of trade in livestock as against trade in slaughtered meat. I have no doubt that Senator Thomas would support the co-operative efforts which have been entered into between the industry, government and trade unions to get over some of the difficulties in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: I have little doubt that the Commonwealth will wish to play a constructive role where it can. I note Senator Thomas's concern that there should not be excessive government intervention, which is consistent with the view that he advocates on this and other issues and which in general has the support of the Government. I have no reason to think that any intervention by the Commonwealth would be of the sort which would hamper this trade, but at the same time we have to take into account the real conflicts within the community in Australia about the correct balance between trade in livestock and trade in slaughtered meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the installation of private and secure telephone circuits direct from the Prime Minister to ministerial bedrooms around the country. Why was this expensive alternative to the national Telecom Australia network necessary? To help us assess the degree of necessity, can the Minister tell us how many times this year he has received a phone call at his home from the Prime Minister? How many of those calls, if any, were of such a nature that absolute secrecy was required? Is it true that the cost was more than $700,000? To which department or instrumentality is that cost to be attributed? In view of the delays being experienced by Telecom in installing phones for ordinary Australian applicants due to Government decisions affecting Telecom's capital works program, how does he justify this ministerial queue jumping? Finally, if the reports of this amazing decision are to be believed, why are Ministers permitted to speak secretly to the Prime Minister only while they are in bed?

—Answers to some of the detailed matters raised by Senator Coates will be sought from the Prime Minister. I am intrigued by Senator Coates' s apparent knowledge of the furniture that exists in my bedroom or the bedroom of any other Minister. The fact is that Senator Coates is wrong again. There is no secure telephone at all in my home; much less is there one in my bedroom. The answer to this ridiculous question is that since there is no telephone there have been no telephone calls. If the Prime Minister is inserting secure telephones in various places I will get answers for the honourable senator, but if he asks that kind of question he might as well be correct on all the details.

—I ask a supplementary question. I said: 'If the reports of this amazing decision are to be believed . . .'. The Minister did not answer one part of the question. I did not ask how many calls he had received on his secure telephone because I had not assumed that the telephone had been installed. So that we could judge the necessity for this proposal I asked how many calls he had received at his home in this year from the Prime Minister.

—I think those who are listening to Question Time can determine whether there has been any shifting of ground. Such conversations as I have with the Prime Minister are a matter for the Prime Minister and for me.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Government will appreciate the good will that has been fostered by Australia in the Middle East countries-for example, Jordan, Egypt and Oman-through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, State governments , private enterprise and the Australian Government itself by way of assistance with land development, agricultural expertise, et cetera. Bearing this is mind, I ask: Has the Government before it any proposals to cut back funding for projects of assistance commenced in these countries, or will it be the Government's intention to develop further projects and so establish continuing support to these Arab nations which can only bring about further mutual benefits ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I can comment only on aid that is given to the Middle East through ADAB on behalf of the Austalian Government. At present official development assistance is given to Egypt and Jordan. In Egypt we are providing food aid project assistance, such as the provision of a cold store and travelling assistance, largely in the agricultural sector. In Jordan we are involved in a dry land farming project as well as training aid, again mainly in the agricultural sector. Australia recognises the value of aid of this type to countries such as Egypt and Jordan and considerable good will is generated through the projects involving the two countries. The Government has no intention of withdrawing the levels of support of aid that it is giving. It will be found that we will sustain that support as far as is possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that, for a variety of reasons, Victoria is the only State of the Commonwealth that does not have a broadcasting channel available for religious broadcasting? As Victoria is the second most populous State in the Commonwealth, will the Minister look into this situation to see whether some arrangements can be made for a broadcasting channel to be made available for religious broadcasting in Victoria so that this important section of the community, namely the churches in Victoria, will have a medium through which they can put across their important message?

—The availability of religious broadcasting channels in Victoria was not and is not known to me. Certainly, I know that the State in which I reside and which I represent has such a channel. I will undertake to seek the information for the honourable senator and to put the suggestion which he has made to the Minister whom I represent.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. In view of the recent closure of the Rossarden mine in the Fingal Valley, which has added something like 60 young people to the number of unemployed in that area, will the Minister give consideration to the continuation of the Fingal Valley-St Marys youth support scheme or inaugurate some other scheme to help the unemployed in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the matter. I will refer it to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and see whether I can get some early response on it.

—I remind the Minister for Social Security that last September and again last October Senator Grimes raised with him the matter of overseas pensioners in Greece who were taken off the invalid pension in March 1978 when the massive arrests were made in Sydney. As the Minister promised to take up urgently the question whether these pensioners without any income could be re- examined in Greece and also whether, if that were not possible, they could be given financial help to reapply in Australia, I ask: What action has the Minister taken in the past six months?

—The action I took following the matter being raised last year was to refer it to my Department for advice and consideration on the various factors which are involved. I have received a number of advisings on the matter. Those advisings have not put me in a position where I feel able to make any move in the matter that I am sure Senator Primmer or Senator Grimes would regard as positive. I still have the matter under consideration. That consideration has gone on for longer than I would have wished. I am not in a position to give a final reply. At this stage I do not have anything positive to offer the honourable senator with respect to the matter raised by Senator Grimes last year .

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to an article in the British Medical Journal volume 283 headed 'A New Year gift from the BBC to all smokers'? The article describes a series of six 10-minute programs designed to help smokers stop smoking and called 'So You Want to Stop Smoking'. More than two years of work, research and thought has gone into the preparation of the programs. The programs have clear objectives. They are to be aimed at smokers who want to stop smoking, not those who do not. They are to help those people to stop and stay stopped. They are to concentrate on the benefits to be had from stopping smoking rather than on death and disease as the result of continued smoking. These programs have the full backing of the British Medical Association. Will the Minister ask both the Minister for Health and the Minister for Communications whether they will encourage the Australian Broadcasting Commission to negotiate with the British Broadcasting Corporation for the rights to these programs to assist Australians who want to give up smoking? This type of program, I am sure, would be in line with the attitude expressed in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare of which both the Minister representing the Minister for Health and I were members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Medical Association recently produced a booklet which had to do with alcohol use and alcohol policy. I suppose that it represents an emerging desire by medical associations to be involved in making constructive social policy on a broad front. I think this is one of the proper roles for medical associations to take. I am pleased that the British Medical Association was involved as a partner with the BBC in the programs to which the honourable senator referred.
—They should get stuck into the rackets too.

—I acknowledge the interjection by Senator Robertson. I am surprised that, when we are talking about positive action by medical associations to try to do something to promote health, all he can do is interject in a totally negative and destructive way. There are two interesting things about the BMJ editorial. First of all, the British Broadcasting Corporation is taking a lead in an area where useful social policy is to be made and where constructive action is to be endorsed. Secondly, it has been directed very much at the benefits which are likely to flow to individuals and to the community. Both of those are positive and useful matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether there was any likelihood that the ABC might approach the BBC for the use of the programs in this country. That would be a management decision for the ABC and is entirely within its authority. I undertake to have the suggestion passed on to the Australian Broadcasting Commission for its consideration. One thing I noticed in the editorial was that, in promoting its programs, the BBC, amongst other things, was actually advertising on the British commercial radio stations about its programs and about what it was offering. I think that is a most interesting and innovative step by the BBC as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: What action is the Government taking to reduce the enormous backlog of applications for new television translators and new radio services throughout Australia? I refer particularly to areas such as the Dandenongs region of Victoria where obviously falsely-based assurances were given just prior to the last Federal election by the then Liberal member for La Trobe and the then Minister that translators would be in service by early 1981. Is the Minister aware that pressures such as this in connection with the broadcasting system are building up throughout Australia?

—I am aware that in the last year and a half, or however long it is that I have been taking questions on behalf of the Minister for Communications, it has been possible to make known from time to time action which has got under way to put translators and extra facilities into place in different parts of Australia. I know that this is a continuing process and that it will continue as the Government honours the promises it has made. I will obtain information for the honourable senator as to the particular situation in Victoria, but I have no reason to doubt that the Government's determination to increase access to television translators is as great now as it has always been and that the action that has been under way to put new facilities into place will continue.
—I have a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the current backlog of planning proposals for new translators and new radio services would now take 10 years to implement?
—It is clearly inappropriate for me to give an answer off the cuff on a specific matter like that. I will try to obtain the information.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. In view of the headlines in yesterday afternoon's Sydney newspapers about the loss of income of from $60 to $70 per week per worker in New South Wales if the proposed zoning and four-day working week are introduced by the socialist Government of New South Wales, can the Minister obtain for the Senate the following information: Firstly, the total income loss to the workers in industry and secondary services in New South Wales ; secondly, the total cost to industry; thirdly, the total cost to the retail trade; and, finally, the average loss of income per worker per day?
—I bet you haven't got that at your fingertips.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by the honourable senator touches on matters of very great concern in New South Wales. The New South Wales Labor senator who interjected that I do not have that information at my fingertips, I think, is by definition right. I doubt that the cost of these power difficulties will ever be capable of the sort of precise assessment that Senator Lajovic quite properly and understandably would like to see. I find it very puzzling that the Labor Party speaks with so many different voices on this matter. Each time the question of the New South Wales power problems and industrial problems comes up I am faced with a barrage of interjections which seem to suggest that there is something peculiar about these matters being raised in this place. I contrast the attitude of the Opposition in the Senate with the attitude of the New South Wales Premier who seems to be saying some very harsh things to the New South Wales power workers, including that some of them seem to have declared war on their work mates in New South Wales. The words used by the New South Wales Premier are that there is blackmail-

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to the fact that when the Minister rose he said that he did not know anything about the subject and that he could not answer the question. He is now making a policy speech.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—That is typical of the sort of response that I was referring to. It is the oldest story in the book and again I have been misquoted by the honourable senator in his so-called point of order. The fact is that there is a quite extraordinary lack of consistency on the part of the Labor Party in this matter. In New South Wales it desperately tries, through its National President, to get out of the responsibility for the situation by blaming the trade unions, and in here it then accuses us of union bashing. I suggest that it ought to try to get its act together and decide, as a party, whether the unions are at fault in this matter in New South Wales. If they are not, it would suggest that perhaps Mr Wran and his Government are at fault.

ANSWER.PARA: Although it will never be possible to calculate the cost to New South Wales of either the Labor Government or the trade union movement, let me say that people in industry certainly have estimated that there could be a loss of $60 or $70 a day to New South Wales workers if this zoning starts. But let me quote another authority who might have some support in this place from the honourable senator opposite who has come from the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. Mr Joe Thompson of that union warned that zoning would have disastrous consequences for New South Wales. He pointed out that these power workers in dispute should remember that a lot of their fellow unionists are going to suffer if zoning is introduced. I ask honourable senators opposite to give a little sober consideration to this matter and to join with the Government in trying to find constructive ways to remove these very great difficulties from the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for National Development and Energy read the reports of Japanese and American experiments with motorised sailing ships using fully automated sails? A further study by two graduates at Monash University suggests that such ships of a comparable size to those used for the grain trade would compete favourably with conventional shipping and save huge amounts of hydrocarbon energy. Will the Minister, in consultation with the Minister for Transport, consider setting up similar experiments in Australia and granting the Australian National Line funds for a feasibility study of the use of computerised sailing ships to reduce the cost of exports for our primary producers and to conserve energy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amongst the many energy conservation matters that I study is, of course, the question of how to reduce the level of freight rates throughout the world. Freight costs, particularly the cost of bunker fuel, are a very serious burden to not only Australia but also countries to which we export. Considerable study and research is going on into all aspects of this matter. For example, I refer to the conversion to coal fired ships with more sophisticated methods of pulverised coal injection. I have noted the proposed use of sailing ships in a more sophisticated form. I will get further information on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the precise questions, the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, the body advising us on research, has the opportunity to put these various matters under study. I will direct the content of the question to both NERDDC and the Minister for Transport. If what we are aiming to do, apart from saving oil, is to get freight costs down-I do not say this in any aggressive sense at all-the biggest shipping cost today in Australia is the degree of industrial disputes and port congestion that costs, in demurrage charges alone, about $1.5m a day. The fact is that in New South Wales, because of the inability to handle ships and the congestion, rationing is being carried out on the use of ports by ships. We are suffering very greatly in terms of our ability to trade overseas. But I come back to the essential situation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do something about it? You are the Government.

—Senator Button interjected and said: 'Why don't you do something about it? You are the Government'. The congestion is taking place in two main ports directly under the control of Mr Wran, the National President of the Australian Labor Party. Indeed, the congestion, the lack of coal loaders and the lack of port facilities are entirely matters for Mr Wran. But I acknowledge the need to put under study everything that would, in fact, save bunker oil. I will pursue that matter further.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of a booklet headed 'Small Business-Australia's Economic Cinderella' and published by the Council of Small Business Organisation of Australia? I remind the Minister that the Council claims to represent about 90, 000 small businesses in Australia. The publication states that many imbalances and discriminations exist against small business and in favour of large business in such areas as taxation, superannuation and finance. It calls for an urgent and full inquiry into small business in Australia. Recognising the critical importance of small business, which is estimated to employ about 28 per cent of the total Australian work force, to the economic and social well-being of this country, what is the Government's attitude to the claims of the Council and, in particular, its call for a full inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware that the Council of Small Business Organisation of Australia has produced an information booklet on small business. It is aware also that its underlying theme is that small business deserves additional support and assistance. The Government does not agree with that part of the book which suggests that there should be some form of public inquiry in this area, although it certainly does agree with some of the points made by the honourable senator in his question about the importance of small business, with respect to both the creation and maintenance of employment and, I think, the maintenance of the sort of society that Australia has. Far from discriminating against small business, the Government points to measures which it has introduced and which do assist small business in the financial and taxation areas and in management assistance programs. It is the view of the Government that small business requires less government intervention. Indeed, it is often the complaint of small business that there is far too much government interference in its activities. The Government will be looking to trying to lessen that burden on small business.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not had the opportunity to study the booklet produced by the Council. In light of the interest that has been shown by the honourable senator, I will ensure that I get a copy of it and examine it. It may well be that some of the more specific suggestions are matters which I can take up with the Minister for Industry and Commerce who is primarily responsible for that area. I welcome the interest shown by the honourable senator from South Australia. I am advised by my departmental advisers that the booklet is a most useful contribution to debate on the issues relating to small business in this country. I will personally apprise myself of them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment been drawn to an article in the Northern Territory News of 3 March entitled 'Kakadu Stage 2 Future in Doubt'? The first paragraph of that article reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park could come under Northern Territory control .

Given that there is a strong feeling in the Northern Territory, particularly among Aboriginal people, that Kakadu should be managed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, will the Minister give an assurance that the Kakadu National Park will not be transferred to Northern Territory Government control?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report in the Press of 3 March to which the honourable senator referred.
—I will let you have a copy.

—I would like a copy and I would like to pass it on to the Minister. I am aware that some of the Aboriginal people in the Alligator Rivers region are concerned about the lack of success of the larger part of their recent land claim. They are at least considering the possibility-I shorthand this for Senator Robertson-of an arrangement such as that made on the Cobourg Peninsula, that is, a satisfactory arrangement between Aboriginal interests and the Northern Territory. As I understand it, there is nothing more than discussions going on. There are no firm plans at this stage for any move away from announced policy. While the Aboriginals are exploring these matters, I understand, the Commonwealth is waiting for something to come from those discussions and for some expression of Aboriginal opinion on the matter. At this stage I think that is all one can reasonably do.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF WHEAT TO THE SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the Australian Wheat Board has announced that its latest sale of one million tonnes of wheat to the Soviet Union was on short term credit at commercial rates? Does the Minister know that the Wheat Board loan was part of joint assistance extended to the Soviet Union by both Australia and the United States to assist its purchases of large amounts of Australian and United States grain? Has the Minister heard that that arrangement has coincided with the Soviet Union's economic difficulties caused by low gold and oil prices on world markets and by its assistance in maintaining martial law in Poland? Is the Minister aware that a spokesperson for the Australian Wheat Board has said that the rate of interest was one of the best kept secrets connected with the sale and that there would be very few people at the Board who would be privy to the information? Does the Minister know that the Soviet Union has always paid cash in recent years for its wheat from Australia? Finally, will the Minister explain to the Senate why we are apparently assisting the Soviet Union on this occasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is a long and complicated one and canvasses a number of matters on which I have no direct information. Of course, it is widely known that for a considerable period now the Soviet Union has not been able to meet its expectations in the primary industry field. It has not been able to grow the quantities of grain planned. It has been a very large importer of grain from many countries. I am not familiar with the precise terms and conditions on which the AWB has made its most recent sale of grain. I will seek that information from the Minister for Primary Industry and endeavour to give a reply.

ANSWER.PARA: The question evoked some reaction within the Senate because, of course, the question of trade with the Soviet Union and, indeed, with Eastern Europe is a matter of great political interest. Again it would be common knowledge within the Senate that very extensive trade credits have been granted not only to the Soviet Union but also to Eastern Europe. Many people would argue that this is all that has enabled those countries to maintain any semblance of economic activity in those regions. The matter is a very large and very important one. I will seek a full reply for the honourable senator to his very important question .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE: ADVERTISEMENT FOR SECRETARY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the advertisement for a secretary in the Prime Minister's office which appeared prominently in the national Press on 10 March. Among other things the advertisement contained the following:

QUESTION.PARA: The position is that of Electoral Secretary and involves the handling of representations, both written and telephoned, from the Prime Minister's constituents.
Later the advertisement, referring to the skills needed by the successful applicant, stated:
She will be able to maintain efficiency and enthusiasm under pressure--
That is certainly true-
and to work as a member of a team.

Will the Leader confirm that the proposed appointment is in breach of the law in that the 1981 Remuneration Tribunal determination clearly required that an electorate secretary be employed in a member's electorate office? Further, will he confirm that the crude sexism evident in the language of the advertisement is in fact in breach of the policy enunciated by this Government and, furthermore, of the guidelines being administered by the Equal Employment Opportunity Bureau within the Public Service Board?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the advertisement. I am not aware of any breach of the law, nor am I aware of any crude sexism. There seems to be some kind of fruity melodrama about this matter. I do not believe that it is in breach of the law but I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister and see whether he has any comment to make.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, concerns the alarming level of strikes and disputations in our country. I refer specifically to a report in the Courier-Mail of 16 March in which it is stated that the Australian Labor Party spokesman on industrial relations and former Australian Council of Trade Unions chief, Mr Bob Hawke, admitted that he was concerned about industrial relations in this country, particularly on the Australian waterfront. In view of Mr Hawke's amazing admission in relation to our domestic industrial relations situation, does not the Minister feel that our Government must come to grips with the militant unions and union leaders and act to combat the effects which daily stoppages all over our nation are having, not only on our reputation as a reliable trading partner but also on the morale and work ethic of the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sometimes get the feeling that everyone in Australia is worried about militant unions except the Opposition in the Senate. Members of the Opposition always seem to be frightfully exercised whenever anyone mentions the words 'trade union'. The concern which has been reported as being that of Mr Hawke reflects the sort of concern to which I referred earlier in Question Time. The Labor Premier and the President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Neville Wran, has expressed a similar concern. I think there was a suggestion by one very prominent Labor man that there was a touch of madness in industrial relations in New South Wales. I find it very puzzling that prominent members of the Opposition always seem so intent on making representations in favour of militant unionism in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are either before the Parliament or about to come before the Parliament a number of items of legislation which I think will do something to assist the position which is concerning Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I do not think I should canvass during Question Time matters which were debated in the Senate yesterday and which will be up for debate I think next week. One measure before us has something to do with this question. A far more important matter is to come before the Parliament though; that is, the legislation which is to be introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations and which has been the subject also of some debate in the Senate. Whatever can be done by government, whatever can be done by employers, the fact remains that sensible industrial relations require sensible behaviour by government, employers and trade unions. I hope that those scattered elements of the Labor movement that can be heard raising their voices in favour of reason will be listened to rather than the members of the Opposition who seem quite intent on preserving the most lunatic aspects of union behaviour in this community. The Government will do what it can. But it is also important that trade unions and individual trade unionists do what they can to ensure that we have industrial sanity in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for National Development and Energy inform the Parliament whether Minatome Australia Pty Ltd wrote to the Australian Safeguards Office on 27 May 1981 seeking permission to display publicly 500 grams of uranium yellowcake? Is the Minister aware that permission was granted for the exhibition of the yellowcake? Can the Minister now inform the Parliament of the safeguards adopted to display yellowcake? Can he inform the Parliament also whether radiation can contaminate the immediate area when yellowcake is displayed in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particulars but I undertake to get them. I disabuse the mind of Senator Keeffe and the minds of members of the Australian Labor Party about yellowcake. Yellowcake, if consumed, is poisonous. It is a toxic substance but it has a very low level of radioactivity. I have said repeatedly in this place that, nevertheless, whatever the degree of radioactivity one should not involuntarily expose the public to it. But I am advised by the experts that the temporary proximity of people to quantities of yellowcake is not in itself harmful. One would have to be in that position for a very lengthy period to suffer any basic harm. Yellowcake is regarded by the International Atomic Energy Agency and by all scientific advisers as a material of low radioactivity. Of course, we safeguard it for a number of reasons. Under the safeguards agreement the movement of yellowcake needs to be monitored so that it cannot be used for improper purposes. Equally, one would not want, however involuntarily, to expose people to yellowcake for any lengthy period. Having said that, I undertake to let the honourable senator know the specifics of whether the particular exhibition took place and, if so, what safeguards were in force.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to an answer he gave yesterday to a question from Senator Hamer in which he noted that the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority could not continue to provide electricity to New South Wales at the current rate beyond today. Does this restriction apply to the Australian Capital Territory supply of electricity from the Authority? How are these matters of supply determined? What are the constraints which are imposing this limitation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been advised that the New South Wales Premier has apparently said in the New South Wales Parliament that any reduction in the allocation to New South Wales from the Snowy scheme is a political move by the Federal Government and has nothing to do with water levels. I must make the situation very clear. The Snowy Mountains Council is under Federal-State control. The Council comprises eight persons: The chairman, being the Deputy Secretary of my Department; the deputy chairman, from the Commonwealth Department of Housing and Construction; two very senior members of the New South Wales Public Service-Mr Frank Brady, who is the chairman of the New South Wales Electricity Commission and Mr Cunneen, the very distinguished leader of the New South Wales Water Resources Commission; two representatives from Victoria; and two representatives from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority. They are high public servants of great and impeccable objectivity. They are doing their job under the legislation. They have not received any kind of political instruction from me. Of course, the New South Wales representatives would be the first to complain if that were not the case. I have said publicly that the Snowy Mountains Council should do everything within its power to provide the maximum amount of electric power to New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: Without qualification I reject the nonsense which has been suggested. There is absolutely no politics in this, except the sensible politics of wanting to help to the maximum that one can. The situation is-this is the advice from the Council-that there is a simple physical limitation due to the extensive demands made on the Snowy scheme by New South Wales over the past few months. There simply is no further water available beyond that which can be brought from replenishment dams and the rate of replenishment is such that production can be no more than between 22 and 24 gigawatt hours a day. The Snowy scheme has been performing consistently to its designed capacity. The major reason for the present limitations is that it is being used to support base load electricity in New South Wales instead of the peak load shaving which is designed to supply Victoria and New South Wales. The only limitation right now is the availability of water. It remains true that the Snowy Mountains scheme has, over the past few months, produced 40 per cent more electricity than it was originally planned to produce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you quoting now?
—This is the advice I have received from the officers of the Snowy Mountains Council. They are officers of impeccable objectivity.
—Are those their words?

—No. I am giving a paraphrase of their words. It is part of a note on a number of things. They advised me that consumption in the last 24 hours was 36 gigawatt hours of which Victoria took approximately four. It is not known what Victoria's draw-down is likely to be today but it will almost certainly be four gigawatt hours or less. It now appears that the equilibrium rate of power generation from the Snowy will range between 22 and 24 gigawatt hours a day. That is a rate of generation consistent with using the water as quickly as it can be run in the short term storage.

ANSWER.PARA: I will repeat a couple of things. First of all, I correct a statement on the Australian Broadcasting Commission news today that I had said that the Snowy power output would be cut by half. I have never said that. In fact, I have given a figure of about 15 gigawatt hours. Quite clearly, the Authority, through its council, is run by officers from the States and Commonwealth. They are making the decisions as to how much is the capacity. They make that decision within the terms of the Act and the instructions they have to work under. I have given no advice at all, other than to say that they should give New South Wales the maximum amount of electric power that is within their power to provide. That must be made abundantly clear. If a State, through its own purposes, fails to maintain electricity output, the State should look to itself.

I make it clear that the installed capacity of power stations that exist in New South Wales and are seemingly capable of functioning is 8 300 megawatts. New South Wales could be supplied quite adequately if 70 per cent of that capacity were functioning. For whatever reason-that is a matter for the Wran Government- at the moment less than half the capacity is functioning. The Snowy Mountains and the Victorian electricity authorities have been aiming to top up the New South Wales supply to the maximum they can. They have now reached a stage in the Snowy Mountains when in the next few days there must be a decline simply because of the lack of capacity of water and the enormous draw-down that has occurred in the past. The Wran Government is on record as indicating that it would draw down heavily in summer, noting that it would be discounting its use of water in the winter. That, of course, is its responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document from which the Minister quoted be tabled.
—Certainly. I table the document.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to an article in the March issue of Pensioners Voice which criticised the attitude of Telecom Australia to the need for a reduced installation fee for pensioners' telephones. Bearing in mind that installation fees can be as high as $150, that ill, aged and lone pensioners depend for their security and welfare on access to a telephone and that Telecom is reported to have made a record profit of $232.5m in 1980-81, will the Minister direct, or at least very strongly recommend, that Telecom reduce the phone installation fee for needy pensioners?

—I have not seen the March issue of Pensioners Voice. I am aware of the very considerable concessions which are made available generally to people in need and the quite legitimate desire of certain groups that these concessions should be extended or made more readily available. In relation to the capacity of Telecom to provide such concessions, I understand that its profit, if one can call it that, for the last year was a very small amount in terms of capital investment. I think it was about 3 per cent. Of course, it was all reinvested into Telecom's capital works program for the benefit of the system. I will pass on Senator Haines's concerns and her request that the March edition of Pensioners Voice be examined by Telecom. It may be that any decision she is seeking will involve a matter of government policy. I will make sure that the Minister also has the matter drawn to his attention.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: EXISTENCE OF DOCUMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to documents associated with his Department in the names of Mr J. Evans and Dr Fleming. Could the Minister inform the Senate on what dates he became aware of the existence of such documents and, in particular, the existence of the first draft, the second draft and the third draft? On what dates did his Department become aware of the existence of such documents? On what dates were those documents made available to his Department?

—This line of questioning is becoming quite farcical in terms of trying to find out information on this aspect. As I have pointed out so many times in the past, the Department is clearly knowledgeable about the first, second and third drafts because it had a hand in the preparation of the information. I will have to examine the timing to see when the process was first instituted by the Department. To the best of my knowledge it would have commenced about January 1980. I personally became aware of the third draft, which I think has been a point of contention in recent times, on 24 February 1982. The matter was brought to my attention by the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Action Association.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to criticisms that have been directed at the engineering design of the Aussat satellite. Dr Norman Abramson, Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computing Sciences at the University of Hawaii, has criticised the high frequency mode of the satellite. In Melbourne yesterday he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The use of high-frequency band widths, which transmitted and received signals between ground station dish antennae and satellites, was inefficient for Australia's needs.
He concluded:
This will be a waste of such magnitude, but the option is not irreversible and I hope considerable thought will be given to the use of low-frequency bands for Australia's sake.
Whilst professional advice may differ in this matter, has the Minister made any assessment of the planning for the satellite?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article by Dr Norman Abramson. I agree with Senator Teague that in a matter of this importance and magnitude we want to see a decision made which is efficient and effective and works for the benefit of the whole country. I can advise the Senate that the factors to be taken into account in the selection of frequency bands are and were well understood by the Australian satellite planners. After the frequencies were selected in this country they were considered by internationally respected consultants. The views of those consultants were taken and the recommendations made were supported. They had the support of not only people in Australia but also international consultants who were engaged by this country to report on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The article referred to the White report which dates from four years ago. That report initiated detailed consideration of the requirements of a satellite communications system for Australia. Planning from that point on progressed through public inquiries which clearly identified the needs for Australia. Some of those needs-for example, the need for isolated homesteads to be able to pick up reception from the satellite-are unique. That imposes particular needs. The mission objectives of Australia are thought to be best achieved by the frequencies which have been selected. We have no information which might support the claim that the system will cost, as I think the newspaper article stated, an extra $500m over the next 10 years. If there is any detailed information I hope that Dr Abramson or anyone else will make it available. No contract has yet been let for the Australian satellite system. The Government will shortly consider a submission on implementation of the system. When the Government is satisfied with the information which is available to it I understand that it may then arrange for a contract to be let to the appropriate selected tenderer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, though it affects the Minister for Primary Industry and perhaps the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It refers to the concern expressed by members of parliament of all political views that the Tasmanian dairy industry could be used as a negotiating chip in closer economic relationship discussions between Australia and New Zealand. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government is fully aware of the disastrous effects on our labour intensive dairy and vegetable industries which could arise from any closer economic relationship discussions which might not take account of the heavy subsidisation of the New Zealand dairy industry by New Zealand taxpayers? Will the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that these factors and the need to preserve our vital food based industries will be in the forefront of the minds of Australia's negotiators involved in the closer economic relationship discussions with New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been keenly aware of the need to preserve the vital industries of Tasmania, particularly the dairy and vegetable growing industries. Indeed, the Government has been taking steps, particularly with the Callaghan report of the Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania and other reports to try to ensure that there is a development and maintenance of stable employment within Tasmania. The Minister for Primary Industry is very conscious of the needs of Tasmania. He is very sensitive to those needs and very anxious that those kinds of matters should be kept in mind in any negotiations with New Zealand or any other country . I can give that assurance. I will refer the full text of the question to the Minister for Primary Industry and, because it is an important subject, I will see whether he, apart from taking note of it, would like to add further to my answer. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on the answering of questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inject new matter into this subject. First of all, I have already stated that honourable senators are seeking to put at least more than one question in three days. I am not the only senator who has not achieved that. I have put one question in three days. On a constructive basis I refer this matter to the Minister in charge of Government business. Honourable senators get locked in. I asked a question eight days ago of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, who represents the Minister for Health, about medical services in Great Britain. The Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, was asked a question-I know that she has the briefing paper on the matter-a fortnight ago. I am suggesting that we need constructive effort in order to get over the impasse that we face. If a Minister has an answer to a question asked by a senator three or four days previously he is voluntarily given the time to give the answer at the end of Question Time. That should not mean that the person concerned has to forgo asking questions on other matters that arise in the meantime. I put this as a constructive suggestion. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has one answer for me. If honourable senators cannot ask questions, of course, they have to resort to speaking during the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I make another point, more in sorrow than in anger. I think honourable senators will appreciate it. Senator Harradine is here. He will appreciate it. Other senators and I wait patiently to ask a question. If it is good enough for me to be here at the commencement of Question Time it is good enough for other senators. I was irritated when Senator Harradine came in very late and got the call. This is a place for honourable senators to vent their spleen. That is what I am doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to the last of Senator Mulvihill's comments, regarding Senator Harradine. The honourable senator may have observed that Senator Harradine sits regularly in this chamber for Question Time. He is an independent in this place. I keep a record of questions asked and the record clearly shows that Senator Harradine has not asked a question for many days. There is a very valid reason why he was not present in the chamber earlier today . I will not disregard that situation of Senator Harradine, particularly as he is an independent on his own and in view of the fact that he has not been called upon to ask a question for many days. I hope that the honourable senator will accept that answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have said this before, but I will repeat it: The sooner we improve Question Time, the better. Question Time has now developed into an area of non-interest for honourable senators. It is clearly now necessary for the Standing Orders Committee to have another look at Question Time. I have always resented the fact that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, without seeking leave of the Senate, can bring Question Time to an end. I have argued that this is contrary to the principle upon which this place works . I do not know how the other place works and I am not interested, but this place has always worked on the basis that the Senate itself determines what shall happen. But time and again the Leader of the Government says: 'While I am on my feet I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper'. No leave is sought and the right to deny the Leader of the Government his initiative has been taken away from the Senate. This means, of course, that there is no flexibility at Question Time. Question Time now is debating time. We should apply the rules which are on the back of our question papers: Newspapers cannot be read from, opinions cannot be given and questions cannot be debated, as Senator Chaney debated a question quite fully at one stage of the game.
—Questions shall be without notice.

—Questions shall be without notice. Questions shall not be of extraordinary length. Too much information ought not be given. Too much detail ought to necessitate the placing of a question on the Notice Paper. As Senator Mulvihill said, there is a period after Question Time in which detailed questions can be answered. That should be the time for answering long questions seeking details which the Minister would not be able to give unless he had been previously briefed. We had an example of that the other day. When Senator McLaren asked for a paper to be tabled we found that a question had been referred to the department concerned at least a couple of days before the question was asked. That is not a question without notice; that is a question that should have gone on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: We have debated this matter time and again. Every time this situation arises in the Senate I will repeat what I am saying until I bore people to the point of doing something about it. It is extraordinary that you, Mr President, have now been forced to take a list of the number of times that honourable senators have asked questions. The point has now been reached, as Senator Mulvihill pointed out, when Senator Harradine can be out of this place for two days, can come in on the third day late in Question Time and, because he has not asked a question, can supersede a number of honourable senators who have sat in the chamber throughout Question Time waiting to ask a question. My view is that he loses his priority position if he is not here from the commencement of Question Time. Otherwise, what is going to happen? I know that I will get a question once a week. So what will I do? If I asked my question on Tuesday and I have more important business elsewhere, I will not turn up to Question Time on Wednesday and Thursday. That is what is happening at Question Time. Instead of this place being packed with every honourable senator seeking to ask a question, we now have scattered attendance. All I am saying indicates that the standard of Question Time has fallen away. I think it is necessary that the Senate, through its Standing Orders Committee, again apply itself to improving Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As to Senator Mulvihill's contribution on this matter, if honourable senators indicate the particular questions to which they want Ministers to answer at the end of Question Time, the Ministers will be very happy to do so.
—They should do it automatically.

—That is a matter of judgment. If the Opposition indicates that it wants that done automatically we will do it. I was just saying that I will extend the courtesy to the Opposition and have it done either in that way-I think Senator Mulvihill will understand that courtesy-or in other ways. In a moment I will follow that course. As to the broader question, nobody knows better than Senator Georges, because he has been a Whip, that there has been agreement in the Senate over a number of years that one hour shall be devoted to Question Time and that agreement has been maintained. The closing of Question Time is a procedural matter that I, as Leader, do at the end of that one hour. If there is a desire for this matter to be discussed at the Standing Orders Committee I would be very eager that we should do so. I have already indicated that. If there are any other ways in which we can improve on this, I would be very happy to hear them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I undertook that by the end of Question Time I would give Senator Gietzelt some information on his question regarding the potential for growth or recession in Australia. The Australian Bureau of Statistics preliminary estimate of expected new fixed capital expenditure in selected industries for the six months ending 30 June this year is $8,514.9m. This is for selected industries and does not cover all industries. If the estimate is realised, expenditure by these selected industries for the year ending 30 June 1982 will be $16,528.5m, a rise of 30 per cent over the previous year. This figure compares more than favourably with the 10 per cent to 15 per cent rise mentioned in the Budget. The figures now showing are those of development.

INTERJECT.PARA: As to foreign investment in enterprises in Australia, in the December quarter 1981 net inflow of foreign investment amounted to $1,427m, which was 54 per cent higher than in the previous quarter and 39 per cent higher than in the December quarter 1980. The major inflows were from the United Kingdom, $435m; and from Japan $239m. The net inflow of portfolio investment and institutional loans, which was $1,534m, outweighted a net withdrawal of direct investment of $107m. The major inflows were recorded for manufacturing, $448m; finance, property and business services, $334m; and mining $243m. The point I make from these figures is that the investment inflow that is taking place at the moment is encouraging in terms of the development of industry and employment for the year ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement in respect of matters which were raised earlier about Question Time. I appreciate the problems which honourable senators encounter in relation to this matter. I think it might be advisable if some of these issues were discussed at the Senate Standing Orders Committee. However, I want to make it quite clear that, in my view, it would be undesirable if the Standing Orders Committee approached the matter on the basis of some of the comments made here today. They suggested that the call for questions should be awarded to honourable senators on the basis of their sitting solemnly in this chamber; that they should be given the call on a first come first served basis with regard to attendance at Question Time. If we start on that exercise the Senate will resemble a school room more than it does at present.
—It ought to stop. It is a rabble now.
—Senator, it is not for me to say who would get the cuts most for non-attendance at Question Time. I do not think, with respect-
—You get a reward for attendance.

—Well done. Senator McLaren is a gold star pupil at Question Time , I must say, if we are continuing with the analogy. But I make it quite clear that I do not regard it as a collective Opposition view that if Senator Harradine were absent from the chamber for some reason or another he should be punished somehow in the pecking order of Question Time for that conduct.

—In response to Senator Georges with regard to the Senate Standing Orders Committee having a look at the overall conduct of Question Time, I will certainly make sure that the suggestion does go on the agenda for the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation with regard to statements made in the other place yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, in the House of Representatives, it was intimated, by way of interjection, that Mr Peter Coleman, who is no relation of mine, may be my brother. Let me assure the Senate that there is no relationship whatsoever . I have no idea how anyone who is a large 'L' Liberal could be considered to be related to me. Nevertheless, in referring to the visit of Miss Vanessa Redgrave to Australia, Mr Coleman said:

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) attended a civic reception for her in Newcastle and was reported in the Press as saying how much he admired her courage in working for the Palestinian revolution. Senator Coleman expressed similar sentiments at meetings in Perth.

I attended one meeting in Perth with Miss Vanessa Redgrave. I had the honour of sharing the platform with her. We-that is, Miss Redgrave and I-did not discuss the Palestinian situation. At the time we were there the matter under discussion was peace. To my mind, that is the most important subject for all people to be turning their minds to at this time in the twentieth century when the world situation is as it is. As I have said, neither of us discussed the Palestinian situation. I have never expressed publicly my opinion on the Palestinian situation. It is not my intention now so to do. But I did then, and I will now, place on record my admiration not only for Miss Redgrave and the courage that she has shown, but also for the courage of any woman or any person who stands up publicly and speaks about peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation on a similar matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Coleman, an honourable member of the other place, decided, during a contribution, to make a couple of remarks concerning me. I, therefore, seek to clarify the situation. The bottom of page 1073 of the House of Representatives Hansard states:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, Senator Georges of the Labor Party was in Beirut the other day celebrating the seventeenth anniversary of the PLO. His trip, according to the Australian-Israel Review of February of this year,was paid for by the United Palestinian Workers, an Australian affiliate of the PLO.

Let me make the position clear. Over the past two or three years, I have received invitations from the United Palestinian Workers to go to Lebanon to view for myself the conditions under which the Lebanese and Palestinian people exist. Because I was visiting Europe for another matter towards the end of last year, it was possible for me to go to Lebanon. I accepted an invitation to go there just as many honourable senators accept other invitations from organizations or states, sometimes having their way paid, sometimes not. In this case the Palestinian workers in Melbourne invited me and paid my fares to Lebanon. I took advantage of that invitation to see for myself what prevails in that place.

Mr Coleman made the statement that I was celebrating the seventeenth anniversary of the Palestinian revolution-he used the word 'celebrating'. I celebrated no such thing. No honourable senator would celebrate the cause of the Palestinians entering a state of revolution. I saw nothing there to celebrate. I saw much that concerned me-for example, the conditions under which the Lebanese exist at present. Lebanon is occupied by a variety of forces. The Lebanese have given to the Palestinian people a place of refuge, but in giving that refuge they have brought upon themselves the wrath of the Israelis. Events have brought great devastation to that country. I am not extending my comments beyond giving a personal explanation. The word 'celebrating' is the word to which I object. I went to Lebanon as an observer. Having gone there as an observer, I came away with the clear impression that the rights of the Palestinian people need to be recognised. I state that very clearly.

It was not my intention to raise the matter now but to speak on it when it was raised in the Parliament subsequently. I would then speak clearly to this Parliament of the need to recognise the Palestinian people and to recognise the position in which they and the Lebanese people find themselves. Mr Coleman is trying to create division within the Australian Labor Party and the community by trying to show in some way that we approve of the terrifying way in which the Palestinians, or for that matter the Israelis, react.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Mr Coleman, the defeated member of the Liberal Party in New South Wales?

—He is a member of the other House. That is all I know about him . I do not know his history to that extent-I am not interested at the moment. However I might take some interest in a moment. I say to Mr Coleman that what he is doing is not serving the cause of peace. He ought to refrain from making statements without first properly investigating the circumstances behind those statements.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to the matters concerning Vanessa Redgrave. I had the opportunity to meet the person. I do not think she deserves the criticisms that Mr Coleman has heaped upon her. I suggest that Mr Coleman ought to accept that a person is entitled to come to this country and put an alternative point of view. Even though we might not agree with that point of view I insist that that point of view ought to be heard. Mr President, I know that I have gone beyond the matter under discussion and that you have given me your indulgence. I am grateful for that indulgence. When a member of the other House misrepresents honourable senators in this House, it is a matter which should concern us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to put the record straight. Senator Georges said that I came into the chamber late during Question Time. I was here at the beginning of today's sitting but was required to go out of the chamber for a short time during Question Time.
—The Chair was aware of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.
—Why does the honourable senator require leave?
—I wish to speak to the matters raised by Senator Coleman and Senator Georges.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to canvass the issues. I realise that we are treading on very thin ice when we are dealing with matters that are raised in the other place. Senator Georges and Senator Coleman are entitled to protect not only their position having regard to the statements made by Mr Coleman yesterday , but also the position of the party to which I belong. Whilst Mr Coleman impugned the motivation and the associations of the honourable senators, who have adequately replied to the attacks made upon them, he similarly cast aspersions on the Australian Labor Party and its policies in respect of the Middle East and what I believe to be a principled position, even if we accept that the Government does not support our position on the Sinai peacekeeping force. It is a matter of regret when a member in the other place indulges in a wide-ranging guilt by association attack which goes beyond the area of genuine debate. I remind the Senate that some years ago Mr Coleman was involved in an attempt to use the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to compile dossiers on members of the Labor Party for the purpose of impugning the motivation.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I did not want to intervene. When leave is granted to an honourable senator it is basic to a personal misrepresentation or even in the wider situation a party which is allegedly mis- represented. I suggest that at this moment Senator Gietzelt is wandering into a wider field of debate. I do not want to limit that for other purposes. If Senator Gietzelt wants to clarify these matters he can do so in a debate on the Sinai, which matter is to come before the Senate today. Whether Mr Coleman was involved in an association with the Australian Security Intelligence Organistion can have nothing to do with a personal explanation in this place. I repeat that I do not want to limit the situation. I simply want to try to keep within the rules concerning this form of personal explanation.

—In response to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, when Senator Gietzelt was asked why he wished to leave he said that he wanted to make a statement in relation to the matters raised but not for the sake of a personal explanation. I suggest to Senator Gietzelt that leave was given on the understanding that he would make only a brief comment.

—Mr President, I appreciate that. I do not wish to canvass the whole area in respect to Mr Coleman except to say that to attempt to suggest guilt by association has, in itself, an element that creates impressions which are totally beyond the questions that were debated in the other place. I will certainly take the time and the energy to research this matter and deal with it at another time. I want to protect my party's integrity in relation to its position on the Middle East which we believe to be a balanced one, made on the basis of a factual understanding of the complexities and the very difficult problems that exist in that part of the world. There is a degree of consensus and unanimity in my party about our position there. I do not believe that the cause of peace is served in this intemperate way or by guilt by association which was a characteristic of Mr Coleman's contribution yesterday in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate I seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
