SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the final report relating to the following proposed work:

SPEECH.PARA: Upgrading of airport facilities for the introduction of domestic wide-body aircraft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the only South Australian member of the Public Works Committee I would like to make a few comments on the report concerning the proposed works at Adelaide Airport for the introduction of domestic wide-body aircraft. I will try to be as brief as possible. Firstly, I would like to make it clear that I do not oppose the proposal or the basic thrust of the report but I think there are some very important factors which need to be taken into account. Adelaide Airport is unusual in that it is located only a few kilometres from the city centre and is right in the heart of the western suburbs. Many houses and schools are in the direct flight path of the aircraft using the airport and, in some cases, jets pass overhead at heights of less than 200 metres. There are many complaints from residents about noise and structural damage to houses as a direct result of vibrations caused by jet aircraft. There has even been a letter from a school headmaster complaining about the interruptions to lessons caused by the constant barrage of jets and other aircraft between 9.30 a.m. and 3.30 p.m. Many residents have also complained about aircraft, particularly executive jets, operating inside the curfew hours.

SPEECH.PARA: I, unlike some Government members of the Committee, certainly thought the complaints were genuine. Generally, the people making these complaints were sensible, average citizens, many of whom built or purchased their homes long before Adelaide Airport became operational, and certainly before the introduction of jet aircraft. In many cases when these people complained to the Department of Transport they were treated in an off-hand way and their complaints usually fell on deaf ears. Of course, Senator Martyr believes that the Department of Transport has adequately dealt with these complaints from people living in the vicinity of the airport or directly under the flight path.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is not a South Australian.

—I wonder whether his views would change if he were the member for that area. I think Senator Martyr's provocative behaviour at the recent public hearing in Adelaide clearly illustrated his insensitivity to the needs of ordinary Australians such as those who live near Adelaide Airport. What better proof is there of the extent of concern in the community than the huge number of letters we have been getting from responsible people living in this area? Surely the fact that people have even bothered to sit down to write a letter is evidence enough of the irritation being inflicted upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I do not oppose the proposed upgrading of Adelaide Airport for wide-body aircraft but in view of the extent of concern in the community, I believe certain conditions need to be met. Firstly, I believe that tangible and positive steps must be taken now by the Commonwealth and State governments for the construction of a new airport, preferably in a sparsely populated outer area . There has been a lot of talk about this and a lot of bureaucratic bungling but we are still as far away as ever from that decision. Of course, the State and Federal governments have moved with the speed of lightning on the proposed upgrading of facilities for an international terminal in Adelaide-so much so that one could be excused for thinking that an election might be coming up in South Australia. Recently we had the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) deliberately side-stepping the Public Works Committee and urging the Government departments concerned to hurry up with the upgrading works which are the subject of this report. However, when it comes to choosing a site for an alternative airport we have nothing but silence from both the State and the Federal governments.

The second condition which I believe must be met is that the present curfew must be maintained and more rigorously enforced. The operation of small executive jets inside the curfew must be stopped and, similarly, the Trans Australia Airlines Airbus must not be allowed to operate inside the curfew. Finally, I believe that all schools and hospitals in the vicinity of the airport , particularly those in the flight path of the main runway, must have sound- proofing treatment and, where necessary, air conditioning, with the cost to be shared between the State and Federal governments. It is imperative that these conditions be met. I think that they represent a sensible and realistic compromise. I call upon the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to do everything possible to ensure that these quite reasonable conditions are met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I realise that Senator Foreman has the obligation to defend his point of view and also his patch, if that is how he would describe it. Senator Foreman has identified me as being provocative. I might be impolite and unco-operative, but I am never provocative. I examined fairly, I thought, the allegations that were made by various people at that inquiry. I am reminded of something that Senator Mulvihill said during the course of Senator Foreman's remarks. I think the implication was that I might not do the same thing in my own patch. I say now that I will do so. When the time comes for the same sort of examination at Perth Airport, if the same sort of allegations are made by much the same sort of people, I certainly shall subject them to the same sort of questioning to which I subjected those who made the allegations in Adelaide. Those allegations may be summed up as follows: That there was psychological damage to those who live under the flight path of the aeroplanes, physiological damage to those who live under the flight path of the aeroplanes and structural damage to homes under the flight path. That is a fair summing up of the allegations. I keep using the word 'allegations' because on my limited examination of the witnesses-it was not really a rigorous examination; it was a fairly limited examination of their allegations-they were not able to produce one bit of substantial evidence to back up those allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: When people come along to an inquiry and claim that their houses are falling apart, the ceilings are coming down and plaster is falling, one would imagine they would have some sort of professional opinion to back up those allegations. These are very serious matters. Members of parliament who appeared before the inquiry were making the same sort of allegations. If those were serious allegations I would have thought that those members of parliament would have visited the places that were supposed to be falling down and viewed with their own eyes how serious the damage was. I was not able to elicit from any of those members of parliament or anybody else at that inquiry whether that had been done . They produced no substantial evidence at all to back up their allegations. In fact, under examination they indicated that they were not sure about the type of soil on which the houses to which they referred were built. They were not certain about the soil conditions underneath the houses. The cracking could have been done due to the soil or a number of other reasons. No substantial evidence at all was brought before the Committee to back up those most serious allegations about houses falling apart.

I now move to the allegations of physiological damage. These were serious charges about people being made ill as a result of aircraft noise. One would think it would be possible to produce medical certificates or something of substance to substantiate the charges. Again, there were many vague statements about what might have happened in the past, but nothing substantial was brought forward. The allegations of psychological damage were in the same vague area. No substantial evidence was given that people were being affected. We drove around in a bus underneath the flight path and, with aeroplanes flying overhead, people in the street were engaging in ordinary conversation in the normal course of business. They were not the slightest bit affected by the noise. It is not fair to offer in the Senate these comments as serious allegations when they are without substance. I am sorry to have taken so much time but I felt that it was important to clear my part in the inquiry. I cannot see that anything I did was provocative. All I did was to examine the allegations that people made. They were serious allegations and people offered no evidence to back them up. It seems to me that I am fulfilling my function on the Public Works Committee by subjecting anyone who comes before it with such allegations to examination because it is the duty of care that I have to the Committee and also to this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I cannot sit quietly by and listen to the sorts of statements that Senator Martyr has just made. Having attended some time ago the Public Works Committee meeting in Adelaide to consider the upgrading of the airport, I could not sit back idly, after watching the treatment that those attending the meeting had meted out to them by-amongst others-Senator Martyr. He maintains that he is anything but provocative. I was indignant at the treatment that was handed out to those ordinary people who were not tremendously well versed in parliamentary proceedures or what is involved in a Public Works Committee hearing or any other parliamentary committee hearing. They were just ordinary prople who were concerned at what they saw as an invasion of their liberties, rights and privacy. I acknowledge that the majority of people who attended that meeting had been given by the media a false impression of the Committee's role. Nevertheless, putting aside the fact that they were there under a misapprehension, there was no excuse for the sarcastic, rude and frivolous treatment that they were given by Senator Martyr.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I find those remarks offensive. I simply state in my defence that I did not act in the way in which Senator Haines has described. I find her remarks offensive.
—There is no point of order.

—A Hansard record of the proceedings of that meeting is available . I suggest that anybody who reads it will see quite clearly that Senator Martyr -and he was not alone-treated with considerably less respect than they deserved the comments and the anguish that was clearly evident from the people who attended that meeting. It may not have been intended, Senator Martyr, but that was certainly the way they were received.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—The point remains that there were many very upset people at that meeting. They were upset not only because they could see in the very near future that a predicament that they had suffered for many years would be made worse but also because they were not being taken seriously enough, in their opinion, by members of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martyr said that people made a series of allegations and they produced no evidence to support them. I can tell him that the soil around Adelaide Airport is excellent building soil. It is certainly far better building soil than that found in the eastern suburbs of Adelaide or in the hills district. It is rotten soil for growing plants-one cannot grow a carrot-but one can build on that soil a house which does not crack easily. That fact ought to have been ascertained from a soil report which the Committee could have called for. It ought not be encumbent on people complaining about the damage done to their homes by aircraft to provide expensive evidence. Most of those people are pensioners. They are certainly elderly. They have lived in that area for many years, certainly before the airport was built. Why should they have to go to the expense of getting medical evidence to prove that problems they are suffering with their health, whether physiological or psychological, and problems they are having with their homes are not the fault of some other outside interference? One has only to visit a house anywhere in the area from West Beach through to Plympton and around to Richmond to know the effects on windows and on any glassware in cupboards of aircraft flying over the home or anywhere near. It is not just the area around Adelaide Airport that is affected. One of Adelaide's most prestigious suburbs, North Adelaide, suffers the same problems. Senator Foreman mentioned hospitals and schools around the Richmond-Thebarton area. There are hospitals in the North Adelaide area which are affected because they are directly beneath the flight path.

It would have been encumbent on the Committee to pay a little more serious attention-or at least to appear to be paying it-to the very real problems that are being faced by the people in the area. It certainly seems to those people that this Committee is only whitewashing a decision made by the Government-it may not be-which, we all suspect, is using the upgrading of Adelaide Airport, which will be more expensive than originally anticipated, as an excuse for not building a full international airport somewhere in the north east of Adelaide. With regard to the positioning of the airport, I suggest to Senator Martyr, with the greatest of respect, that there is no comparison between the surrounding residential areas of Perth Airport and Adelaide Airport.

Adelaide Airport is surrounded by homes a substantial number of which, as I said earlier, were there before the airport was moved into the city from Parafield. If this Government does not do something fairly smartly about setting aside specific land for an international airport on the north-eastern side of Adelaide, that area too will be obliterated by surrounding residential areas and removed from all contention. I suggest, that in view of the increased costs further consideration be given to the upgrading of Adelaide Airport. Because of the increased nuisance value, pain and distress that is likely to be caused to local residents, we should think again about putting international facilities at the existing domestic airport and move expeditiously for a full international airport to be developed for the use of South Australians somewhere outside known developed residential areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am obliged to enter the debate having regard to the remarks that Senator Haines has made about parliamentary committees and the way in which they deal with members of the general public. This reminds me of the experiences that I have had when we were in government. I was the chairman of some parliamentary committees and also a member of some joint committees of the Parliament which were chaired by other members. I was concerned with the attitude that was taken on some of these occasions when submissions were made by ordinary citizens to parliamentary committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall one particular case where an Opposition member, later a Cabinet Minister, subjected a member of the public to grilling and cross-examination as though the person who was giving the evidence was guilty of some misdemeanour. When I objected, my objection was supported by another member of the Liberal Party who later became a Minister. He too supported the fact that when we are dealing with members of the public they must be given some licence for the way in which they present their evidence. From those experiences it is clear that it is essential for members of the Parliament sitting on parliamentary committees to exercise a great deal of discretion and care in the way in which members of the public are handled when they have a desire to come before a parliamentary committee to present a point of view.

I agree entirely with the comments that have been made by honourable senators about aircraft noise. I was responsible for convening a large demonstration and conference in the St George and Sutherland area almost 20 years ago about the problems of aircraft noise at Mascot airfield. Arising from that public concern the Australian Government, to its credit, established an aircraft noise committee. A number of us subsequently became members of that committee and played a very important part in attempting to ameliorate the problems of aircraft noise. I have to say again that members of the public do not have to be academics, leading citizens or have any other sorts of attributes in order to feel that they are being disadvantaged by parliamentary and government decisions about these sorts of matters.

It is a fact of life that aircraft noise-this certainly was my experience in local government-affects people differently. Some people can put up with the noise and some people cannot. Some people have rather hysterical reactions and others have more passive reactions. We are all made up of different types of personalities and characteristics. It is all too easy to have a generalised position about the way people react. Of course, problems still exist at Mascot airfield with aircraft noise. As you know, Mr Deputy President, the problem is still a very live and burning issue in the whole of the region of the southern and eastern suburbs of Sydney. This is the reason why the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, refuses to agree to any further extensions to that airfield. An airport should be placed in some other vicinity of Sydney which is removed from residential and any type of modern development.

I agree that not only people living in houses are affected by aircraft noise. In more recent times, I have read in the local papers of mayors of some of the municipalities finding that churches, schools, convalescent homes and hospitals are also affected. This is a matter of serious public concern. Governments have to be a little more careful about where they place such important public facilities in the future. It is pretty clear that Sydney ought to have a new airport and certainly an international one where traffic can be diverted from Mascot into an area that is, at the moment, unspoiled by residential development . As a result of public concern over the last 20 years Federal governments have been forced to recognise the major problems affecting the amenities and the lifestyles of its citizens.

I know that where my parents live it is impossible to have a conversation or make a telephone call when flights go over. One can virtually put a stick in the air and touch the undercarriage of the planes as they come down. It is very untenable for citizens to have to constantly put up with that nuisance. It is likely to be increased if the question of the Sydney airport is not resolved. I support the concern of Adelaide residents. Clearly, air travel will not stand still. It will expand and more and more citizens will be affected by it. I suggest that all honourable senators and all members of the national Parliament should be exercising a little more concern about these matters and insist that the impasse that exists about airports be resolved by creating and building new airports far removed from any residential development and far removed from citizens who have to exist side by side with noise factors.

As a result of the campaign that we waged back in the 1960s the Government was forced to change flight plans and build runways which ameliorated and considerably improved the position, but there are still thousands of citizens who are affected by the inevitable use of the Mascot airport. I think it is proper that members of the Senate should be expressing their concern in some of the other cities of our Commonwealth where the problem is now perhaps minor to what it will be in the future. I make the point very strongly that State and Commonwealth governments have a major responsibility to resolve this matter which, in many cases, can be resolved only by building airports in different locations.

I come back to the main point. We are here as representatives of the citizens. I have heard it said that even the petitions of the citizens ought to be dealt with in a more formal way. I certainly object to that because petitioning is one of the means by which the ordinary person in the community can express his point of view to the Parliament. Committees of the Parliament should go out of their way to create an atmosphere that is conducive to ordinary people, the citizens of our community, feeling that they have a friend in court. They should feel that the committees are interested in their viewpoints. The community does not expect committees merely to produce acoustic reports and reports from organisations, universities or government departments to substantiate and sustain their common reaction to living with noise. If senators and members of the Parliament just do that then they will bring the Parliament into further disrepute with the average citizen. We need to establish closer links with the citizens of this Commonwealth. I hope that the debate has helped to create a better condition in these matters.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Recommendations for 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Debate has already gone on within the community in part in relation to the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission for 1983. However, I feel that, on a closer reading of the report, a rather disturbing aspect has not yet been taken note of. I refer the Senate's attention to the general recurrent grants program section. In paragraph 1.1 the Commission makes the point that the Australia-wide average real increase in expenditure was 3 per cent between the 1980-81 and 1981-82 financial years. The Commission goes on to make the point that there have been some reductions in the order of 18,000 in enrolments in government schools. In paragraph 1.3 the Commission makes the point that despite this reduction there are some dislocatory and diseconomic effects of enrolment decline. It cautions that these should not be underestimated. Indeed, the Commission states:

The evidence before the Commission is that present enrolment declines which are mainly at the primary level do not produce swift or automatic savings and may indeed, in the absence of actual school closures produce higher costs associated with the need to maintain uneconomic class sizes and to phase in the application of staffing formulae which dictate redeployment. They also result in higher per student maintenance costs and more expensive support services.

Having noted that and having made several other points about the diseconomies the Commission makes a very strong point that, whilst there may be a small decline of the order of 0.8 per cent in enrolment in government schools, that might increase rather than decrease costs. However, if one goes to the Commission's recommendations one reads in paragraph 1.5:
Accordingly, the Commission is recommending a 2 per cent increase in the general recurrent grants for government schools.

Whilst the Commission makes the point that there was previously a 3 per cent real increase in expenditure and that costs may rise, it recommends a 2 per cent increase. It states that this particular recommendation will contribute to improved morale in the government school systems. I find this a rather interesting statement. Certainly, from the discussions that I have had in the weeks since this report was tabled in the House of Representatives I have found that by making recommendations which will not maintain real standards in government schools it has done anything but improve morale in government school systems.

Another point to which I draw the attention of the Senate relates to the capital grants program on which the Commission in paragraph 2.3 makes the comment that there have been some decreases in government funding, the most obvious one being the reductions in the Loan Council allocations to the States for capital works by nearly 10 per cent in real terms. The Commission makes the point:
There is not doubt that pressure on capital grants for new student places remains very high, and that many children are being educated in sub-standard facilities.

Despite this fact, noting that the State governments in particular had decreased their capital works programs, the Commission went on to say on page 8 that it does not see any reason to recommend to the Government that it should make in any way compensatory Commonwealth grants. This is despite the fact that many of our children in Australia are being educated in sub-standard facilities in those schools for which the State and Commonwealth governments have responsibilities. I believe that that is a depressing aspect of this report. Despite the fact that the Schools Commission makes some useful recommendations in relation to non- government schools-these are to be applauded-I believe that its recommendations in relation to the government schools will only increase the concern that is already within the community that the Government through its instrumentality- unfortunately, not an independent instrumentality any longer in terms of its reports-will, indeed, continue to exacerbate that disjunction between private and government school systems.

I have said here, and I will say on every opportunity, that this is something that this country cannot stand and does not need. It does not need that continual fostering of disharmony between private and government school systems. Both systems will continue in Australia and both have in the past made great contributions to the growth of the country and will do so in the future. At the moment, as the report stands, the recommendations that continually come forward tend to foster that disharmony, to foster acrimonious debate within the community and to foster divisions between private and government schools. We do not need those. The education system does not need them. Private and government schools do not need them. Parents and citizens associations in those school systems do not need them. We need to have those systems working in harmony as they had done until a few years ago. We need to re-establish that climate of good will between those school systems for the benefit of all children in this country. I urge yet again that the Government seek to bring forward policies which will re-establish that harmony within Australia and within our schooling systems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to confine my remarks to two aspects of the report. I refer to page 56 and the Regularisation of Status Program. It will be noted that rightly the Government gave amnesty to a number of illegal immigrants who surfaced in Australia between 19 June 1980 and 31 December 1980. It is now near the end of the first quarter in 1982. I sympathise with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is in a squeeze play because of rigid staff ceilings. I think most senators have been confronted with people who have surfaced in this country . I think over 9,000 applications from those people to remain here were processed and only 200 remain to be processed. I think overall they have been a favourable acquisition for Australia.

I know that late last year the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) virtually issued a deadline. He wanted all the difficult cases sent to central office in Canberra for final assessment. We are now into March and this has not happened. The point, I suspect, is that assessment is very difficult in some areas when there is a suggestion of a criminal act. I would be the last to say that persons who are involved in drug running or prostitution machinations should not have the barrier lowered on them and be denied permanent residence. I know of a Spanish applicant who had an altercation 17 years ago with the police in Madrid at the height of the reign of the Franco Government. I would be very suspicious of the provocation of that era and would believe that he had every justification to get into an altercation. I give another example-that of a Bolivian whose name I will not mention. I know that the Bolivian Government is synonomous with the export of cocaine; it is its main source of revenue. Some of the Bolivians whose applications have already been finalised have worked here for eight or nine years in arduous industries and are distinct acquisitions to this country. The Department was fair enough to hint to me that in one case in these last 200 cases there was a suggestion of a drug offence. In my own style of interrogation, I had the chap into my office and he refuted the suggestion. No final decision has been made, but I wonder, on balance, how we adjudicate on an application from someone from a political system in which the police force might make an assessment different from our police force. How do we decide whether that person shall stay?

We are into the first quarter of 1982 and there is quite a number of these people. I have assured them that they appear to be fairly sure of getting permanent residence, but there are exceptions. I think there was a chap here who was sentenced in Macao to eight years imprisonment for manslaughter and who did not tell us that he had shot through. He has gone back, but that is a rare case. I take this opportunity to make the plea that, even if it means overtime, we finalise the status of these last 200 people.

Another point I want to raise is the delays in granting citizenship. I pay tribute, as I think other New South Wales senators will, to men with the dedication of Mr John Wallace in Sydney. He goes out of his way to try to break the administrative log-jams. I mention this because I received from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle one long answer about how we were grappling with staff problems, particularly in regard to the granting of citizenship. I do not blame the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but I have some reservations about the stop and go role of both the New South Wales Police and the Australian Federal Police. Of course, when there is a VIP here they have to man the battlements, but I always believed that they stop in mid-air and that it takes weeks before they pick up the slack. I suppose 99.5 per cent of those who apply for citizenship are as clean as a hound's tooth, but there is no question that the police are a major factor in the delays.

The only other point I have to make is not an outright criticism. We know that people move around, and I have heard of cases of people who have asserted that when they changed their address somebody went to the Department's counter in Sydney and said: 'I have moved from Rockdale to Waterloo'. I just wonder whether that information gets back to the citizenship section. Our immigration operations are, I believe, subject to unrealistic staff ceilings and the rigidity of the Department of Finance in its obsession with ensuring that staff incur no overtime. Whether it be in the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, we are dealing with the plight of people. I believe the Government could be much more flexible in those departments than it it is in other departments. I do not know what the procedure is for feedback on this information that is put out. I think that Senator Messner is listening intently to what I am saying. I hope that we get feedback about breaking the log-jam of delays in granting citizenship and, secondly, on the Regularisation of Status program.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Statement by Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I give full credit to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) for this statement. It is a very courageous document because it admits there have been cases in which people have prostituted Australia's refugee policy by being manipulated by the media. The Minister gives a couple of examples which, as I am mindful of the time, I will not reiterate. That is the first point. The second is the admission that some refugees are economically motivated as distinct from being in fear of political persecution in their homelands. I simply say this: I believe that what is lacking is the specifics. At the moment in Europe there is a backlog of refugees fleeing from the situation in Poland. I do not want us to have the problem we had with respect to Vietnamese refugees when people were saying: 'Are you giving priority to people from camps in Malaysia over those in Thailand or Hong Kong?' I raised this matter briefly with Senator Durack the other night. He did not have specific answers. I believe those refugees who face our posts in Europe, whether in Stockholm or Paris, have to be registered in some order so that justice is done. I think the Minister has referred in general terms to Poland and has given an overall figure of about 25,000.

Whatever the United Nations' concept of what we should or should not do about South East Asian refugees, I like to believe that the forgotten continent, Latin America, gets full credit. Senator Primmer and I have been fighting a battle about Uruguayans. We have been waiting a fortnight for a simple lift of 50 politically persecuted Uruguayans who were in a United Nations camp in the Argentine. I feel that we are lagging somewhat there, or perhaps I should say that there should be a more equal distribution. I am mindful of the time and I want other honourable senators to come into the play.

I make one final point. It concerns an economic problem. When we bring in political refugees we rightly are not rigid about their job skills and their physical qualities. I say that because I know that other honourable senators will agree with me that in another age other migrants' first idea of the lovely Australia was at the end of a jackhammer or shovelling coal into a furnace, when it was not such an easy country to work in. Many of the present political refugees-I have in mind the Vietnamese-have a rather light physique and are arguing whether they can lift particular weights in industry. I suppose that as a trade unionist I am all for the protection of people, but that other migrants did not have those safeguards is well known.

That gets me back to our tariff policy. If many of these people are to be put into the textile and clothing industry and even the rubber industry where the work is much lighter than that in a foundry, I believe those people who argue that we should lower our tariffs will find that we are in a jam when we face these people. The proof of that assertion is that trade union membership in the textile and clothing and rubber industries has dropped. I leave the matter with those words of wisdom because I know that at least one other senator wants to contribute to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) on the excellent paper that he has presented. It has been favourably received, even by the Opposition spokesman in another place. As one who came to this country as a refugee, I feel that I can say a few things about the Minister's statement. I am one of those 400,000 people who settled in Australia after World War II. I appreciate the humanitarianism of and the action taken by this Government in its in-depth study of the problems of refugees and how to solve them. We all know that the present Minister is one of the best Ministers we have had. He is the most humane. Therefore, I recommend to all honourable senators that they study this statement from the Minister. I particularly like the passages in the statement, as reported at page 991 of the House of Representatives Hansard, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where persons have been classified as refugees, Australia will continue to give priority consideration to those refugees with family in Australia.

This is one of the major points in the Minister's statement. Anyone who has been separated from his or her family knows how important it is that families are united. I commend the Minister and the Government on that matter. I am also very impressed that the Minister in his statement said:

The Government has also decided that it will no longer announce individual program ceilings for particular refugee groups. This will enable us to have maximum flexibility in responding to different or changing situations without creating undue expectations.
We all know the state of the world today and how vastly and quickly conditions in different countries change. The Minister also said:
As a result of the present review, I can renew assurances to people in Australia that our generous humanitarian response is directed only to those in genuine need.
He continued:

The present overall program for refugee and special humanitarian entry is now 24,500, the highest intake ever in this category . . . Polish refugees in this current year illustrate that Australia stands ready to respond to new and sudden refugee situations.

As Senator Mulvihill said, we have some problems with refugee intake and processing refugees from Vietnam. Therefore I was also delighted to read what the Minister said about special procedures which have been introduced to cope with the unexpected volume of migration applications as distinct from refugee applications. He stated:

Of the order of 4,400 Polish refugees and over 1,400 Polish migrants are expected to arrive in Australia this financial year and, in addition to that, there will be approximately another 1,600 East European refugees. This intake is expected to be numerically higher on a per capita basis than that of any other country.

That again proves my point about humanitarian government and the attitudes of the Australian people towards refugees. Anyone who has not gone through the traumatic experience of being a refugee would not appreciate what that means. I can assure all who are listening now that being a refugee is a position in which I would not wish anybody to be. It is not easy; it is very hard and is an incredible experience. I know that the Australian people in general will recognise that refugees take a step which involves a complete break with their old country and their old friends when they move to a completely new situation. The Opposition spokesman in the other place, in his reply to the Minister, mentioned that there are about 10 million to 16 million refugees in the world today. He gave an analysis of the figures and stated:
There are 6.3 million refugees in Africa; 3.1 million in Asia, which includes 1 .4 million from Afghanistan; 200,000 in Latin America and 3.5 million in the Middle East.

Later he stated that the Government should raise its voice to make the point that the number of refugees which we are taking-20,000 to 25,000-is a great number but still only a fraction of the total. We should analyse the figures to see why those people flee their countries. I am afraid-I do not think I am wrong -that the majority of refugees fled their country because of the regimes installed there. The majority of those countries are run by either socialist or communist dictatorships.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not apply to Latin America.

—I agree with Senator Mulvihill that that does not apply to Latin America. But if the honourable senator looks at the proportion of those who flee the so-called right wing regimes in Latin America and the proportion of those who flee socialist or communist regimes he will see the great difference. The question which arises is: Why did 200,000 people from Latin America want to come to Australia, Canada, France or the United States of America and not go to the Soviet Union? Why do those countries which have socialist or communist regimes not contribute a penny to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to help the humanitarian cause of the millions of people who fled their own country because of the system imposed there? Where is the humanitarian approach, the humanity of socialism or the humanitarian heart of the communist system to help those who left their country? This is another aspect of the refugee situation which we should look at. I commend the statement by the Minister and commend the Government for its humane policy on refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Industries Assistance Commission Report 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I do not want to delay the Senate for long on this matter. I will try to complete my remarks before the sitting of the Senate is suspended for lunch. I want to make the point here that in my opinion the Government presently has not followed the advice given to it in this Industries Assistance Commission recommendation. There is a very strong outcry from the Carpet Importers Association of Australia which, I think, has some considerable justification. The Government still seems bent on its heavy protection of the carpet industry in this country. In my view it is a somewhat inordinate protection. The Government really ought to take more advice from the IAC in these matters. It asks for its advice but frequently when it comes down to a question of reducing protection the Government does not take its advice. Carpet importers particularly have been considerably discriminated against, not just recently but in previous years. I think they have a case. They make that case regularly to the Government but the fairness of the whole proposition of carpet importers is totally ignored by the Government. I am asking the Government to listen more to what these importers and other importers have to say, certainly in the proper context of IAC reports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-by leave-proposed:

That the Senate- (1) recalls that the Australian Government condemned the invasion of Afghanistan by the Soviet Union on 27 December 1979 as a gross violation of the United Nations Charter and of Afghanistan's non-aligned status;

(2) notes that the international community, in particular the United Nations General Assembly, has repeatedly called for the immediate withdrawl of the foreign troops from Afghanistan and reaffirmed the right of the Afghan people to determine their own form of government free from outside intervention;

(3) deplores the continued fighting within Afghanistan, the tragic loss of life and destruction of property, and the suffering of the Afghan civilians who have been subjected to sustained and increasing military harassment, bombing and disruption;
(4) views with deep concern the plight of approximately 2.5 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan;
(5) notes that 21 March has been traditionally celebrated by the Afghan people as the beginning of their New Year;

(6) welcomes the decision by the European Parliament to designate 21 March 1982 as Afghanistan Day and make it the occasion on which international attention again should be focussed on the Soviet military occupation of Afghanistan, and

(7) declares also its intention to designate 21 March 1982 as a day for Australians to convey to the world their desire for the USSR to withdraw unconditionally from Afghanistan and allow a free, independent and truly non- aligned Afghanistan to be re-established.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one or two brief comments about this motion. This issue of Afghanistan and the responses of Western governments to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan has been debated over a long period in this Parliament. I do not resile from any of the comments that have been made by the Opposition. I remind the Senate that there was a bipartisan attitude at the time of the invasion of Afghanistan to the basic response that should be made to that invasion. There was a common expression of concern by both sides of the Parliament. We pointed out at the time, and still point out as a matter of regret, that there is a fundamental and strong gold thread of hypocrisy running through the attitude of the Western governments by way of response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. That hypocrisy was reflected in Australia by a greatly beaten-up debate about whether an Australian team should participate in the Olympic Games, accompanied by a refusal by this Government and, indeed, by other Western governments to impose sanctions against the Soviet Union which would have hurt the Soviet Union but which would also have hurt sections of our own communities. I refer to the imposing of embargoes on the sale of grain and so on to the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I wish to make is that, in a sense, this initiative is a pious, platitudinous monument to the failures of Western policy in providing a cohesive response to Soviet initiatives in areas such as Afghanistan or, for that matter, in Poland. Of course, that is something which is a cause for regret . I do not want to go into the debate which took place on an earlier occasion as to whether Afghanistan is, appropriately, a Soviet sphere of influence or a Western sphere of influence. I think our position was very firmly stated at the time; that Afghanistan, as far as the Opposition is concerned, has traditionally , always been regarded by international experts as falling within the so-called Soviet sphere of influence. That is a factor which ought to have been considered at the time. Nonetheless, nobody in the Senate, I believe, would do anything but deplore the continuing occupation of Afghanistan the same as, if we had a decent debate about foreign affairs in this Parliament, many of us would want to deplore United States foreign policy initiatives in southern and middle America. That, again, is an area in which the thin gold thread of hypocrisy runs through many of the statements that are made. I wish to refer particularly to paragraph 6 of the motion which states that the Government:
welcomes the decision by the European Parliament to designate 21 March 1982 as Afghanistan Day . . .

I am glad that the Government welcomes the initiative of the European Parliament in relation to this matter. I wish it would do it on a more even-handed way in relation to other matters. Yesterday I asked a question about the trial and persecution of trade union leaders in Turkey, a matter in respect of which the European Parliament has made strong statements to the Turkish Government. It appears that this is a matter in respect of which the Australian Government has made no response other than to say that the Europeans are doing the right thing. Again this is an example of double standards.

Finally, I do not think the declaration or recognition by Australia of Afghanistan Day will do any more, for example, than stopping an Olympic team from going to the Soviet Union did to influence events in Afghanistan. At the time we said it would do nothing to influence events in Afghanistan. We said it would have no effect on the regime in the Soviet Union and the foreign policy of that regime. Designating 21 March 1982 as Afghanistan Day will have no effect on what is happening in Afghanistan. It will be of no comfort to the people of Afghanistan. What might have been a comfort to the people of Afghanistan and what one might have hoped to hear in support of this statement is some further initiatives from the Australian Government to help Afghan refugees in Pakistan. That would have been welcome because that would have been a positive and humane contribution which this Government could have made. But the declaration of a day called Afghanistan Day in Australia, as I said, will be cold comfort to the people of Afghanistan. Indeed, perhaps it will be only a reminder to them of the fact that Western democracies do not match their words with deeds; a reminder to them, as an oppressed people, that in countries like Australia, people are prepared to make empty gestures on these sorts of matters but are not prepared to make a contribution such as additional humanitarian relief to refugees of the type I mentioned which would be a positive and constructive contribution in human terms. Apart from those comments, which indicate my own sincere qualifications about this motion, and apart from the qualifications that I have about the purpose of the motion, I see no other objections to the motion being adopted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my leader, Senator Button, I wonder what is the motivation, the purpose and the strategy of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) in introducing such a motion. Substantially, it reinforces and endorses the previous stand taken by the Parliament on the continuing intervention by one of the super-powers, the Soviet Union, in the affairs of Afghanistan. I think we have made our position clear. Certainly, I want to be on the public record as condemning the intervention of one of the major powers in the internal affairs of a country such as Afghanistan which was one of the non-aligned countries of the world. Even though it could be argued, ad infinitum, that the Government of Afghanistan invited the presence of Soviet troops into that country, that government did so, I believe, on the basis that there was a sphere of influence that had to be recognised and that the Soviet Union was entitled to be concerned about the events and therefore was entitled to intervene to the extent that it has. One is entitled, having recognised that fact, to say: 'Where does an impoverished country like Afghanistan, which clearly has a division of opinion amongst its own people, get the very extensive resources to fight the war that is taking place in that country?'. Therefore, one is entitled to have some doubts about who is sponsoring the rebel forces against the government of the day in that country. We are probably seeing part of a super-power rivalry being fought out in Afghanistan, with one super-power supplying resources and another super-power supplying an equal amount of resources to continue the tragedy that we know is taking place in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that raises the matter of spheres of influence which I think we ought to have a view about. I think we ought to be expressing a view on that. The motion fails to do that. For example, I ask how we can justify the United States of America's claim that Vietnam was an appropriate place for the intervention of American troops. Are we saying that in that part of Asia the United States had a sphere of influence? Are we saying that America was entitled to intervene in a country far removed from its borders? Are we entitled to say that the Australian Government, without any economic, social or political considerations, was entitled similarly to be involved? In the tragedy of Vietnam we saw an example of the intervention by a super-power in a country attempting to establish only the very important principle of self-determination.

The motion does not accept the principle of sphere of influence. The motion makes no mention of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Chile or all the other Latin American countries where the United States of America view is that Latin America , being a sphere of influence, entitles it to interfere in the internal affairs of those countries. We are aware of the fact that the super-powers themselves have decided, without the authority of the peoples concerned or of other world nations, on a subdivision of the world into two blocs-two spheres of influence. Therefore, having established those sorts of principles, they have set about saying that they are entitled to take whatever steps are necessary to maintain the so-called security of their borders. That is the justification of the Soviet Union's presence in Afghanistan. That is a justification which I and my party do not accept. We do not believe there is a moral, political or any other justification for that sort of approach. That is why, in the belief that we are supporting fundamental principles of self-determination-the right of people to determine their own affairs-we have been consistent in our approach whether it be to Afghanistan, Poland, Vietnam, East Timor, El Salvador or any other part of the world. We do not abrogate our responsibilities. We do not delegate to the super-powers the responsibility and the right to say: 'Well, this is a sphere of influence. It is on our border. Our security is affected; therefore we are entitled to intervene'.

We saw that absurd situation when Indonesia, a country of some 200 million people-true, not necessarily a major power in the sense of the founding members of the United Nations; nevertheless a power of some significance-said that a little area containing some 600,000 people who wanted to have their independence to determine their own affairs could be invaded and annexed and made part of the big power. This was despite the fact that there was no indigenous relationship or basic threat to the security of Indonesia whatsoever. We are seeing repeated tragedies that are part of the Latin American situation. In the small countries such as El Salvador, Nicaragua and maybe even Colombia, Guatemala and all the other countries the United States Government and the President are taking a more than unusual interest and involving the Government and taxpayers of the United States in a massive intervention in the internal affairs of those countries.

Those matters reveal the weakness of the Government's motion. It is one-sided. It is a motion of double standards. It does not establish basic principles about the rights of the peoples concerned. It ignores the attempts made by President Reagan, an aged ham actor, to suggest that he is entitled to do what he is doing in El Salvador. He suggests that it is wrong for the people's movement in that country to seek assistance from anybody else. This is a classic case of double standards, cant, hypocrisy and humbug of a mammoth worldwide order. There is a failure by the Government in any circumstances to take an even handed position in these matters. It fails to make any representations to the Government of the United States to allow the people in Latin American countries to determine their own affairs.

I will look at the Latin American situation in a little more detail. It is an area of great riches. It is also an area of extreme poverty. It is an area where the very wealthy and the foreign investors have bled the countries dry. All the people want to do is to determine their own affairs. They have been subjected to unbelievable interference by the American President, the American Central Intelligence Agency, and other American agencies active in that area.

One has to condemn that with great vehemence having regard to what is being done similarly in another part of the world-in Afghanistan. We cannot just condemn another of the super-powers for intervening on its southern borders. We cannot say that the Soviet Union should not have the right to intervene to the extent that it has even though, in strictly protocol terms, it can be argued with some conviction that the Government of Afghanistan did in fact invite the Soviet troops in. The Afghanistan Government did invoke the treaty that existed between itself and the Soviet Union. Similarly of course the Government in El Salvador can say that it sought assistance from overseas countries, to wit the United States, in order to resolve the civil war or civil disturbance that is going on in that country. One thing which the Socialist International, the Australian Labor Party and those in the movement for world peace are sure about is that we cannot have double standards in respect to these matters. Whilst I would not go on the public record as opposing the motion, I think it falls far short of our obligations as a section of the national Parliament. We are being one-sided if we concern ourselves only with the tragic situation that has been in existence for some three years in Afghanistan and at the same time fail to recognise our responsibilities in respect of those countries in Latin America.

As one who has played an active part in Amnesty International-an organisation which now enjoys the bipartisan support of the national Parliament-I can say that there is not one meeting when we in that organisation do not have brought to our attention examples of countless numbers of parliamentarians of those countries being tortured, murdered, imprisoned and driven into exile as a result of their attempts to establish in a parliamentary democratic way the rights of their countries to determine their own affairs. That is the concern of all democrats, of all of those who want to see the rights of people protected. We in that organisation feel the need constantly to press and plead with the Australian Government to take up these matters of human rights in those countries currently being affected by the United States presence, whether this be in the form of advisers or massive sales of sophisticated weapons and armaments. I believe that the United States presence in Latin America constitutes as much a breach of protocol, of proper relations between nations and of human rights as indeed does the Soviet presence in Afghanistan. Reluctantly I am forced to support the motion but I point out its grave weaknesses as a result of this Government's not adopting an even-handed position on the protection of the rights of people wherever they are in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I tried to interject a few minutes ago because I had no idea from Senator Gietzelt's speech or indeed from Senator Button's speech whether the Opposition was supporting the Government on this motion.
—I will send you a cable next time so that you will know. Would you like that? Should I ask your permission?

—I would be very obliged if you would because otherwise I would never know where the Opposition stood. You virtually said: 'Ignore all my rhetoric. Ignore everything I am saying. We do, after all, support the Government's motion.' The only way in which the people of Australia and indeed the Government would have any idea whether the Opposition was supporting the motion would be if Senator Gietzelt sent us a cable. We have had all sorts of rhetoric from Senator Gietzelt. He said that this Government has not given support in relation to other problems in the world. He referred to all of the current internal problems in every other country. He did not mention that this is not an internal problem. This issue is the indefensible position of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in going straight into Afghanistan as a force against the will of the people. It is not an internal problem. Senator Gietzelt was accusing the United States of America-obviously that is the country to which he was referring-of supporting the local forces in Afghanistan. I doubt very much that Senator Gietzelt or Senator Button has ever visited Afghanistan.
—Would you like to go there?
—I have already visited Afghanistan. I was there for 10 days.
—When?
—It has changed.

—It has changed, as Senator Haines has said. Those people have been subjected to incredible situations by the USSR. Opposition senators can laugh but every time they laugh or speak it comes across to the Australian public loud and clear whom they are covering for. The European Parliament has said that 21 March this year is to be a special day in Afghanistan-New Year's Day. The European Parliament has asked the world to think of Afghanistan on that day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt, to use his own word, is 'reluctantly' supporting this motion. I would say that he is reluctantly supporting this motion only because he has been caucused so to do. I cannot understand how the Opposition can possibly profess not to be supporting the USSR invasion. Sometimes, when I am sitting in this chamber and honourable senators opposite are in their places, I cannot understand their reasoning. People reading the speeches of honourable senators opposite will wonder whether they are supporting the Government's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't regard me as a ratbag but they will regard you as one.

—I believe Senator Gietzelt is entirely wrong in that respect. ( Quorum formed). Senator Gietzelt said that the European Parliament was indulging in humbug. The United Nations General Assembly would not agree. It has called for the immediate withdrawal from Afghanistan of all foreign troops. As I said earlier, Senator Gietzelt and Senator Button have not been to Afghanistan. No doubt that is why, through their ignorance, they presume that America is supporting the local people there. America does not need to support the local people. The USSR cannot possibly penetrate that rugged country to defeat the tribes. If honourable senators opposite had visited that country they would realise that through the course of history nobody has been able-many have tried- to eradicate those people. Nobody has been able to conquer Afghanistan and its people. They are a tough people. They are able to live in the very small pockets of agricultural land that are available to them. The USSR will fail again. There is no way in which it can win this war, try as it may. It can use every inhumane means that it can muster but it cannot ever conquer these very tough people in Afghanistan. Having listened to the debate, it seems to me incredible that we cannot decide which side the Opposition supports. It is incredible also that Senator Geitzelt should end his speech by saying that he supports very reluctantly the motion presently before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot allow this motion to come before this chamber without speaking to it. I have to shake my thoughts back into order after listening to the remarks of Senator Walters. She rambles on in such a way that one questions whether she should be allowed by the Government to enter into an important debate such as this as she reduces it to the lowest possible denominator. The problem that faces me is that the motion has suddenly come before us and is directed to a problem in a particular way. I know the advice that the Senate should give to the Soviet Union is to get out of Afghanistan as soon as possible. I do not doubt that the Soviet Union would answer: 'We would like to get out as soon as possible'. The Soviet Union went into Afghanistan reluctantly and now it is in a position where it is difficult for it to disengage. We ought to be encouraging the Soviet Union to take its troops out of Afghanistan. I do not think we advance that cause by a resolution such as the one before us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very selective on the part of the Government to bring forward such a motion. I could go through this resolution and replace the word 'Afghanistan' with the word 'Cyprus' and if I put in the word 'Cyprus' I would expose a situation which is as tragic as, if not more tragic than, that which is occurring in Afghanistan at present. If we relate the disaster of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus to numbers, the disaster in Cyprus is considerable. Let us look at how our attention seems to be directed away from our problems. Cyprus is a Commonwealth nation. It is very much the concern of Australia that the invasion of Cyprus should come to an end and that the Turkish troops in Cyprus should be removed. We should be applying ourselves even more to that problem than to the problem of Afghanistan. For this reason I believe this motion to be suspect. I believe it is selective for a purpose. It is part of a campaign of anti-Sovietism which, admittedly, does not do the Soviet Union any good but which does Australia no good either. The matter has to be resolved in the context of world peace. We quickly have to come to an understanding with the Soviet Union. We should not allow ourselves to be brought into the environment of the cold war. That is Reagan's purpose. We ought to deny Reagan his purpose. We ought to be moving towards understanding and communication. This sort of proposition does not help, especially when it is so selective.

Again if we are talking about troops occupying other countries we could look at the situation in several places. We could look at the Israeli occupation of certain territories which the Israelis refused to the Palestinians. The Government ought to agree to a resolution in this regard but it is not prepared to do it. Apparently it is not prepared to agree to such a resolution concerning Cyprus. It is certainly not going to agree to a resolution later this year in favour of our having a Timor day, setting up some sort of organised protest about what has happened in Timor. Although this proposition expresses our strong objection to the existence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan, the manner in which it has been introduced, the terms in which it has been drafted and its selectivity indicate that it is part of a campaign of anti-Sovietism. That is the basis upon which this document should be considered.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter embraced in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing is regarded by the Government as a significant one and one that should be taken seriously, researched and studied. The Government made an interim response, about which the Jessop Committee was informed, and then sought consultations with the Presiding Officers so that it could then reach a set of recommendations to bring back to the Senate and the Parliament. There have been some difficulties, as you know, Mr President, in completing these consultations. The Government realises that it is desirable to bring the matter to a conclusion. I seek the indulgence of the Senate to schedule this matter for debate next Thursday, today week. I give an undertaking that I would very readily schedule it. I am seeking the time both to complete the discussions with the Presiding Officers and to give the Government an opportunity to complete its deliberations. I do so with the full understanding that this matter has dragged on. It is not of my choosing that it should so do. I seek the indulgence of the Senate in light of the fact that the next matter listed for debate is a contingency motion. I ask the Senate to support my request to re-schedule this matter for full discussion next Thursday.
—Am I to understand that the Leader wishes to move a contingency motion for deferment?

—No, I do no more than make that statement. I think it is a matter of whether the Opposition seeks to continue with its contingency motion. I have made that statement against the background that the next item of business this afternoon is that contingency motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have listened with interest to the remarks of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). I point out that whilst the Government regards the matter as a significant one, we of the Opposition-I think I also speak on behalf of all members of the all party Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Staffing and Appropriations that was appointed by the Senate to inquire into and to bring down recommendations on the matter-regard it as being one of the most important recommendations that this Parliament could consider. If I might use the Canberra Times as an exhibit in this debate, I note that on 7 December last it ran an editorial headed 'Parliament the Master'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: When Parliament resumes on February 16, the Government will be obliged to take action on a motion carried by the Senate on the last day of the session, November 26, which has historic implications for Australian democracy. Decisive action would, eventually, make Parliament master of the five departments which serve it and work within its own building. These departments administer the Senate, the House of Representatives, the Joint House, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Parliamentary Library.

They are now controlled and dominated by the Government, as if they were ordinary Government departments. They have been denied the means and the confidence to serve with proper effect the Parliament, which must be sustained against the Government if democracy is to be real. Parliament's tame acceptance of this state of affairs has been a disgrace. Now, the Senate is beginning to reject it.

I would raise other matters canvassed in that editorial if I had sufficient time but I emphasise that this debate, the gravamen of which is the subject of Senator Jessop's notice of motion, is one of the most important and significant debates that the Parliament could be conducting. By the establishment of such a committee Parliament is asserting its supremacy over the Executive and over the bureaucracy. We of the Opposition are determined to have Senator Jessop's motion not only scheduled for next Thursday, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate suggested, but also resolved by next Thursday before the Parliament rises for the Easter break.

As I have emphasised, the Select Committee on Parliament's Staffing and Appropriations was an all party select committee comprising Government members, members of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats. It was established as long ago as May 1980. It reported in June 1981-nearly 12 months ago. The report was debated in the Senate on 26 November and following that debate the Senate adopted the Committee's recommendations. Following the adoption of the report by the Senate, Senator Jessop, as the chairman of the former select committee, rightly gave notice of the motion that now stands in his name on the Notice Paper. When that notice of motion by Senator Jessop was called on, despite the fact that the Senate had adopted-from recollection unanimously-the Committee's report, instead of the Government declaring the matter to be formal, Senator Peter Baume, who was then in charge of Government business in the Senate, declared the matter to be not formal. What happened to Senator Jessop's notice of motion? It became General Business item No. 55 on the Senate Notice Paper. General Business notice of motion No. 1 on the Senate Notice Paper was given as long ago as November 1980.

Obviously, had action not been taken yesterday by my colleague Senator Robertson, by way of a contingent notice of motion involving the suspension of Standing Orders to enable Senator Jessop to bring on for debate the terms of his motion, item No. 55 on the Notice Paper probably would have remained there until this Parliament was prorogued. Therefore we regard the matter as very important indeed. That is the reason why Senator Robertson, on behalf of the Opposition and also as a former member of the Senate Select Committee, gave his notice of motion yesterday. Frankly, I cannot for the life of me understand what appears to me and to members of the Select Committee to be uncertainty, suspicion or hesitancy on the part of the Government. As we see it, there can be no problem with the establishment of such a committee. I have heard doubt expressed around the place about the constitutionality of such a committee being established by the Parliament. I can tell those who are suggesting that the committee would be unconstitutional that senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department gave evidence to the Committee and said that there was no constitutional difficulty at all in the establishment by the Parliament of a committee of this nature because the Parliament is master of its own destiny.

As I said, this is an important recommendation. The proposed committee is an important committee. By its establishment we would assert the supremacy of Parliament, not only over the Executive but particularly over the bureaucracy. I remind all members of the Executive that before they can become members of the Executive they have to be members of the Parliament. They have to remain so. This is an important recommendation. We believe that it should be determined. We are determined not to let this matter go through to the keeper. We will face up to it when it comes to the wicket next Thursday. Whilst we appreciate what the Leader of the Government has said and that he will give an undertaking that the matter will be scheduled for debate next Thursday, I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that we will be moving next week to bring the matter to a determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I support what Senator McClelland has said. There was a lot of good will among members of the tripartite Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing that was given the task of examining this important subject. As a result, a report came forward and was adopted by the Senate on the motion of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) in November. It was recognised in the body of the report that the Government has to give this matter consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The report was very moderate in its approach. It recognised that changes need to be approached carefully. That is embodied in the spirit of the report. I believe that each member of the Committee understood when I suggested that the Government Leader needed some time to give this matter consideration. However, it has gone on for a long time. I was glad when I heard the Leader of the Government say today that the matter will be debated thoroughly on Thursday of next week. I lend my support and that of Senator Missen to what Senator McClelland has said. We are determined to resolve the matter next Thursday so that appropriate action can be taken before the Easter break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bounty (Drilling Bits) Act 1980 and the Bounty (Non-Adjustable Wrenches) Act 1981 to extend the bounty assistance under those Acts until 31 December 1982 but at half the rates of bounty and half the annual limits on the amount of available bounty as specified in the principal Acts. The bounty schemes, which terminated on 31 December 1981, provided short term assistance to Australian producers and manufacturers of cemented carbide drilling bits and non-adjustable wrenches pending further inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission.

Bounty assistance on non-adjustable wrenches was payable at 11 cents for each bountiable implement and the total bounty payment was limited to a maximum of $ 620,000 during the bounty period. Bounty assistance on cemented carbide drilling bits was scaled on the basis of bit size and the total bounty payments were limited to a maximum of $150,000 in any one year. The extension of the bounty assistance to these industries follow the Government's acceptance of the recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report of 30 June 1981 on 'Cutlery, Industrial Knives and Handtools'.

In respect of non-adjustable wrenches the Industries Assistance Commission found that the major local manufacturer, Siddons Industries Ltd, improved its market performance since receiving the bounty and was rationalising its operation. The Commission considered this industry to be relatively economically efficient at moderate levels of assistance but was concerned that the sudden withdrawal of the additional assistance might cause resources to move out of this activity. It therefore recommended bounty assistance at half the previous rate for a further 12 months.

In respect of the drilling bits the Commission found that the greater part of the local industry producing rock drills is, with moderate levels of tariff assistance, relatively economically efficient and that its further development is consistent with the Government's broad objective of promoting a more efficient manufacturing sector. The Commission recommended that, in order to provide the local producer with the opportunity to improve its market performance further, short term bounty assistance for drilling bits should be extended for a further 12 month period but at half the rate of those previously payable. After 31 December 1982, the manufacture of non-adjustable wrenches will be assisted by a long term General Tariff of 25 per cent and the production of drilling bits will be assisted by a long term General Tariff of 15 per cent.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
