DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill which seeks to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1976 and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act of 1979. I state at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill, although we have reservations about some aspects of it. I place on record my thanks to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) for his co-operation in making available to the Opposition his officers and information to help us to grasp the consequences of the legislation we are currently debating.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. A number of the amendments are in response, we understand, to requests by Aboriginal and Islander peoples and, therefore, have our support. Clauses 4, 5 and 6 which provide for the Hermannsburg area to be granted to the Aboriginal traditional owners in a form more in accordance with their wishes certainly have the Opposition support. The Hermannsburg traditional owners wanted five separate land trusts instead of one and they wanted to vary the membership and chairmanship of trusts. These amendments accommodate their requests. The Aboriginal people who live in the Hermannsburg area have been waiting for a long time for their land. The area is, as the Minister pointed out , one of the areas listed in Schedule 1 of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act for granting to an Aboriginal land trust, and is the only area listed in Schedule 1 which has not yet been granted. The Opposition feels it is high time that the people of Hermannsburg have title to their land. I point out that the need is all the more urgent in view of the Northern Territory Government's recent moves to pre-empt the grant of land at Hermannsburg in respect of the area of the proposed Palm Valley gas project.

I would like to comment briefly on this aspect to bring to light the Northern Territory Government's determination to do everything in its power to frustrate the intentions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The Northern Territory Government recently indicated to the Central Land Council that it would resume the area of the Palm Valley pipeline and the area of gas production under the Northern Territory Petroleum (Prospecting and Mining) Act. It indicated it would do this regardless of the status of the land as land scheduled for grant to Aboriginals, thus removing the need for an easement agreement with the Aboriginal traditional owners. This Bill, by making it possible to grant the Hermannsburg area immediately, will pre-empt the Northern Territory Government's resumption and protect the rights of the Aboriginal traditional owners. I congratulate the Minister, Senator Baume, for acting quickly in this matter and urge him to make the Hermannsburg grant as soon as possible after the passage of this legislation.

The Opposition is aware of the pressure being put on the Federal Government by the Northern Territory Government to ensure the emasculation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. We are aware that negotiations are still under way between Aboriginal land councils and Federal and Northern Territory governments about further amendments to the Act. Let me put the Minister on notice that the Federal Opposition will examine all proposed amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act with great care to ensure that the Act is not weakened. Conversely let me assure the Minister of the wholehearted support of the Australian Labor Party for any legislative moves to resist the Northern Territory Government's attack on land rights.

Other aspects of the Bill currently before the Senate which the ALP does not oppose are contained in clause 10 which allows for the granting of legal aid in respect of the closure of seas hearings under the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Act 1978. Clauses 8 and 11 which allow for a consolidated title for Bathurst and Melville islands to be held by the Tiwi Land Trust and the granting of a small additional area also have Opposition support. We believe such changes to be in accordance with the wishes of the Tiwi people. The Labor Party does, however, have reservations about clause 7 of the Bill. This clause allows the Minister to vary the number of land trusts in a grant area and to give land recommended for grants to land trusts in stages rather than as one grant. There is nothing objectionable in these amendments themselves. However we must place on record that we believe the impetus for their introduction at this time is the facilitation of the Jabiluka uranium project.

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced in a Press release dated 8 March 1982 the granting of all the land recommended for grant in the Alligator River stage 2 claim with the exception of a number of areas affected by High Court actions. The land to be granted included 95 per cent of the Jabilunka project area. On 16 March 1982 the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, announced conditional approval for the development of the Jabiluka uranium deposits. We now have this legislation. It is not difficult to see that the Government is in a rush to get Jabiluka moving as quickly as posible and Mr Anthony has made Aboriginal agreement a condition of approval. Before the Northern Land Council can complete an agreement with the Jabilunka partners it is, of course, necessary for the Aboriginals to be given official title to the land and thus Senator Baume's statement of a grant earlier this week and this legislation. The Labor Party does not propose to obstruct this legislation. I recognise that the Minister can grant the land in question-including 95 per cent of the Jabiluka project area-whether or not this Bill is passed. Without the passage of this Bill those areas of the Alligator Rivers which cannot be immediately granted due to High Court action could be lost to the Aboriginal traditional owners and, for this reason, the Labor Party will not oppose its passage.

At this point I would like to state the total opposition of the Labor Party to the mining and export of uranium. I would also like to emphasise the Labor Party 's opposition to mining-that includes all mining-within the area of the Kakadu National Park. The Jabiluka area, of course, falls within stage 2 of the park which is yet to be declared. I would also like to comment on clause 9 of the Bill which relates to the repayment of amounts advanced to land councils to Consolidated Revenue. Under this clause repayments will come from moneys allocated for the administration of land councils rather than direct from the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account. I have received a telex from the Central Land Council indicating its opposition to such a change. I presume that the Minister has received a similar telex. To facilitate the Minister's comments on the Central Land Council's objections I seek leave to table the telex at this stage.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Central Land Council has also raised with me the issue of sufficient time for consideration of the proposed amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. Senator Baume in his second reading speech indicated that the changes proposed in this Bill had been thoroughly canvassed with the land councils. However, yesterday I received an urgent telex from the Central Land Council requesting that debate on this Bill be delayed for 24 hours as it had received the Bill only yesterday morning. I understand the proposed changes had been discussed with the Central Land Council in general terms. However, members of the Council had not seen a draft of this legislation or had the opportunity to seek legal advice on its effects. The Minister, in his haste to have this legislation introduced and passed in two days, did not, I submit, give the Central Land Council sufficient opportunity to examine the legislation and comment on it prior to debate in this chamber. Even taking into account the urgency of the Hermannsburg situation, I think it would have been more appropriate for the Minister to ensure that the Council had an opportunity to examine and comment on the Bill before it came into this chamber for debate.
—I thought it was not proper to make the draft Bill available until it was introduced here. It is just a question of propriety.

—I take note of the Minister's comment on the matters raised by the Central Land Council. I raised them for comment by the Minister because I have received representations. I presume that the Minister will make more detailed comments in reply.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I repeat that in general the Opposition is pleased to support this legislation insofar as it will finally give land title to the Hermannsburg Aboriginal communities and is substantially in accord with the wishes of various Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. In general, I think the flexibility given to the Minister in the matter of granting land under this legislation is desirable and is in the interests of the Aboriginal people. Our only reservations about this Bill are its interrelationship with the Government' s determination to proceed with the uranium mine in the Jabiluka area. However, I recognise that that government decision cannot be affected by any attempt on the part of the Opposition to amend this legislation. At this stage, I make it clear to the Minister that the Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall briefly indicate the position of the Australian Democrats in relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1982. We will be supporting the Bill with one reservation which I will mention shortly. I believe that if other legislation were introduced into this chamber with at least as much care and consultation as this one has been we would, in fact, avoid many of the problems that could subsequently arise. I believe that the approach of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in tabling the Bill here first is the correct parliamentary procedure. It is a pity that the pressure that has been placed on the Federal Government by the Northern Territory Government has telescoped the debate to such an extent that we have run into a couple of problems in relation to two items. I do not believe, however, that that was in any way anything to do with the Minister's activities. I place on record our commendation of the activities of the Minister in regard to this Bill, for the extensive consultations that he has enabled to take place and for the information he has provided to the Senate and to honourable senators prior to the Bill coming into the House. For that we are very appreciative.

SPEECH.PARA: Our one reservation-it is one that Senator Ryan has already raised-relates to clause 9 of the Bill. We hope that the telex which came from the Central Land Council will be addressed by the Minister in detail so that we will be able to satisfy ourselves about the types of problems that were raised. I believe that some of them are genuine ones. In a sense probably they ultimately come down to a matter of principle. The feeling of the Australian Democrats is that self- determination of the Aboriginal people is the ultimate principle upon which a judgment should rest. In this case there is some difficulty as to whether it is the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Authority or the land councils that would most adequately represent that position in the long term. I made our concern known to the Minister prior to his introducing the Bill. I hope that he will place on record his position in relation to that.

I think ultimately our position would have to be that we accept the Bill as it is presented but we hope that the Minister will seek to meet the points that have been raised, in particular, by the Central Land Council. If there is still any dissatisfaction at that stage I believe that we may have to seek some further action in relation to clause 9. I hope that we will be able to give the Bill as rapid a passage as possible both here and in the other place so that possible problems will not arise in the Northern Territory Government and so the land which is currently being granted to Aboriginals in the Northern Territory will swiftly become theirs. We do not see ourselves causing any legal difficulties in that regard. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Bill. We await the Minister's comments in relation to the Central Land Council's problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1982. This Bill proposes some significant changes. The five main aspects of the Bill are as follows: The grant of the title deed to Hermannsburg land, the consolidation of the title over Bathurst and Melville islands, the grant of land on report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, repayment of moneys advanced to land councils from revenue, and the payment of legal costs for people involved in Land Commissioner hearings in respect of closure of seas applications. As honourable senators can see, all the changes are of considerable significance. The first two were specifically requested by the Aboriginal people of the areas concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly interested in the grant of the title deed on Hermannsburg land. This story goes back quite a long time to the beginning of the granting of land rights in the area when the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act was brought in in 1976. It was clearly indicated in those days by the Aboriginal people of Hermannsburg that they were dissatisfied with the fact that there was to be only one land trust for the whole area. They made many very strong protests and submissions to the Government asking it to consider having a series of land trusts, each having its piece of paper in the form of a grant in fee simple over its own land. The principle that was enunciated by the people of Hermannsburg was that they could speak for their land and for no one else's land and no other person could speak for their land. They were saying that one grant in fee simple did not recognise the traditional ownership of the land. The submissions that were put to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs of the day, Mr Viner, brought about a statement from the Minister that the Government would continue to explore the possibility of the title being held directly by the traditional owners themselves and that it was the aim of the Government eventually to achieve this goal but the subject presented considerable legal and practical difficulties. It is now, I suppose, some six years since that promise and that promise has been fulfilled. I commend the Government for that action.

In the meantime a lot of work has been going on behind the scenes. I take the opportunity of expressing the commendation of, I believe, many people who have witnessed the work carried out by Pastor Paul Albrecht, the field superintendent at Hermannsburg, Rex Ziersch, the former teacher at the school, and Garry Stoll, the superintendent of Hermannsburg mission. These people in the last few years have put in practically all of their time tracing the geneology and anthropology of the Aboriginal people of that area. They have carried out vast amounts of research. They have camped out and lived with the people for many months on end to gain a complete understanding of the people of that area. I believe that the work these people have done has brought about to quite a degree the measures which were introduced by the Government and are being debated today. At Hermannsburg the small clan groups will have their own title-their own piece of paper, as they express it. The land title will be held by the Aboriginal people. It has been said that the Northern Territory Government is endeavouring to emasculate the Northern Territory land rights Act. That, of course, is completely wrong. It is to be stressed that in all the negotiations on Aboriginal matters in the Northern Territory that have taken place between the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and the various land councils there has always been agreement after discussion. It is a fact that the Northern Territory supports the land rights proposed. Over the years there have been plans for a gas pipeline from Palm Valley to Alice Springs which will put Alice Springs on to natural gas-a very desirable thing. This is also desired by the Aboriginal people of the area. For some considerable time now they have been requesting and, indeed, pressing for the completion of the negotiations. When the negotiations are completed and the gas starts to flow to Alice Springs considerable royalties will go to those people. They are realistic enough to see that the royalties will bring considerable benefits to them.

I believe that far too much has been made of the present situation. It has been many years now since gas was discovered in the area. The Magellan Petroleum Corporation was the discoverer and has been the developer over the years. This project has been held up while negotiations have taken place. It is natural now that all interested parties wish it to proceed. When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) speaks in reply I ask that he clearly indicate whether, when the legislation has been passed and the grants in fee simple are made available to the people, arrangements for the easement as requested by the Aboriginal people will be carried out as quickly as possible. Of course, this will enable the negotiations to continue, the tenders for the pipeline to be called and everything to be brought to a successful conclusion. I think there is very little to say about the granting of title over Bathurst and Melville islands. The Tiwi Land Council is the youngest land council of the three. The Tiwis have proved that they are well capable of looking after their interests. I believe the Bill contains just a minor amendment in this regard to have these and other islands included in the Tiwi land. The grants of land on reports of the Land Commissioner have been discussed at length. It was a reasonable request and I wish to make no comment on it.

The repayment of moneys advanced to land councils from revenue is a matter of particular importance. Honourable senators will realise that over the years substantial amounts have been paid to the land councils to help meet administrative costs in the early years of their formation when royalty payments were relatively low and activity on land claims and mining negotiations was at a high level. Royalties were small and this brought about a situation in which the Government had to make advances to land councils to allow them to meet their administrative costs. To date some $1,598,000 has been advanced. The provisions presently in the Act require the payment to Consolidated Revenue as a once-only lump sum. I do not think that is realistic. I commend the Government for bringing in this amending legislation which will now provide for gradual repayments at the Minister's discretion as surpluses become available. In the Northern Territory, mining royalties will accrue tremendously in the next few years; they will amount to many tens of millions of dollars. As the money becomes available, the money that was advanced to the land councils will be repaid. Section 64 (1) of the parent Act provides that 40 per cent of the royalties is to be distributed among land councils to meet their administrative costs. If repayments were not made from this 40 per cent, the amounts available to Aboriginals generally in the Territory would be reduced.

Already the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account disbursements to Aboriginals in the Northern Territory have been greatly reduced because of the large amounts going to land councils and communities directly affected by mining. Numerous complaints have been received from communities seeking ABTA assistance to develop enterprises and to help improve living conditions. The ABTA Advisory Committee, which is composed of representatives of the three land councils, has very firmly recommended repayments from the land councils' share of royalties. This was indicated in the letter tabled by the Minister in the Senate on 2 December 1981. It is appropriate that advances for land council costs be repaid from the share of royalties allocated by the Parliament. There is no question of the money not being repaid. Of course, this is a point that has been discussed at length, particularly in the Northern Territory, over the last few months. I make the particular point that it also means that the moneys for the administration of the land councils will come from that share of the royalties. That means that the other moneys, the 60 per cent, will be paid to the traditional owners under the formula that was set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. So there will be no chance whatsoever of the administrative costs of the various land councils being taken out of the moneys due to the traditional owners through the formula.

I go on to mention the assistance provided in the payment of legal costs of people involved in Land Commission hearings on closure of seas applications. The actual principle has been very contentious. The principle, which was introduced some time ago, and agreed to by the Federal Government, is that people involved in land claims-that is, people who wish to put their points of view on particular land claims because they feel that there is injustice or that the claims have some effect on their actual conditions-can make a claim for funds to pay legal expenses, provided they can prove that their financial situation is such that they cannot pay their own legal costs. The principle has now been extended to those people who wish to oppose claims on the coast of northern Australia. I wish to say only one thing about this, and I have quite strong feelings about it. A type of means test is applied to people who claim financial assistance. Previously it was applied in respect of land claims and now it will be applied in respect of closure of seas applications. I once again ask the Government to give sympathetic treatment to people who make such claims for payment of legal expenses. Very many people and small organisations in the Territory do not have the financial ability to stand up to the huge costs involved in land claim hearings. I believe at times these people are hard put to meet these legal expenses. I suggest to the Government that, even now, it should not take the hard attitude that I believe it has taken. I believe the means test system has been a little too hard and that other people should be given legal assistance. In this instance such people will include fishermen and those people who are living on and making their livelihoods from the coast and the islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the professional fishermen have already made an application for assistance.

—I believe so. This organisation could well be considered for such legal assistance. All in all, I support the legislation. I think it is very good legislation. I note that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in his second reading speech, said that it is not to be confused with the present negotiations that are taking place between the Federal Government, the Northern Territory Government and the land councils in regard to further amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That particular parcel of legislation is of considerable importance and, like many other people in the Northern Territory, I hope that the negotiations will continue as quickly as possible. They have considerable ramifications for the whole of the Northern Territory. I look forward to the day when that further package of legislation comes into the Senate where it may be processed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly interested in that package of legislation which has yet to come before the Senate because I believe it has a lot to do with the future well -being of the people of the Northern Territory. By that I mean the ability of both races to live alongside each other or to live in what I call co-existence. I believe it essential for the future of the Territory that these matters be considered and rectified as quickly as possible. There can be no future for the Northern Territory if the people of the Northern Territory cannot co-exist. So I encourage the Government and all those people who are participating in the discussions at present to pursue them as quickly as possible so that the amendments may be brought into the Senate. When they come before the Senate I hope that all sides-the Australian Democrats, the Opposition and the Government- will see that they are for the ultimate benefit of the Northern Territory.

In closing I merely repeat that the leases for the pipeline easement between Palm Valley and Alice Springs will be on Aboriginal land. The leases to this land have been held up for some considerable time. I hope that all parties will reach agreement and this line will be constructed as quickly as possible. There have been charges and counter-charges about the matter. I believe that if the Federal Government sees fit to issue these grants in fee simple as quickly as possible, to allow an easement for the pipeline, tenders could be called, construction of the pipeline could be carried out in the latter part of the year and all would be well. The Aboriginal people would be satisfied, the Magellan company and the Palm Valley gas fields could be developed after so many years in limbo and Alice Springs would benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to take only a few minutes but I want to make some comments. Firstly, I am critical of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). This legislation is an example of his usual rush jobs in bringing in a Bill at the last minute. He has done that ever since he has occupied the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. I realise that in some cases there are problems. He has three co-Ministers working with him. He cannot do anything in Queensland until he gets permission from the Premier. He is not able to do anything in the Northern Territory until he gets permission from the Chief Minister. Until the recent retirement of Sir Charles Court he could not do anything in Western Australia either. I hope there will be some improvement there. Resolution of the problem at Hermannsburg has been held up for a long period. It should have been attended to many years ago. Part of the reason for some of our problems associated with these amendments was summed up very well by our shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Ryan, in a Press statement on 16 March. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The action of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, today in granting approval for mining in the Jabiluka uranium deposits puts unacceptable pressure on the Aboriginal traditional owners of the area to give the go-ahead for mining.
Mr Anthony's approval means that the Jabiluka project partners can begin negotiations for the sale of uranium from Jabiluka before the Aboriginal owners have agreed to allow mining to proceed.

While the Northern Land Council has initialled an agreement on Jabiluka, the agreement has still to be discussed by the Aboriginal owners of the area as specified under Section 48 of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act.
If the Aboriginal owners are to be given sufficient time for thorough consideration of the agreement this could be a lengthy process.

Mr Anthony's decision will put pressure on the Aboriginal owners to make a hasty decision in favour of the mine. It assumes that the Aboriginal owners can only make one decision, that is to give their approval, and therefore disregards the Aboriginals' power of veto under the Land Rights Act.

The last three amendments that came into this chamber, concerning the Northern Territory land rights legislation and the uranium mining legislation, were dealt with in a hurry. If the Minister had cats' eyes he would probably sneak into the chamber in the middle of the night and want to debate the legislation at daylight without anyone having access to the Bills. It is just not good enough. I suggest that the Minister take time to think the matter over. He has done the same sort of thing in other areas as well. I asked a question here recently regarding the operation of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program. I received a most strange reply, the crux of which says:

The delays have been caused by the need to develop a workable program which meets the requirement of both the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists as well as Governments and which includes appropriate Aboriginal involvement. Allocation of Government funds for the project during this financial year will depend on acceptable workable arrangements being developed.

We are almost at the end of the financial year. This is another area in which the Minister has fallen down badly. He has made no attempt to get this scheme operating effectively again. It worked effectively before, it saved the eyesight of many hundreds of Aborigines, particularly children. But this year nothing is happening because the Minister is too busy arguing with the three States in which this scheme will not be allowed to operate. The Northern Territory has a half-baked scheme which will cover half the patients. Western Australia also has a half-baked scheme which probably will not cover half the patients, and as far as I know the people conducting the program will not go to Queensland because Joh says that they cannot. In the meantime the health of the people suffers.

I hope that somewhere along the line the Minister is moved to another portfolio . Alternatively I hope that if he stays in his present one he will not make all the decisions himself but will consult with the Aborigines, which he is not doing now. A legal organisation-the equivalent of the Aboriginal legal services- in Townsville was wiped out of existence just before Christmas because the Minister had what he thought was a very important report. He would not let the Aborigines look at it but he acted under it. He decided that whatever dad said was right. The Minister has now become the big white father who lays down the law. I make those few remarks to point out that many people are unhappy about the way the Minister is failing to administer his portfolio, the way he is failing to consult with Aborigines at any level and the way he makes dictatorial decisions about when programs will be brought in. I suggest that he should develop a political backbone and not be dictated to by the people I have nominated and others such as the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators who have taken part in the debate. All except Senator Keeffe dealt with the Aboriginal Land rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 which is before us. I listened to what Senator Keeffe had to say. I reject most of it. I am pleased that he said it because the more he says it the more I know I am on the right track. In relation to what other honourable senators had to say, I am grateful for the support that has been given for this legislation which Senator Keeffe might note is the first piece of legislation I have brought in. Therefore he need not talk about my constant practice of bringing in legislation at the last moment. I thank honourable senators for the support they have given for the principles of the legislation and acknowledge the points they have raised, the particularities on which they have questions and on which they want some further elucidation in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I take a few of the points raised and suggest that the comments on clause 9-the one on which honourable senators have asked for specific information-might best be dealt with in the Committee stages rather than my going over it twice. Senator Kilgariff raised the question of the easement for the Palm Valley pipeline. Let me be quite clear about this matter. With the passage of this legislation the preparation and issue of the pieces of paper may still take some weeks, but the Aboriginal communities can go ahead now, negotiate and complete the agreements. Even under the best negotiating conditions that will take them several weeks. Therefore we will be ready without delay to finalise the arrangements which, as the honourable senator said, will bring into those Aboriginal communities the benefits they are seeking to obtain from the royalties which they will receive once the gas starts to flow. By passing this legislation the Senate will assist those communities in getting that economic benefit.

In relation to the advice which we may have received from communities, I indicated to Senator Ryan-by way of interjection-that we had not considered it proper to distribute the legislation until it was introduced into the Parliament . What we did was canvass the issues and get agreement in principle to the matters which were raised. The honourable senator is quite correct that at that stage we then passed out the legislation. I think it was introduced into the Parliament on Tuesday. It was in Darwin that night and handed to Aboriginal Land Council representatives, from whom we now have some further information. The Government is grateful for the support it has received from the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats for the legislation. I will discuss, during the Committee stages, the issues relating to clause 9. I hope I will be able to answer queries to everyone's satisfaction. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 7 (Recommendations for grant of Crown land, other than that described in Schedule 1).

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to comment on the application of the provisions of this clause to the Jabiluka uranium project. In particular, the Minister might answer, at this stage, the points I raised about the use of this piece of legislation to facilitate the Jabiluka project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jabiluka project area is contained largely within that piece of land which has been recommended for grant in the Alligator Rivers region. The purpose of clause 7 will be to allow me to grant any land in stages. That could apply to the Alligator Rivers region, as it could to any other region. The honourable senator raises the question about whether I need this clause to be passed to enable the Jabiluka project to go ahead. The short answer to that is no, it is not necessary for this clause to be passed. The Jabiluka area can be granted once the appropriate survey work is completed. The Jabiluka project could go ahead whether or not this amendment is passed. In fact, the purpose of this amendment is to put beyond doubt the capacity of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to make progressive grants. The purpose of that is to ensure that Aboriginals are not disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take a moment of the Committee's time to explain that within the Alligator Rivers area there are eight small parcels of land in the area recommended for grant by the Land Commissioner, each of which is held up at the moment because of concerns that we have over the Finniss River appeal which is before the High Court of Australia. The matters being appealed in the Finniss River case are matters which are relevant to these eight small pieces of land. It is my intention to proceed to grant land in the Alligator Rivers region as quickly as I am able, leaving those eight small pieces of land out until I have the result of the High Court judgment on the Finniss River. This matter is not even coming up for mention before the High Court before April. We will be lucky to have a result from the High Court before the end of this year. Who knows? The Court works to its own timetable.

Those eight pieces contain land which may be of great importance to traditional Aboriginal owners because they include areas which are controlled by Peko- Wallsend Ltd which may contain mineral wealth and which Aboriginals want to become Aboriginal land in due course so that negotiations could take place in the usual way for mining to proceed on them. If the Senate or the Parliament chose not to pass this amendment, the only losers could be the traditional Aboriginal people; the only winners could be the people who hold the pieces of land, perhaps Peko-Wallsend or some other company should it choose to mount challenges in the court and should it be successful. The passage of this amendment will put beyond doubt my capacity to make progressive grants. Coming back to the question asked by Senator Ryan: As soon as the survey work is complete I could grant the land necessary to enable the Jabiluka project to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) for his explanation. Indeed, on behalf of the Opposition, we welcome the steps that the Minister has taken to protect the right of Aboriginals to the eight small pieces of land which are currently affected by claims before the High Court of Australia. Returning to the grant of land to the traditional owners in the area involved in the Jabiluka project, the Minister has just stated that it is his intention to make those grants as soon as possible. Of course, the passage of this legislation will facilitate that. I ask the Minister: What steps will he be taking to monitor the application of the principal Act, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, insofar as it requires the Northern Land Council to consult with traditional owners and insofar as the traditional owners will have access to information which will help them decide whether or not to exercise their veto rights over mining? I raise this matter because the Minister will be aware that from time to time some traditional owners have complained that consultation by the Land Council with the traditional owners has not been adequate. When we are dealing with such a controversial matter as uranium mining I think all of Australia will be anxious to know that the Aboriginals' veto rights in this matter, insofar as they exist, are being properly investigated, that all due process of consultation is taking place and that all information that the traditional owners need to be able to decide whether or not to exercise that veto will be available to them. I seek general assurances from the Minister on this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — Under the Act I am required to satisfy myself that a number of things have happened. Before I give my approval for an agreement for mining to proceed or for any agreement which may be entered into by a Land Council, I am required to satisfy myself that the Land Council has sought and has received proper instructions from the traditional owners in the first instance before it starts negotiating. I am required to satisfy myself that the relevant Land Council has acted upon instructions that it has received and not in any other way. I am required to satisfy myself that any agreement which is reached is in accordance with the instructions which were issued. I am required also to satisfy myself that the agreement which has been reached by the Land Council on their behalf is understood and agreed to by the traditional owners.

SPEECH.PARA: My officers, as my agents, have been closely following the procedure and monitoring each one of those steps. The situation is that we now have an initialled agreement between the Land Council and the company. We are at the stage now where the Land Council is going back to the traditional owners to explain to them the agreement which has been reached to ensure that it has their agreement. As part of that monitoring process we are trying to ensure that the appropriate information is available to traditional owners to enable them to make the judgments which they are required to make. I will not give my approval unless those things are done. There are other things which I want to know too. I want to know that the agreement accords with certain principles. I think I have to approve the distribution of moneys which is proposed. I will want to make sure that that is adequate and appropriate before I approve it. It is our wish that the information which Senator Ryan believes is important for communities to have in their hands will be in their hands during this process.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 8 agreed to.
Clause 9 (Transfer of amounts from Trust Account to Consolidated Revenue Fund in certain circumstances)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated during my summing up that I would answer some questions that were raised during the second reading debate. This might be an appropriate time to do it. The issue raised by this clause concerns the repayment of moneys which have been lent by the Consolidated Revenue Fund to keep the land councils operating. The issue which comes up is that there are several areas from which the repayments can be made. During their contributions to the debate, honourable senators drew attention to the conflict that might exist between the land councils, as a source of the repayment, and the rest of the Aboriginal community , as a source of the repayment. I draw honourable senators attention to letters which I tabled which indicate a division of opinion within and among the Aboriginal community. In the letter from the Central Land Council dated 7 December which I received on 18 December the view of that Council on that matter was set out. I draw the attention of the Committee to a couple of paragraphs in the letter. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Central Land Council has accepted supplementary funding offered by your Department on the understanding that this supplementary funding would be repaid to consolidated revenue by the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. This is provided for by the Land Rights Act. It has never been the understanding or the scheme of the Act that the supplementary funding should be repaid from amounts due to the Land Councils under s. 64 (1) of the Act.

The view of the Central Land Council is that the money should be repaid from the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account and not from the land councils. On the other hand is the view expresed in the letter, which I tabled, from the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account which I received on 22 December. It stated:

We also understand that you have written to the Northern Land Council and Central Land Council enquiring whether they will agree to repay recent advances made to them by the Government, as and when their share of royalties exceed their administrative costs. The Committee-
That is the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account Advisory Committee-

feels that having the Land Councils repaying this money is the correct thing. The A.B.T.A. has already got to repay old loans made by the Government to the Councils and the Councils should be made to accept some responsibility for these later loans. With regard to the repaying of the old loans by the A.B.T.A., my Committee consider-

The letter continued on a technical matter. The letter is signed by Mr Leo Finlay, who is of course an Aboriginal and Chairman of the Advisory Committee. Incidentally, he is also the Deputy Chairman of the Northern Land Council. I put it to honourable senators and the Committee that here we have two views. In the end there is no view that will satisfy all Aboriginal interests. However, it may be possible to resolve the matter by acknowledging that all we are talking about is the repayment from that part of money allocated to the land councils which is in excess of their needs for administrative purposes. If I do not have this amendment all I will be able to do is to have the money go back in one lot. No one questions the fact that the money has to be repaid. The issue now is whether I can repay it in bits or in one hit. Having looked at the two letters and thought the matter through, my proposition is that it is money that was advanced to the land councils for their administrative purposes and it is appropriate that we look, when the income is sufficient, to repaying it from that amount of money in excess of the administrative needs of the land councils.

I think Senator Ryan, or Senator Macklin, referred to section 35 of the principal Act, which sets out the way in which these moneys are to be distributed. Excess money is money to be distributed by the land councils to communities within their land council area. It seems to me that if we go the way the Central Land Council wants we will end up with the ABTA being very poor for a long time and the land councils very wealthy. As I see it, in terms of equity and judging by rule of thumb, it is probably appropriate to make the repayments from excess moneys available to the land councils once their administrative needs have been met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) for his explanation. There is one other aspect of the Central Land Council's submission that I seek his comment on. That matter concerns the retrospectivity of the provision. I understand that clause 9 provides that the repayment in the form that the legislation sets out will be back dated to 1978. The Central Land Council is concerned about the retrospective aspects of clause 9. I ask the Minister to explain and to justify the decision to make that matter retrospective to 1978.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again refer Senator Ryan to the letter written by the Central Land Council. I repeat the sentence which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Central Land Council has accepted supplementary funding offered by your Department on the understanding that this supplementary funding would be repaid to consolidated revenue-

The amount to be repaid has accumulated over several years. The amount was made available to the land councils because it was considered appropriate that the land councils should have enough funding to enable them to operate effectively, even though at that time the royalty income was negligible. I think this is merely to allow the debt to be cleared. It is a finite debt; we know what it is. It is $1.6m at present. In terms of the kinds of amounts of money that will be coming in, it will be no real hardship to repay it, particularly if we do it in segments year by year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Senator Peter Baume) for his explanations so far. The Australian Democrats will not press their objections. I would like to place on record that after listening to the Minister's reply and to the various representations that have been made I think the point that the Central Land Council made is a telling one. It is that ultimately the wealth of the Aboriginal people comes from their lands and therefore the land council is the organisation that we should seek to bolster in the long term. However, we will not press our objection basically because of the other problems that have arisen with the legislation. We hope that in the administration and recovery of costs the Minister will not in any way remove administrative moneys from the land councils in such a way as to make them less able to undertake their work, which is seeking to further land claims as expeditiously and as effectively as possible.

Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982CANNED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982

This Bill proposes to amend and repeal existing legislation to allow for the termination of the operations of the Australian Canned Fruits Sales Promotion Committee and for the residual assets and liabilities of the Committee to vest with the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation.

The Sales Promotion Committee was established in 1959 with the single function of promoting the sale of Australian canned deciduous fruit. As a matter of policy, the Committee has always restricted its promotional activities to the domestic market. The Committee's activities are funded from the proceeds of a charge on grower deliveries of fruit to canners collected under the Canning- Fruit Charge Act 1959.

Following the announcement of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions on 31 April 1981, the Minister for Primary Industry canvassed with grower and canner interests the desirability of rationalising the operations of the Committee within the existing broad marketing and general functions of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. This has been accepted, and the domestic promotion programs of the Committee were taken over by the Corporation as from 1 January 1982.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
CANNED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1982
This Bill proposes increases to the rates of levy imposed on canned deciduous fruit production to finance the administrative operations of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation.

As from 1 January 1982 the operative rate of levy increases from the equivalent of 11 cents per basic carton (24 x 825 gram cans) to 27 cents per basic carton. Provision is also being made for future alteration of levy rates by regulation up to a maximum of 30 cents per basic carton. The new maximum and operative rates for various container sizes are set out in the Schedules to this Bill.

The increased levy rates have been recommended by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation following its decision in November 1981 to reduce canned fruit production in the 1982 season to approximately one half the level achieved last year. This decision was made necessary following the drastic downturn in export market outlets last year and the build up of unsold stocks to near record high levels.

The Corporation's marketing plans for 1982 have been developed in close consultation with grower and canner interests and the reduction in production is seen by the bulk of the industry as the best response to the current oversupply problem. Significant marketing and promotional problems will continue to face the industry this year and the increased levy rates proposed by this Bill are essential if the Corporation is to have the resources necessary to deal effectively with these problems.

The Government is also giving urgent attention to the problems facing the industry. It agreed late last year to an urgent IAC reference. The Commission is scheduled to report on the industry's short term assistance needs by 31 March.
The Minister for Primary Industry has assured industry interests that the IAC report will be accorded urgent consideration by the Government.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCTS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1982DAIRY PRODUCTS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1982

Leave granted.

DAIRY PRODUCTS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1982

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce, as from 1 July 1982, charges to recoup a proportion of the cost borne by the Commonwealth for inspecting dairy products for export. This is part of the Government's programme to recover costs of providing export inspection for certain agricultural and fishery products.
Export inspection is designed to ensure that products meet minimum standards of quality, hygiene and presentation when exported.

The Government introduced charges for inspecting meat, grain and wool in 1979, and fish and dried fruits in 1981. These charges are aimed at recovering approximately 50 per cent of the inspection costs of the Commonwealth. The Government proposes that fees aimed at a similar level of recovery should be imposed for similar services provided by the Department of Primary Industry for other products.

Turning to specifics in this Bill, Honourable Senators will see that it provides for the recovery of dairy product export inspection costs to be achieved through charges on dairy products inspected for export.
The Bill provides that the person who furnishes an Export Notice for inspection purposes is liable to pay the charge. Exemptions may be provided in the regulations.

A maximum rate of charge of $5.00 per tonne is specified. The actual rates of charge will be specified in regulations. It is proposed that the following rates for 1982-83 be recommended to the Governor-General for promulgation by regulation
Butter packed in bulk or pat form-$2.50 per tonne
Butter packed in other forms and butter fat products-$1.00 per tonne
Cheese packed in bulk-$2.50 per tonne
Cheese packed in other forms-$1.00 per tonne
Concentrated, condensed and dried milk-$0.50 per tonne
Milk and other milk products-$1.00 per tonne
On current estimates of export production for 1982-83, charges at these rates will yield approximately $307,000 in a full year.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
DAIRY PRODUCTS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1982
This Bill is related to the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 just introduced. Its purpose is to provide for the collection of charges proposed in that Bill.

It follows provisions for the collection of levies in other export inspection charge legislation. Specifically, provision is made for persons to pay charges due to the Commonwealth for the inspection of dairy products for which a certified Export Notice has been served.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to enact the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals which were tabled in the other place on 18 August 1981.
The changes to the coal export duty, as proposed by this Bill, were foreshadowed by my colleague the Treasurer in the Budget speech on that day.
These changes impose, with effect from 8 p.m. on 18 August 1981, an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal previously exempt from export duty.

The Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act imposes a duty on exports of coking coal, at rates of either $3.50 per tonne or $1 per tonne depending on the quality of the coal and certain other features of the mining operation. Lower valued coals, principally steaming coal, had been exempted from this duty.

Because of changes in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal the Government decided that there was no longer any reason to differentiate between coking coal and steaming coal in the application of the export duty.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1982TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1982TOBACCO CHARGE (No. 3) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Messner:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In January of this year several people discovered that at least one load of hay had been transported from Queensland in breach of regulations relating to the control of cattle tick and delivered to the Bendemeer property of the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair. In the first parliamentary week of this year-that was from 16 to 18 February-jibes in the House of Representatives about tick-tock and tickey hay apparently alerted the Minister. In a speech to an obscure New South Wales National Country Party branch on Saturday, 20 February, he attempted to defuse the issue by trivialising it and by pretending that he was an innocent bystander-a victim of circumstance yet again. On 23 February I spoke in the Senate pointing out that he was not an innocent bystander or a victim of circumstance and that he was fully in control of the farm operations, according to a statement he had given to the Land newspaper which was published in January this year. My speech was reported by the Tamworth newspaper, the Northern Daily Leader, on 24 February under the heading 'MP Passed Blame for Breach'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Sinclair once used the forum of Parliament to reply to me, to Senate committees or to anyone else who was exposing his assorted villainies. Sometimes he got his party leader and party ministerial colleague, Mr Nixon, to assist him in doing that-those well-known financial wizards of the National Country Party, Messrs Anthony and Nixon. The defences lately have not been terribly successful. Perhaps that explains why he chose as the forum for reply an article that was published in the Northern Daily Leader on March 1. Another reason could be that if he makes assertions in Parliament which are too easily or too unequivocally shown to be incorrect even he could be in trouble. Perhaps the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) would be in even more trouble if he refused to take action pursuant to that. The Minister asserted in what I think is a weekly column of his in the Northern Daily Leader as follows:

As explained in a speech to the Country Party at Kingstown at the weekend, a small quantity of hay was innocently acquired by my farm manager from a local carrier at the end of the drought last year to feed calving cows.
Later, he said:
Senator Walsh, however, claims I owned the hay when it crossed the border, which I did not . . .

Those points are crucial. Mr Sinclair's version of this incident is that the truck driver was acting as the principal in the transaction, effectively hawking hay from farm to farm, some of which was purchased by Mr Sinclair's manager. What actually happened, and what was disclosed by Mr Sinclair's manager in a statement to the relevant New South Wales authorities, is that the manager, in replying to a newspaper advertisement, rang a fodder merchant in Gatton, Queensland. He was quoted a price for the hay, delivered. He formed the opinion that the delivery charge was too high and hired a local Tamworth carrier to transport it. I add that the carrier was not paid for six months. Perhaps he should count himself lucky. The Walshes still have not been fully repaid the money the Sinclairs pinched from them up to 10 years ago. It was later discovered by the authorities that the hay had not been fumigated or sprayed and Mr Sinclair's farm was put in quarantine which lasted, I understand, for about three months. The Minister has also endeavoured to leave the impression that his manager and not he is responsible for what happens on his farm-a version which conflicts directly with a statement by Mr Sinclair quoted in the Land newspaper of 14 January. He said:

But I still like to be involved in all the major stock decisions. I'm there at the weekend and I try to have a look at the stock. I sign cheques and give orders and ask why last week's orders weren't carried out. Occasionally I participate in calf-marking or hay-making or something like that, . . .

On his own prior statement he cannot plead ignorance or innocence of this incident on the grounds that the manager, not he, is responsible for everything that happens on the farm. Another matter, which arises from a question asked last week, has the appearance of yet another attempt to cover up activities of National Country Party Ministers-on this occasion apparently, with at least the passive assistance of a couple of senior Liberal Ministers. On 9 March I asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle whether the appointment of Mr Al Wallace, the former head of the Dairying Division of the Department of Primary Industry to a supernumerary position called 'special adviser' within that Department complied with the Public Service guidelines and also with the directive on Government expenditure circulated by her Department last month. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle replied:

I think Senator Walsh's question would primarily fall within the area of the Public Service Board or the Department of Primary Industry. I will seek information from those departments with regard to the appointment that he has outlined, about the requirements of the appointment and the other matters to which he has referred.

I dispute on factual grounds the Minister's implied assertion that it really did not have anything to do with her Department but was a matter for other departments, because her Department issued a directive last month about Government expenditure and about the deferring of all expenditure that could possibly be deferred into the next financial year. But I leave that aside. The more important fact is that nine days later there still has been no reply. Yesterday in the Senate I reminded the Government of the fact that there had been no reply. Obviously, that question could have been answered within 24 hours had there been any will on the part of the Government to do so. One could speculate about the reason for Mr Wallace's new appointment, one of the beneficial-to the Government-consequences of which will be that he will no longer appear before Senate Estimates committees as the head of the Dairying Division of the Department of Primary Industry. The officially stated reason for his appointment as a special adviser is that he is to advise upon the reorganisation of the Department of Primary Industry consequent on the exposure in this Senate and in other places of very serious deficiencies, to say the least, within that Department. Nobody who saw Mr Wallace perform before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations would doubt his loyalty to his Ministers, past and present. They would, however, doubt his competence to reorganise anything or to give valid advice on how to reorganise anything. The Committee, in its report, said:

Regrettably Mr Wallace's evidence was so guarded and qualified and his manner so evasive that far from providing unqualified support for Mr Sinclair's version of the events, Mr Wallace at best only offered lukewarm and tentative confirmation.

At one stage Mr Wallace's performance was so inept that the Chairman felt obliged to note explicitly for the record that the laughter around the room-from assembled journalists, senators and interested spectators-was, as he put it, at and not with Mr Wallace.

The second matter about which I asked a question last week was the appointment of a barrister to represent Mr Nixon before the royal commission into the meat export substitution scandal. Since I asked the question, I have had firm corroboration of the fact that a barrister has been appointed. In my question last week I asked whether it was a fact that a barrister had been appointed. We now know-no thanks to this Government-that that is so. I also asked who authorised this appointment, how much it would cost and who would pay.

Those are questions which could probably have been answered within half an hour had there been any will on the part of this Government to answer them. A telephone call to Mr Nixon's office would have provided the answers. I do not know whether Senator Carrick made any attempt to get an answer. I suspect he would have done so. I have usually found that when Senator Sir John Carrick is asked to provide information of a straight factual nature such as those questions sought he has attended to his duties quite diligently. I expect that Senator Sir John Carrick or someone on his staff would have contacted Mr Nixon or Mr Nixon's office seeking answers to those questions. The answers have not come through. The only conclusion which is compatible with those facts is that Mr Nixon does not want the answer to be made public. He is deferring it for as long as possible, in keeping with a well-established National Country Party tradition of deferring by any means all potentially unpleasant decisions and matters in the hope that they will go away.

The Government was reminded yesterday that these questions had been asked and had not been answered. I appeal to Senator Sir John Carrick-if he cannot do it today, he should do so at the very latest, at the conclusion of Question Time next Tuesday-to tell the Senate whether he has put these questions to the Minister and whether he has received any reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this first reading debate to raise two matters relating to East Timor. One is family reunification, which I have mentioned in this place on a number of occasions, as have many honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. The other is what I have called the need for the door to be opened; in other words, the availability of access to East Timor by people from outside the province. I am prompted to make these comments by two matters that have been reported in the newspapers. The first is the visit of the Honourable E. G. Whitlam, Q.C. and Mr Peter Hastings of the Sydney Morning Herald to East Timor. This was reported in the Canberra Times on 12 March. The second is the visit to Indonesia of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, Mr Paul Everingham, as reported in the Northern Territory News of 6 March, the previous week.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to comment on the situation in East Timor at present or even, for that matter, to discuss reports which have been made by Peter Hastings and which have appeared in a number of newspapers. The reason I do not want to do this is that Hastings was invited to visit Indonesia and then East Timor by the Indonesian Government. When someone is invited, as in this case, I believe that anything he says when he returns must become suspect. I am supported in this by an editorial in the Canberra Times which, after commenting that other journalists had not been allowed to visit East Timor-I will have more to say about this later-stated:

Mr Hastings would have welcomed, of course, a general invitation to foreign media to send to East Timor correspondents selected by themselves. Then his own position would not have been so lonely and exposed. Journalists believe in competition for the truth and they believe that their own reports should be tested by the reports of their competitors, if the people they serve are to be well informed and also convinced.

Also, Mr Hastings was not served well by the Indonesian Government in being closely associated during his visit with Mr Whitlam, another man of integrity but also the Prime Minister responsible for Australia's controversial foreign policy during the planning period for Indonesia's invasion of East Timor in December, 1975. Again, the purpose of the Indonesian Government's special invitation to Mr Hastings and Mr Whitlam becomes apparent when it is realised that the Minister for Information, General Ali Murtopo, is the man who planned the political preliminaries to the invasion and that the head of BAKIN (the Indonesian security intelligence body), General Murdhani, was the commander of the invasion forces. It has to be asked why such men would want Mr Hastings and Mr Whitlam to visit East Timor and not, apparently, other foreign observers? The question is unfair to both Mr Hastings and Mr Whitlam, but it is one to which Indonesian policy has now subjected them.

In no way do I cast any aspersions on Mr Whitlam, our former leader, or on Mr Hastings, who is not known to me but whose integrity I have no reason to question. I am not saying that the account is biased but simply that there is insufficient evidence to enable us to make any sort of comment on the situation in East Timor. If we wanted to speak about it we would need a balance by looking at reports from other people or making observations ourselves. I will discuss this matter later.
I turn to the matter of family reunification which I have raised previously in the chamber. The Northern Territory News article to which I referred earlier stated:
The Red Cross team now in East Timor was doing a survey which might result in an accurate list of people who had families in Australia, the Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, said yesterday . . .
The President-
That is, the President of Indonesia-
had said that people would progressively be allowed to leave Indonesia to rejoin their families in Australia.

The Chief Minister said that once the Red Cross team had prepared its list of people, the Australian Embassy would be consulting it to make arrangements 'for Timorese people to come progressively to Australia as all their formalities such as passports, exit visas and so on are cleared up'.
It is rather interesting that this is the same Mr Everingham who was not very happy with the Indonesian Government in 1976. A newspaper article which referred to Mr Everingham's visit stated:

Back in 1976 Mr Paul Everingham, then Deputy Leader of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, castigated the Indonesians over the 'continued slaughter of innocent men, women and children in East Timor'.

One of the lessons to be learnt from Timor, he told the Assembly, 'is that the Indonesian Government, although it may be bungling and inefficient, is nevertheless quite cold-blooded and ruthless. It will be friendly to us only as long as we continue to appease it or do not get in its way'.

'I rather more admire,' he continued, 'the diplomats from the Soviet Bloc than our own diplomats because at least they have the guts, or if they don't have the guts, they have the instructions, to stand up and say what they want.'

That statement is rather interesting when we recall that Mr Everingham is the Leader of the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory, the Chief Minister of the Legislative Assembly at the present time and one who certainly is no friend of Soviet Russia. Mind you, he has had a change in attitude. I will come back to this later. The comments made in the statement by Mr Everingham about family reunification seem most encouraging. But let us take the matter a little further. Let us look at the record. On 30 March 1977 the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr MacKellar, made a statement in the other place in which, in part, he said.

I wish to inform the House that agreement has been reached with the Indonesian Government concerning arrangements for the reunion of East Timorese in Australia and their close relatives from Timor . . . The Australian Government has very much in mind the distress occasioned by the separation of families and arrangements are proceeding for the visit to East Timor to take place as early as circumstances permit . . . It is necessary to set a closing date for receipt of nominations so that the operation can proceed as quickly as possible. Nominations received by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs up to close of business on 22 April 1977 will be considered in this operation.

The full statement was rather lengthy. It was reacted to by the shadow spokesman at the time, Mr Innes, who noted amongst other things that the Minister had used what Mr Innes called unusual definitions. He said that throughout the statement the Minister had used the word 'refugee' to describe people from East Timor. He did not use the word 'evacuee', although that word was used later on. He did not use the phrase 'asylum seekers' which Senator Durack used the other day in this place. This does not seem very important until we see later that refugee status is important in terms of coming to Australia and getting assistance. I do not want to pre-empt what I will say later, but let me just comment that one of the problems that we faced in the Northern Territory was to get the Minister to accept the fact that the people from East Timor are refugees within the term of a statement from the United Nations. If we regard them as ordinary immigrants it is more difficult to get them out; it is more difficult to meet the requirements that have been changed since 1977. I do not want to get in front of what I have to say in the other context. The saga continues on 3 June when the former Senator Justin O'Byrne asked a question. He asked:
Is it correct that the Government does not consider the East Timorese people in Australia to be refugees but evacuees.
Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, answering that part of the question, replied:

For many years victims of many different circumstances have been called refugees. These have included displaced and stateless persons, those seeking political asylum, defectors, members of oppressed minorities and victims of natural disasters.

It is rather interesting that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle later on defends the use of the term 'evacuees' as one of the reasons why the people from East Timor-those that we would call refugees-were not being brought to Australia. We jump now to March 1978, 12 months later, when Senator Button and Senator Missen, after attending a meeting in Victoria, both came into the chamber and in the adjournment debate raised the problems of the people in East Timor. Senator Button, in an excellent speech, reported that nothing had happened in the previous 12 months. During his comments he quoted a report of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. Speaking of East Timor specifically, the ACFOA had this to say:

ACFOA is concerned that the Minister appears to be reneging on his former statements regarding the acceptance of refugees from East Timor. It is particularly concerned about the change in criteria which will not allow many people to come from East Timor to be reunited with their families.

ACFOA believes that the continual lack of action regarding the reuniting of families from East Timor, separated since the latter part of 1975, is causing emotional hardship and possible long term psychological damage both to those who are already here and those separated from them.

ACFOA believes that the past ambiguities of Australian policy towards East Timor have resulted in confusion and the raising of false hopes amongst East Timorese people. We should therefore regard all East Timorese wishing to come here as refugees and treat them as such.

Senator Missen, when he spoke, again drew attention to the lack of activity over the previous 12 months and mentioned the reply given by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle on refugees. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle had this to say:

The arrangements for reuniting East Timorese now in Australia with their relatives either in Australia or in East Timor follow from an agreement between the President of Indonesia and the Prime Minister of Australia that officials of their two countries would meet to resolve the problems of the East Timorese ' refugees' who had come to Australia without their parents.
The Indonesian authorities have given their agreement in principle to a visit by Australian officials to East Timor to interview migrant applications sponsored-
Senator Missen went on to say in his remarks:
That still awaits. The situation is that we do not have a team. We have not reached a situation where any of our specialists can go there and see the position.

He went on to be very critical of his own Government and its treatment of the people of East Timor and the slow movement of people to Australia for the reunification of families. In defining families he again referred to the report by the ACFOA where families were defined in this way:

'families' should be widely interpreted in the terms of the culture and background of the refugees concerned rather than according to the normal criteria of Australian immigration procedures-this would involve the acceptance, appropriate to each particular ethnic group, of degrees of what we might describe as 'extended families'.

Of course, that is a point which has been made in this place many times by many honourable senators. Certainly I have raised it on a number of occasions when I have spoken particularly about the people from China and the ethnic Chinese from Timor. Senator Missen went on to talk about the problems of individual case histories. He called for a team to visit East Timor, something which we have done over the years as well. It is good to see that both sides of the chamber see the problems in East Timor. Senator Missen continued:

Our responsibility as I see it is, firstly, urgent and effective pressure from Australia for the acceptance by Indonesia of an Australian immigration team in Timor and the achievement of early reunion of families from there; secondly, for a more compassionate re-examination of the Portugal refugee program and the bringing from Portugal of many more of the people who are there at the moment and who want to come to Australia.
He noted in his address that the Indonesian Government said that visits would be arranged after the election. I quote again from Senator Missen's speech. He said :

However, the Indonesian Government has advised that arrangements for a visit to East Timor by a Department of Immigration team will be discussed after the elections this month. It is therefore anticipated that a visit will take place in the near future.

Of course, we are talking of the elections not of 1981 or 1982 but of 1978. Senator Missen was speaking in 1978 about the elections which would be held then . It is interesting to see that the comments made in that original article that I read, noting Paul Everingham's visit to Timor, were related to problems associated with the election and pointed out that we would be able to do these things after the election, not in 1977 or 1978 but in 1982.
We jump now to 1980 when a question was asked in this place referring to an article in the National Times regarding Australia-East Timor family reunion. The question was:

Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, on the claim that Indonesia appears to have slammed the door on further departures from East Timor of people included in the Australia-East Timor reunion scheme? Is it correct that to date only half of the 600 refugees approved by the Indonesian Government to join family members in Australia under the scheme have in fact been granted permission by the Indonesian authorities to do so?

The Minister responded by saying that the Government was very unhappy at the slow progress of movement of people from East Timor for family reunification in Australia. It put the blame squarely back on the Indonesian Government by saying that Indonesian immigration procedures were slowing things up.

What is the present situation, in March 1982? The answer is that people are still waiting. Of the original 2,500 in Timor who said that they wanted to join their families in Australia-honourable senators will recall that that number was cut by the Indonesians from 2,500 back to 600-only 300 have arrived in Australia . People are still in Portugal and in other countries. I realise that they are not the responsibility of Indonesia. We should simply be concerned about the 2, 500 people who want to come to Australia. Honourable senators will recall that that number was cut to 600.
