They are still not regarded by the Australian Government as refugees; they are still regarded as either evacuees, ordinary migrants or asylum seekers, as Senator Durack has said, although I must admit that I do not know the definition of an 'asylum seeker'. Perhaps an asylum seeker is someone from the Soviet Union in a red bikini who jumps off a boat. Perhaps that is different from a refugee or an evacuee or someone wanting to come to Australia.

We still have problems with passports. The Indonesians are making much of this. Honourable senators will recall that when East Timor was a province of Portugal the people of East Timor had the choice of a Portuguese passport or, if they happened to be of Chinese ethnic origin, a Taiwanese passport. Obviously they would select the passport which suited the particular movement they wanted to take. At present Indonesia is demanding that people from East Timor take out Indonesian passports because it claims-we have accepted the de facto recognition and de jure recognition to follow some time later, despite the feelings of the people of Australia-that East Timor is now part of Indonesia.

I refer back to Hastings's article. Hastings comments very favourably on the education of the East Timorese people, who are now attending good Indonesian schools, learning from good Indonesian text books in the Indonesian language. This is seen as a great improvement for the people of East Timor. Yet we have to be very careful about Mr Hastings because he said that the Fretilin people, those few who were still up in the hills, were just a nuisance.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his disgusting remarks about the bishop?

—One could go on about those sorts of remarks. The point I am making is that people in other parts of the world-but not in East Timor-are called freedom fighters, patriots. The people in East Timor, who are fighting for their own country were pests to the Indonesian Government and, of course, would be wiped out. I do not have to go through the comments that have been made in this place by myself and others about the action that was taken by the Indonesians either to starve out the Fretilin people or to 'encourage' them to come out of the hills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Indonesian authorities are demanding that people from East Timor should have Indonesian passports. Of course, once one gets an Indonesian passport one cannot be seen as a refugee. Quite clearly, if one is carrying an Indonesian passport and one lives in East Timor one is very happy with the situation in Indonesia and would not want to leave. We know that bribes are still being required of those people who insist on trying to come from East Timor to Australia, that bribes are required to move from East Timor to Jakarta and that bribes are required to move from Jakarta to Australia. As I have said in this place before, there was only one occasion when Australian officials were involved in this. When I drew this to the attention of the responsible Minister, to his great credit, he made sure that no Australian officials-the people involved were locally recruited-were involved in the bribery. Bribery is not indulged in by the Australians.

Questions must be asked. Is Indonesia dinkum about what it is doing? Is it really interested in the well-being of those people in East Timor? We hear a lot from Mr Hastings about the improvement of the roads, about the fact that there is more food than there was a few months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not mean that there is enough, though.

—That is what we are not sure about. I do not want to comment too much because, as I said earlier in my speech, we do not have the information . We have had only one report from a man who was invited by the Government to go there. We have to be a little careful. I will come to the suggestion that we be allowed to see for ourselves. Then we will be able to answer perhaps, more clearly, the honourable senator's question. I come back to the Australian situation. Are we doing enough or is our concern for trade and oil overriding our obligations to these people who are our former allies? I think I will leave that aspect and move on to the need for Indonesia to open the door to Australia. The editorial in the Canberra Times of 13 March opens in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: ''There is no doubt that Indonesia now has a story to tell. It would be dreadful, counter-productive waste of all its efforts and those of others, if it does not begin to allow more foreign journalists and observers in to see for themselves,'' . . .

Whilst that is part of the Canberra Times editorial it is actually a quotation from something which Mr Peter Hastings, a foreign editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, had written. The Canberra Times used this quotation from Hastings to open up what it had to say. I will leave and come back to that quotation in a moment. The Canberra Times agreed with what Mr Hastings had saw in its introduction to editorial. The Canberra Times noted that Australian journalists had been excluded from Indonesia. It noted that the Australian Broadcasting Commission was not allowed to have a resident correspondent in East Timor. It noted that foreign journalists were not allowed in. The Canberra Times stated:

As The Times, London, wrote in an editorial on February 24, 'Indonesia has obviously not won over the hearts and minds of the East Timorese, and her very unwillingness to allow independent observers access to the territory corroborates that'.
The Canberra Times makes the editorial comment:
If The Times is mistaken and the East Timorese have been won over, then why has its correspondent in Singapore, Mr Watts, been refused permission to go there?

I am trying to make the point that Mr Hastings was invited. He was quoted in the article. The Canberra Times went on to say that other Australian journalists are not allowed in, no other foreign journalists are allowed in and the ABC has not been allowed to have a correspondent there since the famous occasion when one ABC man was drummed out of Indonesia.

I refer to a personal situation. I have been trying to get to East Timor for years. I make two or three requests a year; they have all been rejected for various reasons. I will not go into those reasons now but they are fairly wide ranging-from the fact that the East Timorese were unsettled and did not want me in East Timor to the situation that it is very difficult to live there at present. I make the point strongly-I think this is the point that Senator Coleman was coming to earlier on-that politicians need to go to East Timor to see for themselves what is going on. Mr Whitlam, when he came back from East Timor, told me that he went anywhere he wanted to go. He went with a Red Cross team. He had no officials with him. He did not have an Army interpreter; he had an interpreter who was part of the Red Cross team. He was allowed to go to any spot that he wanted to go to. This is good. I commend this. It is tremendous if a person-someone of Mr Whitlam's standing-can go to East Timor and be allowed to see anything that he wants to see.

Why is the situation not the same for the rest of us who are interested, who have been interested over the years, who have been involved over the years and who, perhaps, have been a little more critical than Mr Whitlam has been of Indonesia and her relationship with East Timor but who, nevertheless, have had an involved interest? The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has indicated that it wants to go to East Timor. I hope that it can go. I hope that the discussions which Senator Scott has had with the Indonesian Ambassador will mean that the Committee will go there, will be given the same freedom as Mr Whitlam was given and will be able to see whatever its members want to see in East Timor. I see this only as a first step. I see this as a step towards other people, other senators and members of the House of Representatives , if they are interested, being allowed to go to see for themselves what is happening in East Timor at present.

If, as Mr Whitlam indicates, things are better, I would be pleased to see for myself. I have a great warmth of feeling for the East Timorese people. I hope that their conditions have improved; certainly, from the reports given to me a couple of years ago, they could not have gotten any worse. I do not make that as a facetious comment. I hope that things have improved, that roads are being built, that crops are being developed, that people are being allowed to return to their own areas and live in them and are not being closeted together in the so-called protective villages-the same concept as was used with such devastating effect in Zimbabwe and as I understand it is being used in South Africa at present. I hope that we will be able to go and see whether the East Timorese people have accepted the yoke of the Indonesians, have agreed to become Indonesians, and whether there is a general feeling that they are now happy with their lot and are ready to open their doors to those of us from Australia who have such happy memories of East Timor and who would like to go back to re- establish that contact which we had years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks concerning society's response to the use of cannabis within our community. I take this course in the belief that all senators and all those who are in a position of having to make decisions concerning society's response to the circulation of this drug within the community have a common aim; that is, that we should create a society where the drug-ridden aspects, the inebriated aspects, of our society which have been so eloquently commented on by Senate committee reports fade away and are not perceived as inevitable features of our society in Australia and where recourse to drugs does not occur as a matter of addiction but rather as a matter of choice between properly understood health hazards and the natural desire of people to take some substance which is a relaxant or part of a recreational or social situation. In other words, can Australia move away from being the drug-ridden society it is claimed to be because of our abuse of alcohol, tobacco, analgesics, cannabis and other drugs--
—An intoxicated society.

—Indeed, an intoxicated society, which is the sub-title of a report of one of our Senate committees. Can Australia move to a situation in which drugs are taken, if they are taken at all, with the full knowledge of the health hazards involved but as part of a general relaxation, a social, recreational pastime which is a feature of human cultures and societies? It is one thing to concentrate on the known health hazards associated with marihuana use, if I can use a colloquial term; it is another thing to alert us, as did Senator Walters in her contribution last week, to the emerging knowledge which might lead to more caution in the use of this drug and in society's reaction to its use than has hitherto been the case. There are reports emerging that certainly suggest that we need to undertake further study of the long term effects on individuals of the use of cannabis.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this approach is totally unbalanced if no consideration is given to the curious fact that society is latching on to the mere use of a drug and declaring it criminal. It is not saying, as it does with most criminal offences, that there is a victim quite apart from the offender-somebody who is the victim of the offender's actions, as in the case of murder, theft or whatever. It is not even saying, as in some of the old laws relating to those who are alcohol dependent in our society, that the person is drunk and disorderly or drunk and incapable of taking care of himself. There is nothing of that nature. It is merely latching on to the fact that the person uses this particular drug. That should alert us to the fact that society is doing here something quite out of the ordinary which needs defending.

For that reason I am pleased that we have now brought into the debate a discussion paper entitled 'Social Policies on Drugs' prepared by a national workshop convened by the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence . The document which that workshop put together is, as is said in the foreword, not a blueprint for social reform but a paper which demands serious study of all the issues involving the framing of our social policies. In the section dealing with cannabis use it says:

The participants were unanimously of the view that it is most important that the proposals should be introduced only after widespread community debate, including debate in the several parliaments of Australia.

As part of the contribution to that debate in the several parliaments of Australia I wish to offer my views which, as it happens, largely coincide with the views of the participants who put together that discussion paper. Those participants are worthy of our respect, if not of our automatic concurrence. They include such people as Mr Justice Michael Kirby, Chairman of the Law Reform Commission of Australia, Professor Narelle Lickiss, Head of the Department of Community Medicine at the University of Tasmania, and Mr John Toohey of the Drug and Alcohol Office of the Labor Council of New South Wales. Those people cannot be dismissed, as I have so often been dismissed in past years, as trendy radicals. They are people who deserve and command the respect not only of those who know their work within their own fields but also of the general community.

I have made the point that we are dealing here with a peculiar sort of law. Those who take Senator Walters's point of view invariably fail to mount a defence of the impact of the present law on those individuals who fall foul of it and on society as a whole. Those who argue for the status quo have to mount an argument, I believe, for the continuance of the total prohibition model, the model which was adopted by the United States in relation to trying to prevent alcohol abuse in the 1920s and 1930s with all the disastrous results which flowed from it. That is the model that has been adopted in Australia to deal with the problem of cannabis abuse.

Let me list two or three of what I believe to be the quite disastrous social impacts which the present law has. Firstly, it means that we have really devised a system whereby, upon conviction, the lives of many Australians are blighted. Their careers can be put in jeopardy and their jobs taken away from them. Years of training can be undone. These things happen to Australians who potentially offer so much to the community-law abiding, decent, ordinary Australians who, because they are among the very few who are detected, prosecuted and convicted as a result of using this drug, have attached to them a stigma of conviction which they must carry through the rest of their lives in a way which affects very adversely their opportunities to contribute by the use of their skills in a profession or job of their choice and their opportunities to travel to certain countries because then they have to apply to a passport. So the stigma of conviction attaches to a few. I emphasise 'a few', and I will return to that in a moment.

A second effect of the present law is that many hundreds of thousands of Australians find themselves in a semi-criminal subculture in which they must deal in order to obtain this drug. In other words, many Australians find themselves in a shadowy world in which I believe they are now vulnerable to those who wish to lead them on to the use of harder drugs. Ultimately the distribution of marihuana in the main is controlled by criminal syndicates, as we know. So our young people in particular are put into a social situation in which they are vulnerable to the progression to harder drugs. There is no pharmacologically-proven progression. If one starts with marihuana one will not invariably end up taking heroin. But it is almost always true that those who are heroin addicts began on marihuana. In the same way, those who start with a beer do not end up as alcoholics but those who are alcoholics probably started with beer. The fact is that these people find themselves in a situation in which they are likely to be vulnerable to the pressures to go on to harder drugs. Let it be understood, as I am sure it is by many here, that when there is a drought in the availability of marihuana, invariably the harder drugs are offered as a substitute by those who have a profit motive in leading young people into the use of harder drugs. Of course, society is ensuring that there is a ready flow of cash to the criminal syndicates for them to finance their more nefarious and socially destructive activities. It is a peculiar situation in which a legal system creates such problems.

Thirdly, there is the effect on our law enforcement officers-the police officers, the Customs officers and the Narcotics Bureau personnel, the people on the street and in the cars trying to enforce these laws, and the top administrators. The pressure on them exhibits itself, as the report says, in simple stress in that they are involved in an area of law enforcement which is not widely understood or supported by the community. This adds to the stress of an already difficult job. Further, of course, many opportunities for corruption arise when such large sums of money are at stake. Very large sums of money are at stake and, as we know, corruption does occur.

Fourthly, and related to that, because for many hundreds of thousands of young Australians their only awareness of the criminal law, their only consciousness of it-the fear that they may be breaking the law or in peril-is in relation to their marihuana use, they develop, if not a contempt of the law, an indifference to the rule of law because they regard it as absurd. It is a bad situation for society when this indifference to the rule of a law is so widespread. It means that, eventually, there is an indifference to the democratic parliamentary institutions which support and sustain such laws.

Which young Australians are we speaking of? I did a survey, when I was at the University of Tasmania, of those who were convicted for marihuana use in 1975 and 1976. There were 821 convictions in Tasmania for offences relating to marihuana; 111 were recorded against labourers and 288 against the unemployed. That is, 50 per cent of those convicted for offences were either labourers or unemployed. Yet it would be a very brave person indeed who would say that 50 per cent of the users of marihuana in Tasmania were labourers or unemployed. In other words, the law latches on to those who are vulnerable and most defenceless in our society, those who are living perhaps in groups, in poor dwellings or in certain defined areas of town where the drug squad can operate most effectively and freely in order to get its monthly quota of convictions. We as legislators ought to be protecting the poor, the defenceless and the vulnerable in society instead of creating criminal laws which invariably have their impact on them. The fact is that the use of marihuana is extremely widespread. The discussion paper is of the view that a survey carried out by the Age is a valid one. A table was produced showing the percentages--

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not say it was accurate.
—The Committee would not have quoted it if it thought it was radically invalid.
—They said it was the best available.
—The best available table--
—They did not claim it was accurate in any way.

—I bring to the attention of the Senate a survey conducted by the Age in which are shown the percentages of the population who had tried, had used or were current users of marihuana. The figures were as follows: For the 60 years and above age group, 1 per cent of the population; 45 to 59 age group, 3 per cent; 35 to 44 age group, 8 per cent; 25 to 34 age group, 26 per cent; 21 to 24 age group, 42 per cent; 18 to 20 age group, 37 per cent.
—That is those who have ever tried it.

—Yes. My point is that each of those persons, some 42 per cent in the 21 to 24 year age group, was a potential criminal according to the sorts of laws which the honourable senator is defending. In other words, if they had been unfortunate enough to be the subject of detection by a drug squad detective, to be charged, prosecuted and successfully convicted, their lives would be blighted . They would have the stigma of a criminal conviction which would affect their careers, job opportunities and their travel abroad for the rest of their lives and would lead to the horrendous consequences that I have outlined. But the fact is that that number of people will never be detected because the criminal law is used against the poor and the defenceless. My statistics from Tasmania show that that is the case.
—Do you believe that 42 per cent is an accurate figure? No one is claiming that.

—I believe it is in that order. In the 60 years and above age group only one per cent of the population use marihuana but in the 21 to 24 year age group 42 per cent of the population use it. The scale establishes that young Australians are using this drug to a very great extent. The fact is that only a minority are detected. The law is enforced in a way which reinforces the drug stereotype which the general community is invited to believe, that the normal drug user, the user of marihuana, is somehow a layabout, hippie, unemployed labourer type. In fact, use of marihuana is across all classes of society but the law is directed to the poor, the vulnerable and the defenceless. I take very much to heart Lord Justice Lawson's words in an English case some six or seven years ago. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing to be said, and said very firmly indeed, is that Her Majesty's Courts are not dust-bins into which the social services sweep difficult members of the public. Still less should Her Majesty's judges use their sentencing powers to dispose of those who are socially inconvenient. If the courts become disposers of those who are socially inconvenient the road ahead would lead to the destruction of liberty. It should be clearly understood that Her Majesty's judges stand on the road barring that way.

I believe that this Parliament, and other parliaments in Australia, should stand on the road with the judges barring that way, instead of requiring them to do what my figures for the situation in Tasmania show they are doing. To put it another way to summarise this part of my remarks, if society wanted to establish a mechanism which induced our young people into a semi-criminal sub-culture, which provided a situation of extreme stress and temptation for our law enforcement officers, which insured a cash flow to criminal syndicates for their more nefarious activities, which undermined respect for the law and ultimately for the parliamentary institutions which sustain those laws, it would adopt the total prohibition model in relation to marihuana-as did the United States in the 1920s in relation to alcohol with all these consequences.

I think I have established that the penal laws are totally inappropriate to achieve the aim which I said we all have in common, namely, to bring about a situation where in Australia we are not drug ridden, inebriated and intoxicated, but where the use of drugs as a relaxant-as social or recreational matter common to all human cultures-is undertaken as a matter of choice with good knowledge of the health risks involved. I believe that the potential users and the actual users of drugs will listen to information concerning those health risks-such as Senator Walters outlined last week-only if those potential or actual users believe that society is dealing in a fair-minded, even-handed way with drug use and abuse in our society. The discussion paper, in its foreword, states:
A rational society should seek to develop its control policies on all mood- altering substances on a common set of values. Integrity in our values will help ensure credibility of our actions.

It is the view of many hundreds of thousands of Australians, particularly young people, that we have a hypocritical society in which tobacco tycoons and brewery barons are festooned with honours every time Her Majesty has a birthday or celebrates New Year's Day. However, users of marihuana are subject to the full wrath of the criminal law when it selects them out for some sort of symbolic punishment-a punishment, of course, which acts as no deterrent at all. It has no deterrent value. But the law comes down with all its repression on the defenceless and vulnerable in our society whilst, as I said, having a well developed system of bestowing honours on the distributors of the other drugs which are common to our social system. What we have-it has been stated by others before-is really a witch hunt syndrome which most societies seem to need whereby all the evils are visited on one social activity and made the subject of severe punishment from time to time. It is a scapegoat, a witch hunt mentality which seems to be part of our society at the moment in relation to marihuana. We have made terrible mistakes in relation to the distribution and use of alcohol and tobacco in our society by making them--

TALK.START.PARA: —So let's make another!

—No. I am saying that we have made terrible mistakes by making them the source of private profit and government revenue. Nothing I would say about the way to deal with marihuana would see in our response to the circulation of alcohol or tobacco any model for dealing with marihuana. It should not be the source of private profit or public revenue. At the same time, as I have pointed out, we cannot allow a situation to continue in which the circulation of marihuana is the source of funds for criminal syndicates, the cause of corruption of our law enforcement agencies and places our young people in a more vulnerable situation of being prey in the shadowy sub-culture that they now inhabit when they want to deal for marihuana. It is time for a fresh approach and here, I believe, the discussion paper is extremely useful in putting forward proposals which I think may well command widespread support. I believe that several steps need to be taken over a period but in this order: Firstly, there must be an expunging, a wiping out, of the convictions and the stigma of conviction attached to so many hundreds and thousands of ordinary, decent Australians-otherwise law abiding members of our community-who presently have these convictions blighting the rest of their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: Rehabilitation of offenders legislation has been passed in the United Kingdom. I emphasise the word 'rehabilitation' because its aim is to bring back into full society those who have transgressed the laws relating to marihuana. We should do the same. We should expunge those convictions. In fact this has been recommended by royal commissions in this country. It is time the Parliament acted on that as a first step, as a token of faith in our young people, in particular. Society does not want to create such a situation that their careers and their lives will be in jeopardy for one transgression, for being selected out of a mass of offenders by a detective and the court processes set up by our own parliaments. That should be the first step.

The second step is that we should remove the criminal penalties for the use, or possession for personal use, of marihuana. One would only remove criminal penalties in relation to that simple use or possession for personal use. I am not saying, as Senator Walters tried to say last week, that there is not a problem in relation to the use of a motor vehicle whilst under the influence of marihuana or the use of industrial machinery while under the influence of marihuana. There are problems. Offences need to be created relating to the driving of motor vehicles or the use of industrial machinery while under the influence of marihuana.

A certain paragraph of the discussion paper states that in imposing penalties for driving while intoxicated by cannabis one needs at the moment to take into account urine or blood samples to detect the level of cannabis in the blood. Society has found, by the use of technology such as the breathalysers and so on, a means of detecting the levels of alcohol in a person driving under the influence of alcohol. I am not minimising the difficulty of finding a technology which measures accurately drugs in the system. One has also to take into account the fact that because cannabis is retained in the fatty tissues-I think that is right-there is a slower release than in the case of alcohol which is burnt up reasonably quickly. Therefore, it may be some time after one has used cannabis that the deleterious effects on the motor system become apparent.

We do have a problem. We have to have offences and penalties for the driving of motor vehicles or the use of industrial machinery while under the influence of drugs. There are difficulties there. But the point that I am emphasising is that in relation to the mere use or possession for use the criminal law should not operate. It is a most peculiar situation at the moment. There is no victim apart from the offender, as there is in the case of murder or theft. We do not even say that our policy is, as in relation to some of the old laws relating to alcohol, that person is drunk and incapable of taking care of himself. We merely say that a person's using the drug is sufficient for the criminal law to be applied. I argue against that proposition. We should remove criminal penalties for that simple social situation.

Finally, and only concurrently with a very sophisticated campaign alerting Australians to the dangers of drug abuse, we should smash the criminal rackets, the shadowy subculture, the semi-criminal world in which many hundreds of thousands of Australians deal at the moment, by placing the production and distribution of this drug in the hands of a government monopoly. This should be done, as I stated before, in a way so that it is neither a source of private profit nor, I believe, a source of government revenue. When the distribution of a drug becomes a source of government revenue, as the ill-effects on our health become apparent over the years governments will be half-hearted in their reaction and in their campaigns against the use of that drug. Let us admit that that is one of the features of our half-hearted approach to the abuse of alcohol and tobacco in our community at the moment. While it is a source of revenue for the Treasury, governments will not act in a half-hearted manner to combat that abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government has a monopoly, of course it will be.

—Can I make my speech? Senator Walters made her speech last week. Will she please allow me to make my speech. I believe that it may well be the case that the distribution of this drug-this is a personal view, not the view of the discussion paper-ought to be through chemists' shops so that people are psychologically aware that they are purchasing a drug, and there is always a pharmacist on the premises. This would create a cautionary atmosphere, an atmosphere in which the drug is being produced and distributed through a government monopoly not set up for profit or for government revenue. The distribution should occur through registered pharmacists.
—What do you say about growing marihuana for personal use?

—My personal belief is that if society takes the bold step of allowing circulation of this drug by a government monopoly in the way that I have described, those who want to use the drug ought to accept that as a very significant change in our social attitudes. As part of that arrangement or deal they should refrain from producing the drug. To say that is not to stop them actually growing marihuana for personal use. I believe that it would be very difficult to devise a social system that could really combat that. I believe that if hundreds of thousands of Australians came to the view-a view that they do not presently have-that society was dealing in a fair way with the distribution of marihuana, and that they were getting a drug of controlled and known strength or strengths-there may be four or five types or packets available in the chemist shop-then they may not want to take the risk of growing and ingesting something of an unknown strength.

SPEECH.PARA: On a more general note, I believe that if society took this sort of approach we might create a society where the use of drugs-the escape, the addiction to drugs -may not be so widespread because we would, in fact, be creating a more tolerant society, a society where tolerance was seen as a moral virtue and, as I will argue in a moment, as a political virtue which I believe would have a spin-off. People would not feel the sorts of pressures that they presently feel as we live in a most intolerant and repressive society. Of course, the intolerance and repression is selective and generally visited on those least able to defend themselves, as I have pointed out. The Catholic Diocesan Pastoral Council made a submission to the Tasmanian House of Assembly Select Committee on Victimless Crime. I make it clear that it did not endorse the decriminalisation or legalisation of marihuana but in the course of its general submissions on the area of victimless crimes it said:

Law must keep close to the moral sense of the community and the moral sense of the community must inspire law. This is not repressive of minority opinion because in a civilised and Christian community tolerance of differing moral view -points and practices will be part of that general moral sense.

I believe if half of the moral outrage that we hear in this chamber on this type of issue were channelled into an equal sense of passion on behalf of the virtue of tolerance we could indeed create a structure of laws and of social attitudes to the use of marihuana and other mind-altering drugs which would create such a society that the need to escape in an addictive way into the use of drugs would be less common than it is now. Not only is tolerance a moral virtue; I believe it is also a political virtue. The very definition of a democracy is not simply a society where the majority, for the time being, makes the laws. If that was the definition we could easily have a majority acting in a most repressive, totalitarian way. A democracy is a society where the majority for the time being makes the laws but also where there is a tolerance of ways of life which do not involve violence but which might differ from those of the majority and a tolerance of people putting forward points of view dissenting from those of the prevailing majority. That is a tolerant democratic society.

I believe that in many ways the cannabis debate can be one of the touchstones of our attachment to democratic ideals. In any case I believe that the workshop of the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence has served the Australian community very well in the production of this report. It is too early to say what our legislative response ought eventually to be. In that respect I believe that Senator Chipp may wish to wait until there is further discussion and debate within the community before he moves in the way he indicated that he might. I believe we are a long way from coming to a proper legislative response from parliaments such as ours. But it is up to parliaments and chambers such as ours to help engender a responsible, creative and constructive debate in relation to this most serious social situation that we presently find ourselves in. I hope that other senators from time to time may contribute to that discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the first reading of the Tobacco Charge (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1982 and associated Bills to raise matters relating to the Australian Federal Police, the Customs Bureau and the matters on Nugan Hand Ltd raised by my Leader, Mr Hayden, in the other place over the last several days. When we look back on the decisions of the Fraser Government to amalgamate the Australian Capital Territory Police and the Commonwealth Police to create the Australian Federal Police, the decision to disband the Narcotics Bureau and to have a drastic overhaul of law enforcement authorities at the Federal level it would appear that they were more than just mechanical decisions and arose from a great number of deficiencies and weaknesses that existed in these law enforcement agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent time we have seen a number of incidents which would indicate that we have reason, as a Parliament, to be very concerned about the Australian Federal Police. For example, we have seen the drop in morale and various transfers taking place in that organisation. Criticisms are constantly recurring in respect of the Customs Bureau. Criticism was made also about the activities of the Narcotics Bureau, particularly from 1975 until it was disbanded in 1979. The Government has failed to come clean on these matters and to present a factual and truthful report of the reasons why it took the steps it did in 1979 and 1980 to effect dramatic and drastic changes to these agencies.

I am concerned at what appears to be an attempt by the Australian Federal Police to dramatise its activities. There is an element of theatre about the way in which the organisation carries out its activities, and about the persecution that takes place in the lower ranks of the force. I do no more than remind the Senate of the constant attempts by my colleague Senator Grimes to deal with the fiasco commonly known as the Greek conspiracy case and the very obvious attempts made by the Superintendent and some other leading members of the Australian Federal Police to gild the lily and in a Hollywood-like way attempt to create in the public mind the impression that the Australian Federal Police had something new and better in law enforcement at the national level.

My colleague Senator Evans referred several weeks ago to the raids on Dr Wainer 's residence and surgery in Victoria. This is another element of the dramatisation of the activities of the Australian Federal Police. It was an attempt to create in the public's mind an impression of a degree of efficiency that clearly does not exist. The raid was an attempt to create in the minds of the public and the Parliament the impression that the organisation was carrying out a worthwhile task. I believe there is a need for the Parliament to be given information as to the real position in the Australian Federal Police. Hardly a week goes by that I do not have representations made to me by the lower ranks in the organisation about the dissatisfaction and concern that exists at middle management in the Australian Federal Police. I am prepared to exempt Sir Colin Woods, the Commissioner, from any great criticism that I make about the Australian Federal Police. I think he is a victim of circumstances. I think he is burdened with management at a lower level which makes it very difficult for him to handle properly the attempts being made by those who are firmly entrenched in the bureaucracy in the organisation itself. I say that because that is not only my impression but also the impression of the lower ranks of the organisation.

I refer very briefly to one incident in recent times. I refer particularly to the Acting Assistant Commissioner, Mr Antill, who, together with some of his fellow officers at that ranking, is known to socialise very heavily with certain elements of the restaurant trade here in Canberra. As a result of such socialising he developed a relationship with a person whom he subsequently sponsored in an application for travel arrangements. The action was subsequently found to warrant some disciplinary action against the Assistant Commissioner. The Assistant Commissioner was known to be a very strict disciplinarian who always went out of his way to exert the sternest measures against some of the lower ranks for any actions that he considered as misdemeanours or constituting dereliction of duty. Mr Antill was a commissioner who had been promoted very rapidly in the service. He gave the green light to a passport clearance to a person subsequently found not to be of a character that would entitle him to those privileges by the Australian Government. He placed the then Minister for Immigration in a very embarrassing position. Of course, these matters were not dealt with in the way in which the matters of discipline are dealt with in the organisation; he was shifted sideways and made the officer in charge of the Northern Division. Of course, that creates, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would well imagine, a degree of concern and justifiable criticism by other members of the Australian Federal Police.

I refer now to the constant requests and demands that have been made by the Customs Officers Association, particularly those that were made by Mr Spanswick. I speak on behalf of those members who consider the activities of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to be unsatisfactory. I wish to deal also with matters which were partly dealt with by Mr Hayden last week and again this week. I refer to the information that came to hand regarding the Nugan Hand organisation. It might be recalled that in 1979 the Government took steps to disband the Narcotics Bureau. We were not given the real reasons for that. We were told that it was done in the interests of efficiency-the centralising of authority and so on. The facts that are starting to come out include that it was disbanded because some of the officers in the Narcotics Bureau were playing a double game in respect of drug trafficking and other related matters in this country. Persons involved in that organisation found great difficulty in expressing to the Government and to management their concern at some of the events that were taking place in that organisation. The Government took steps to disband it and, to that extent, it recognised that there was a problem. In mid- July 1979 the Government, I think as a result of information which is now becoming public, established a joint Commonwealth-State task force on drug trafficking. This arose as a result of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs conducted by Mr Justice Williams and the Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking conducted by Mr Justice Woodward. They were concerned about the drug problems-matters perhaps more serious than those raised in the very important contribution made by my colleague, Senator Tate, who preceded me in this debate.

Substantially that is where the matter has rested. We have been asking questions in the Parliament about the activities of the task force. I believe it is only because of matters that were raised by Mr Hayden last week and again this week that we finally flushed out from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) a statement which he gave to the Parliament in the last 24 hours. He indicated that some progress had been made on this question of Nugan Hand. The Government felt that it should act, and in this respect the Prime Minister made the following comment:

. . . that there is intense media interest in the activities of Riley, Wainwright and Nugan Hand; in the investigation by the Joint Drug Task Force of these activities, and in the anticipated report of the Force to the Governments on the investigation undertaken.
He then stated why these matters should not be debated. He said:
. . . it is thought likely that in due course criminal prosecutions will be commenced against a number of individuals named in the Report for drug, conspiracy, perjury and passport offences.

It has taken us from 1975 to 1982 to get to the point where some of these facts are being acknowledged by the Commonwealth Government. Information was given to the Narcotics Bureau way back in 1975 that there was a process by which drug trafficking was taking place in this country and that the Nugan Hand organisation was involved. Information from investigations was provided to the Government through the Narcotics Bureau. There was then the death of Mr Frank Nugan. I think it has been said that he committed suicide but when one reads the documents that are now available one has some doubts as to whether it was a suicide. Certainly there is a body of opinion that suggests that because of that gentleman's links with the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence gathering organisations in this country and in Asia there is more to it. Having regard to the whole problem of drug trafficking that is taking place in this country, particularly the importation of the hard drug heroin, in which the Nugan Hand organisation was involved, one does not have to be influenced by a conspiratorial mind to suggest that there is more to this than meets the eye. A lot of people at the government level and at the bureaucracy level have been warned about this. There is still much more to be done before we finally get to the bottom of this whole horrible operation.

One finds it difficult to understand why, several years ago, the Narcotics Bureau both in Canberra and in Sydney had consciously limited its investigations in this matter to background checks of a covert nature. Sections of our intelligence organisation took the extraordinary step of discussing this matter with the present leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales. When he was interviewed back in 1977 I think he was spokesperson for the Liberal Party in the affairs of the Attorney-General. I know that he came to Canberra and discussed with Government Ministers information that was made available, as I saw him here and heard him discussing the matter with government Ministers in the parliamentary dining room. Information is available which shows that Mr Phillip Bailey of the Narcotics Bureau had this to say in a report as early as 14 November 1977:

If Nugan Hand Ltd, is involved in the drug business it is most likely as either a behind the scene financier of drug importations or as a means of laundering the money made from drug sales. The second possibility should take into account the information received on folio 65.

When Mr Hayden referred to a number of these documents in the House of Representatives he was assailed by the Government to produce evidence to substantiate some of the matters that were raised in these documents. It is an impossibility to be able to prove any matters concerning an organisation which is clearly clandestine and which is probably involved in counter-intelligence activities. The American Congress and the American Senate dealt with the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency of that country and with the activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Their reports show that it was only on the basis of the presentation of witnesses and documents which had not been destroyed that they were able to verify any matters through the appropriate parliamentary process. I find it rather strange that Mr Newman should be so sensitive when Mr Hayden raised these matters in the other place, when words have been bandied about in the Parliament suggesting something improper by the leader of my party, when he raised questions as a result of representations made to him. Indeed, these same representations have been made to me.

The Nugan Hand organisation, which was suspected of heroin importation, first came to the notice of the Narcotics Bureau in October 1975. It was a merchant bank that had a turnover of $220m in the year 1976-77. I know that journalists of the calibre of Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson have written a number of articles in the National Times about the role of Bernard Houghton and his links with the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States of America and about a number of admirals who have retired from the United States Navy and who are known to have been actively involved in Vietnam and in intelligence gathering. As these documents show, a whole group of these operators in Australia, the principals involved in the whole operation, are former United States citizens who have been naturalised as a result of their terms in Australia. They have played a covert role of some sort in laundering money and have been involved in illegal activities relating to currency and drugs.

Of course, it is very difficult for members of parliament to establish the veracity of these matters, but I think it is wrong to impute a lack of integrity or party political considerations when members of parliament ask questions and seek to have a judicial inquiry or some sort of public investigation into the very serious matters which have been raised, particularly by Mr Volkman. I am concerned that the Prime Minister in his statement said that the task force interim report, which is of a private and confidential nature, has been made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). In fact, if we look more closely at what the Prime Minister has said we will see that there is a certain restriction on the information contained in that report. Mr Acting Deputy President, having a legal background, you would know that a royal commission can deal with only those matters which fall within its terms of reference. The Stewart Royal Commission, which is currently examining a number of these matters , has very restrictive terms of reference. They are associated with drug trafficking as it relates to Mr Asia and that connection. They are narrow. Therefore I suggest that the wider matters which Mr Hayden has raised following the allegations made by Mr Volkman are not able to be properly dealt with in that inquiry.

So we are still confronted with only part of the story. We are still confronted with the wholesale manipulative process that has been part of the activities of the Nugan Hand organisation and its links with very important sections controlling finance capital in this country, with land development companies, with respectable banking institutions, with political parties, with prominent citizens and with criminals. We have before us an unholy mess, only part of which has come to the light of day.

As the Senate is to deal with another matter at 8 o'clock I will have to say what I want to say about Mr Volkman in the next few minutes. Mr Volkman was employed by the Commonwealth Government for a considerable number of years. His line of investigation accidentally got him into the position of lifting a small part of the curtain on Nugan Hand. He did not take kindly to the suggestion that was made to him by management in the Narcotics Bureau that there should be no further investigation by him and his fellow officers. He considered that it was his bounden duty to the community, to the Australian people, to see that this matter was properly ventilated, examined and investigated. Some members of the senior management in the organisation for which he worked decided to get him, to seek some vengeance because he had refused to be part of the cover-up arrangements relating to Nugan Hand.

Of course, whether he is guilty of the charges that have been preferred against him is not for me to say. But I think you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would agree that when an officer of such an organisation-a public servant, a person who has given long service to the community, to the people-has been subjected to committal proceedings for 16 days in the Court of Petty Sessions under Stipendiary Magistrate Nash in New South Wales and it has been found that there was not a case to answer, one is entitled to ask why the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, has filed an ex officio indictment against Mr Volkman and why the Commonwealth authorities have approached the New South Wales Supreme Court seeking a period of six to eight weeks to deal with the charges preferred against Mr Volkman and others. The maximum penalty for the charge which has been preferred against Mr Volkman is $1,000. The judge, when asked to set aside that period, made a very pertinent and relevant point. He asked why the Commonwealth should be so concerned when the maximum fine, assuming that there was a case of guilt, would be a mere $1,000.

Mr Volkman has made allegations and has provided a number of documents which are in the hands of the Leader of the Opposition. He has asserted that a number of documents on the file relating to Nugan Hand have been destroyed. Mr Hayden has suggested that the way to test the veracity of the allegations by Mr Volkman would be to produce the files that deal with the Nugan Hand matter. Then we could get to the bottom of the extent to which leading members of the Australian establishment are involved in Nugan Hand and its activities. Mr Volkman has been supported by two other persons, former colleagues of his who worked in this area . One is prepared to have his name used publicly and the other, for obvious reasons, is not. I spoke earlier about the persecution that takes place in the Australian Federal Police and the Bureau of Customs. One can understand the reluctance of the second person to be identified, having regard to what he knows to be an attempt, as we see it, to frame or get even with Mr Volkman. In addition, Mr Spanswick has reiterated his call on behalf of his organisation for a full scale investigation by the Government into the Bureau of Customs. One is entitled to say that on all the evidence that is available there is something rotten in the state of our law enforcement agencies; that there is a case for an examination of the allegations that have been made; and that there is a case for the Parliament, if not to be involved in its own right, to seek to have an investigation into these allegations. I cannot imagine why Mr Spanswick speaks continuously about these matters in his own right when, in fact, he claims to be speaking on behalf of all the people who have been involved in investigations into the Nugan Hand operation.

The Prime Minister indicated very clearly in his statement that in the establishment of the Commonwealth task force it was necessary to have the support of the New South Wales Government and its Corporate Affairs Commission. He indicated that the task force has 11 New South Wales police officers, five Australian Federal Police officers and one Corporate Affairs Commission officer. It is within the knowledge of members of parliament and interested members of the public that the Corporate Affairs Commission in New South Wales has been carrying out a very extensive investigation into the Nugan Hand organisation. Today, in the New South Wales Parliament, documents were tabled which indicate that Mr Nugan, who was one of the principals in the organisation, which was set up deliberately, was prepared to pay a large sum of money to anyone who was prepared to frame the New South Wales Attorney-General, Mr Frank Walker. That story was in the news and was made public in the New South Wales Parliament today.

We are not talking about fairy tales. We are not trying to create a conspiracy that does not exist. We are talking about facts. Law enforcement officers are involved in the drug scene in Australia. Certain people whose task it is to protect the Australian people and the users of hard drugs, are involved in drug distribution. It is quite clear that heroin is imported into this country on a massive scale. There is an interchange of opinions between honourable senators about marihuana. The use of that drug is child's play compared with the massive importation of heroin that is taking place in this country. It is not for me to suggest how it is coming in, but it obviously is. There is massive importation and disruption of our law enforcement agencies. It is an area in which there is a great deal of corruption. I do not believe it is possible for drugs to be continually brought into our country without the involvement of people in high places. It is impossible for ordinary John Citizen to be involved in this process of importation. Drugs are clearly coming into the country with connivance. It may be happening behind the scenes, but it is coming into this country in a successful way and our law enforcement agencies are failing to deal adequately with the problem. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
General Business taking precedence of Government Business at 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 November 1981.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page (1), clause 3, definition of ''Aboriginal'', after ''Australia'', insert ''identified as such by the community in which he lives''.
(2) Page, Clause 3, definition of ''Islander'', after ''belong'', insert ''and is identified as such by the community in which he lives''.

(3) Page 3, Clause 3, leave out definition of ''Law of Queensland'', insert the following definition: '' 'law of Queensland' means any law, whether written or unwritten and whether substantive or procedural, and as in force in Queensland from time to time, and includes:

(a) a law made by the Parliament of Queensland or a law having effect under, or by virtue of a law made by, the parliament of Queensland, and includes regulations and other instruments (including by-laws), and
(b) any laws providing for the interpretation of laws specified in paragraph (a );''.
(4) Page 4, clause 5, after sub-clause (4), insert the following new sub-clause:

I comment, briefly, that the amendments came about as a result of a number of things. Most of the amendments came about by consultation with the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland and, in particular, by consultation with the National Aboriginal Conference representatives from Queensland. Other amendments came about because Senator Missen, Senator Bonner and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, raised issues concerning the first draft of the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill. Most of those comments have been accommodated. I think all of the substantive issues raised by Senator Missen have now been accommodated by way of amendments. There are also amendments which I prepared myself to overcome some of the technical problems with the drafting.

The thrust of the amendments is to clarify those parts of the Bill which were not sufficiently clear, to strengthen some of the self-management provisions in the Bill, to put into the Bill the normal kind of parliamentary scrutiny of the regulatory making powers of the councils and to clarify, in particular, clause 14 which provides that all of the laws of Queensland shall apply to reserves except those laws which are prescribed by the Minister, and they will be prescribed only if they are discriminatory towards Aboriginals and Islanders. Those honourable senators who have been actively involved in debate over this Bill have had the amendments in hand for a couple of days. Other honourable senators will have received them recently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the amendments that have been moved . I agree that most of them relate to recommendations by the Queensland Aboriginals. Senator Ryan pointed out that when this matter was being debated at the second reading stage I was in general support, but I was concerned particularly with clause 14 because it appeared that it allowed a very sweeping opportunity to remove the laws of Queensland, including even human rights laws and laws which, of course, were for the benefit of people in the reserves as well. I agree that the amendments Senator Ryan has put forward, which enable the prescribing of laws in Queensland so that the Commonwealth Minister can set out those laws which ought to be not required to be complied with by members of the reserve, now make considerable sense in relation to this clause and, I believe, make the Bill quite workable. Honourable senators are well aware that Senator Bonner spoke last week and expressed views on the proposals which the Queensland Government had made alleging that land rights were to be given to people in the reserves in Queensland. I take the view which he has taken here that-
—Senator Bonner's speech was very compelling.

—Yes, indeed it was. What is not compelling is the proposal of the Queensland Government. Honourable senators will remember that the debate on this Bill was deferred for a period to enable the Queensland Government to come up with a genuine offer of land rights for the people of the reserves. What has come up since are really just proposals contained in statements. As far as I know there are no signs of a Bill. Certain rights are proposed under the relevant lands Act which can be abolished at any time by the Queensland Government. I do not find that, in any way, a genuine offer of land rights for the Aboriginal population of Queensland. I know from the people and the many organisations which have made representations to me that they do not find this offer acceptable and in accordance with the obligations which we, as a Federal Government, accepted in the 1967 referendum. It would not be a fulfilment of our obligations to the people of Queensland. I do not see that the duty that we owe to Aboriginal people in Queensland is very different from what we owe to the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory or in other places. Of course, we have provided for land rights in the Northern Territory. In Queensland the offer , which so far has not even been translated into a Bill, as far as I know, is one which, of course, is open to be destroyed by the whim of the Queensland Parliament and does not give the security to which I believe Aboriginals in Queensland are entitled. I do not propose to expand on this in detail. Senator Bonner has said more on this subject. I support him most strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: Having supported the second reading of this Bill last year and finding no reason now to find acceptable the offer which the Queensland Government now makes, I believe this is a Bill which, with the sensible amendments in it, ought reasonably to be carried through this place. If there were other defects in the provisions of this Bill, of course, one would expect that before this Bill went through the House of Representatives the Federal Government would have ample time to look at it again. I have yet to see any commentary from the Federal Government on the terms of the Bill and the amendments. Of course, there is time . A Bill passing through the Senate has to go to the House of Representatives. Therefore, if there are any defects, it is well within the position of the Government to bring them forward and to debate them in the other chamber. I believe it is important that we pass this Bill. I believe the amendments which are now proposed make a very sensible piece of legislation that ought to have the support of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add another reason why it is important for the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 to be passed. I refer to the unhappy circumstances that are developing in Queensland, where we face, as the Commonwealth Games approach, confrontations between the authorities and the Aboriginal people. Citizens-both black and white-will be caught up in that situation. The police forces will be involved and even, as was intimated in answer to a question by Senator McLaren, perhaps the armed forces.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will give some satisfaction to the Aboriginal people that at least the Senate-and, I hope, the Parliament as a whole-recognises the rights of the Aboriginal people and will pass sensible legislation in connection with land rights. I cannot too strongly stress how important this is, how it will defuse the situation in Queensland and how it will take the initiative away from the Hinzes and, for that matter, the Premier of Queensland who are determined in some way to exacerbate the problem. For that reason I strongly support those who have taken the initiative and who have brought this Bill to this stage. I will not speak any longer because I hope that the Bill has a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to clause 14 of the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 because it is one of the clauses about which I had some grave reservations. I am very pleased to see that Senator Ryan has proposed an amendment to clause 14. It is certainly now acceptable to me. All of the clauses that have been changed are in keeping with what I would have wanted. They strengthen the Bill and make it a far better Bill than it was. That is no criticism of Senator Ryan' s earlier Bill. These provisions have strengthened the Bill and have made it a much better Bill. It can be said that the passage of this Bill at this time may be only an expression of opinion. We do not know what will happen to it when it leaves this place. We cannot be sure whether it will have as speedy a passage down at the other end of the building as I am sure it will have here. The Bill will be an expression of opinion of this chamber of the Commonwealth Parliament. It will give encouragement to the Aboriginal people not only of Queensland but also of all the other States where there is at the moment no land rights legislation before the Houses of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud again to have the opportunity of standing up in this chamber and supporting this Bill as I did on the last occasion with my colleague Senator Missen. There were two or three other people on this side of the chamber who I am quite sure have a great deal of sympathy and support for what we are endeavouring to do in the passage of this Bill. Senator Georges touched on a very important point. Senator Georges is concerned that-I too am concerned- confrontation could occur in our State during the Commonwealth Games. I pray that that will not happen. I hope it will not be necessary for Aborigines to offer any kind of protest, demonstration or whatever. I hope that we will be able for the first time in my State of Queensland to bring justice to the indigenous people of that State. I still have some small hope that the Queensland Government will come good-to use a common Australian expression-that it will, as it were, produce the goods in what it is endeavouring to do.

I pointed out in my speech here recently what is wrong with the Queensland proposal. We do not have any legislation. We do not have a Bill or anything like that. I availed myself of a copy of the Act which will govern the proposal that has been put forward by Queensland. All the things that I said the last time I spoke on this issue are in that Act for anyone to see. The proposal certainly is a most unacceptable proposal if it is to remain as it is at the moment. I sincerely hope that that will not be the case and that, with the passing of this Bill in its amended form, some encouragement will be given to the Government of Queensland to come up with a better proposal. If that happens Senator Ryan will have served the indigenous people of this country very well indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The amendments that have been proposed to the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self-Management and Land Rights) Bill 1981 have our support. The vast bulk of the amendments are machinery amendments of one kind or another, though scattered throughout them, as least on my recollection, are three substantive amendments of the same kind to extend the consultation process. I think these measures follow on from the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 that went through the Senate. Action is becoming more and more crucial in this area. I commend Senator Ryan for drafting some of the amendments and the extension of those consultation processes in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: With the limited resources available to the Australian Democrats and, I am sure , to the Australian Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —And others.

—And Government senators. There may be and almost certainly are drafting defects still in the Bill. One must grant that that is a possibility. I hope that, since the Bill will obviously have the support of the majority of the senators in this chamber, any such defects currently in the Bill have been brought to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and that he will be able to raise them at this point. I am quite sure that he and the Senate would be unwilling to pass this Bill and send it to the House of Representatives unless it were in the best possible form that could be supported by the majority of senators. Therefore, I hope that the Minister, if he has any comments on any of these amendments, particularly any that he feels need to be altered, would put his argument now. If not, I suppose that we could assume that since the Bill would have been looked at in detail by the Minister we probably have what might be the best Bill, given the collective resources of individual senators and the Government, and may now pass this Bill to the House of Representatives for its deliberation and, I hope, passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I might speak briefly at the third reading stage to set out the Government's position, but it is appropriate to speak now at the Committee stage to respond to the point made by Senator Macklin. I believe that we received the amendments last night. There has not been a lot of time to look at the amendments that have been circulated, so we have a number of questions and queries. I make it clear that this is a private senator's Bill; it is not a Government Bill. The Government still does not support the Bill for reasons which I will set out later and, therefore, I have some queries which I think Senator Ryan can probably answer. I will take them seriatim, if I can, and ask them one at a time.

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of 'Aboriginals' that Senator Ryan has used in clause 3 of the Bill requires that an Aboriginal person be one who is 'identified as such by the community in which he lives'. I do not believe that any Commonwealth statute uses the three-part working definition of an Aboriginal. The question arises as to how the definition will work. For example, what rights of appeal will people have if they are not so certified by their community? It may be that they will have no rights as Aboriginals under this legislation. So there is an appeal procedure under the Act using the definition in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition was broadened to include the phrase 'identified as such by the community in which he lives' at the request of the National Aboriginal Conference. It goes beyond the constitutional definition of Aboriginal and Islander but we believe that it is a constructive suggestion by the National Aboriginal Conference because it will solve the problem of people coming into a community in order to participate in the ownership of land when those people are not acceptable to the community. If an unacceptable person were attempting to participate in the ownership of the land, that would be a disruptive situation. We believe that the communities can identify their genuine members and that this would help to create social harmony . There is no appeal procedure in the Bill as yet. If the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) would like to suggest one, I am sure we could consider it. There is in the Bill provision for a disputes commissioner. Perhaps the disputes commissioner could also have the task of hearing an appeal against the non-according of resident status to a person. I suggest that the disputes commissioner could be given that extra function.

— This definition is almost identical to the definition used by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It is almost the definition used for National Aboriginal Conference elections. It is not word for word the same. The definition used by the Department and for NAC elections is that an Aborigine is a person of Aboriginal descent who identifies as such a person and is accepted in the community in which he lives as such a person. That is almost identical to the definition used here. I do not understand why there should be a need for a disputes committee or whatever, because the Department does not have a disputes committee. If someone is rejected for a house or for a housing loan because he does not fit that criterion, there is no appeal that I know of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — This is not my Bill. I am merely drawing out some of these problems. I said very clearly that the definition is not in any other statute. It is correct that it is used by my Department. Recently I was in Tasmania talking to Aboriginal communities there. One of the subjects they brought up for discussion was the difficulty which this definition gives to that community in making it work. One of the questions they brought to me was: Who certifies that someone is accepted as such by the community in which he lives? The question of an appeal procedure came up. I am just making the point that Senator Ryan, by using this definition, may be building in a power of veto against which someone has no appeal. I am not certain that it sits well with clause 18, I think, in which reference is made to the rights of a person who was born in a community. I am not sure how that person's rights are going to sit with the need to be an Aboriginal according to this definition. This definition, because it is now in a statute, may be testable. I just ask whether the honourable senator has thought through the difficulties she might have with the definition and whether she requires an appeal mechanism. As no one has risen to answer that point, I leave it.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to clause 7 and ask Senator Ryan: Is it a fact that this is the first of several amendments which change words which were previously in the Bill? Senator Ryan used the words 'Aboriginal and Islanders' and changed them to 'persons'. I think she has also done that in clauses 9 and 10. I just ask whether this change will meet the constitutional validity test; that is to say, can the power to make special laws for the people of any race give to the Parliament the power to make laws, or to authorise the Aboriginal councils to make laws, to apply to any persons? Has Senator Ryan thought through whether she might have created problems for herself in terms of constitutional validity by changing those words in that way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The replacing of the phrase ' Aboriginal and Islanders' by the word 'persons' occurs a number of times throughout the Bill. It creates a situation whereby the councils are responsible for all persons living on the reserves but responsible to Aboriginal and Islander people only. The Aboriginal councils will be able to make by-laws, in respect of which, by the way, there will be parliamentary scrutiny and disallowance procedures, and everbody living on the reserves will be obliged to live by those by-laws. I would think that the same sorts of constitutional powers that allow any local council to make by-laws would be the appropriate powers here-not the special constitutional powers concerning Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) an example of the kind of situation which led us to accept this amendment, which was proposed by Aboriginal and Islander people. If a community makes a decision that alcohol will not be permitted on that community and makes a regulation to that effect and if that regulation is scrutinised and maintained by the Minister , by the Government, then any white person living on that community-a school teacher, an administrator or any such person-shall be bound by that regulation not to bring alcohol on to the reserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be constitutionally invalid.

—The Minister persists in the view that it may be constitutionally invalid. Of course, such provisions are in effect in some communities in the Northern Territory. I am sure that the Minister will be aware that there are some communities where alcohol is not permitted and that white people similarly are not permitted to bring alcohol on to the reserves. So I do not think there is any precedent in what I am proposing here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Ryan has said in respect of this matter. I certainly think that this is a constitutional provision which will stand up. As she says, this happens in the Northern Territory. The provision as expressed in the original Bill suggested that in making special laws for Aboriginal people, the powers of the council which runs a reserve are confined to dealing only with Aboriginals; and teachers and others employed by the council who are not Aboriginals would be otherwise not under its control. I think that a special law for the race that is being protected here and given power over the reserves would be a very inadequate law. I have no real doubt that a proper power here is given to the council to make laws which also affect others who are on an Aboriginal reserve but who happen to be white Australians. To my mind that is a very useful and necessary power if the councils are to control the reserves properly. For these reasons I believe that it is one which should be upheld.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that such actions taken by the council are made by regulations and are subject to veto by this Parliament. That is not a constitutional point. From the point of view of ensuring that there are not too sweeping rights, that white Australians' general rights and privileges are not taken away from them, it is well within the competence of this Parliament in reviewing such regulations to ensure that that does not happen. So far as the constitutional position is concerned, I believe that this is a proper and competent power which can be given. Of course, it relates to a number of other amendments which will be made further down the line.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to one point. Again, I am just trying to bring out some of the problems that I have seen. Senator Ryan cannot compare a situation which exists in the Northern Territory. She is no doubt aware of section 122 of the Constitution, which creates a special capacity for the Commonwealth to make laws in respect of the Territory. I repeat that I do not agree with Senator Missen's interpretation . The power under which we are acting is one restricted to making laws for a person of any race for whom it is deemed necessary. I doubt that it is a capacity to make laws for any person.

—Obviously clause 12 gives a power to the Aboriginal land council to exclude from a reserve a person who is not an Aboriginal or Islander. Its ability to affect white Australians presumably has to be part of the authority that such a Bill gives. It must be able to extend to white Australians or there would be no power, for example, to exclude people. If the point that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is making is correct, I think it does threaten to a very large extent the ability of the Aboriginals and Islanders under the rest of the Bill to control those lands in any real sense.
