If this Bill cannot affect Europeans in relation to who is allowed to enter or who is excluded from a reserve, presumably there is very little point in pushing ahead with the legislation. However, I would have thought it would be beter not to move these amendments, given the types of questions that have been raised, but instead rely on clause 12 which contains a fairly obvious power. If one could establish the reserves in such a way that white Australians or Aboriginals in some circumstances could be excluded from the reserves I think that that would give sufficient power to the council to pursue matters raised under the clauses referred to by the Minister, 7 and 9.
—That is assuming that clause 12 stands.

—That is assuming that clause 12 stands. I think that if clause 12 cannot stand the whole legislation becomes a farce. It merely means that the council can control Aboriginals but it can do nothing to whites. Surely that is not the intent either of the legislation that this Government enacted in relation to the Northern Territory or of this legislation.

—Senator Macklin raised an interesting point concerning the entry to reserves and communities dealt with in clause 12. A very similar proposition appeared in the Bill from which to some extent this Bill was copied. The Bill which this Government carried in 1978, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-Management) Act 1978, is a prototype. A number of provisions are similar. The provision in regard to entry into reserves and communities is differently phrased in section 12 of that Act which we passed. But essentially it has the same purpose. It provides that where the council for the reserves is satisfied that it is for the benefit of the Aboriginal community it may permit persons to reside or visit and it can so authorise. In other words in the Act which the Government passed in 1978 we make it clear that decisions can be made by the councils which may allow or forbid white persons to come on and go off reserves. So it hardly becomes the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to speak as he did in the light of the legislation which the Government previously passed which deals with Queensland and which turned out to be ineffective legislation because the Queensland Government abolished the reserves. Nonetheless we relied upon those sorts of powers in 1978. It is very difficult to see why we cannot rely on them now.

—I turn to clause 9. I will not repeat the concern that I had about clause 7 regarding the question of 'persons'. I think the same argument applies or does not apply. Clause 9 goes to the provision of services by councils. It is curious that it refers to powers to make by-laws on forestries, waterways and fisheries. I am intrigued to know from the honourable senator whether these are valid powers to confer on councils under the constitutional provision to make laws for people of any race.

—I understand why the Minister raises those matters because these particular activities-forestries, waterways and fisheries-are controlled by the State. They are included because they are traditional Aboriginal activities. Many of the communities will be getting part of their livelihoods, for example, from fishing and so on and they will wish to make some sorts of regulations concerning them. However, I must point out that State law will apply and that any regulations that the Aboriginal councils make with respect to those functions will be subject to State laws except insofar as State laws have been proscribed. If there were any conflict between a regulation that the Aboriginal council made concerning fisheries and the State law, the State law would override unless it had been proscribed. I do not anticipate that laws concerning fisheries would be proscribed. But it may be the case that regulations that the Aboriginal councils make with regard to fishing are in accord with the State law and so there would be no conflict and no problem at all.

—I want to be quite clear about what Senator Ryan is saying. Is she saying that whether it is a valid power the State law would prevail and there would be a capacity to make those by-laws so long as they were consistent with the laws of the State?

—Yes, I think that the Minister has understood the point that if the Aboriginal councils make some regulations with regard to the taking of fish, for example, then those regulations, if they were in accord with the State laws affecting fisheries, would remain; if they were not the State law would override.
— Does that mean that the State has a power of veto over the kinds of by-laws which the councils might pass?

—I think Senator Missen has already clarified the role of State laws with respect to these councils in his comments on clause 14. I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to turn his attention to clause 14 which sets out very clearly, I think, the relationship between Aboriginal self-managed communities and State laws. There is a parliamentary power of scrutiny over all regulations. So in that sense yes, there is a veto power because of parliamentary scrutiny. But in a day -to-day sense, the State law would override only in the case where the resolution was in conflict with it.

— Clause 14 relates to the application of Queensland law to Part 1 of the Bill. By the way, I take it that in a strict technical sense there should have been a Part 1 right at the beginning of the Bill and the section we are discussing should be Part 2 but we are not going to worry about that. What is a prescribed law and who prescribes it?

—A prescribed law will be a law prescribed under the provisions of this Bill by the Government. The only clause which will be prescribed laws are laws which are discriminatory to Aboriginal and Islander people. Obvious examples of this-the ones we all have in mind-are the Queensland and Torres Strait Islander Acts. They would be prescribed laws because they are discriminatory. But the laws that are to be prescribed laws will be laws prescribed by the Government for the purposes of this Bill. They may be prescribed only if they are discriminatory towards Aboriginal and Islander people.

—I think they go further than that. The expression 'prescribed' is that used in the Acts Interpretation Act. It means, of course, that they must be by regulation. Once a regulation is put down saying the Queensland health law or some law is to be prescribed then, of course, that is a regulation which comes under the scrutiny of this Parliament. It would be for the Minister in this Parliament to decide that such and such a law does act unfairly towards members of the reserve and that, therefore, it ought to be prescribed. So, within the control of the Minister there is the determination of what laws are to be prescribed. That can be checked. But my understanding of the use of the word 'prescribed' is covered by the Acts Interpretation Act and that brings it within the sphere of regulations which are subject to scrutiny by this Parliament. I think that is a sensible way of dealing with the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Missen for his clarification. Indeed, he is quite right. Under the Acts Interpretation Act a prescribed law is one prescribed by regulation. I point out to the Minister that he would be prescribing the laws under this Bill. I draw the Minister's attention to the third part of clause 14 in my amendments which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations may make provision for the exclusion or modification of a law of Queensland which adversely affects Aboriginals or which discriminates against Aboriginals in its application to Reserves or to Communities.

TALK.START.PARA: — Honourable senators will probably be aware that I have a complete analysis of the Bill. It is quite pointless, therefore, raising point after point. However, there is one other matter I feel I should raise because I do think it is a substantial matter and it worries me. It relates to clause 44 of the Bill. I will leave all the other matters aside because I accept what honourable senators have said, that the Bill requires considerable drafting work to make it really acceptable or watertight. But clause 44, under the regulation-making power, as I understand the amendment, purports to require prior approval by the National Aboriginal Conference and the land trust or the council for any regulations even to be put to the Governor-General. Have I read the clause correctly? My understanding is that, if that were the case, the amendment would put the NAC and the land council or the land trust between the Governor-General and his advisers in a veto position. If I understand that to be the case that would be completely unacceptable, certainly in a sense of constitutional propriety. I have no objection to a requirement or a desire that one should consult with these Aboriginal groups. But it would be quite another thing to provide them with what is a virtual statutory veto. I find this to be a matter of some concern as the clause appears to be drawn.

—I think the Minister has drawn his interpretation too widely altogether. The provision that is proposed in this amendment is that there shall be consultation with the National Aboriginal Conference before regulations which affect Aboriginal councils are taken before the Governor-General and, therefore, brought into effect. It is a certification that there has been consultation. That consultation in no way implies that the Governor-General has to agree with the advice of the National Aboriginal Conference. But surely it is a very sensible thing that he should have consulted it and told it about these regulations just as we have in the situation, commonly now, where regulations are being made affecting the Australian Capital Territory. The House of Assembly is constantly consulted and advised of them. But that in no way binds the Government.
—Is it a statutory relationship? I do not study regulations but the legislation seems quite singular.

—It is not quite singular. Just recently the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills reported on a provision in a Bill-I cannot remember which Bill it was, but it was mentioned in one of our three reports already brought down-in which there is a provision for consultation with an industry body. It relates to one of the schemes for control of primary industries. That provision is included in a recent Government Bill which has not passed through the Senate. It is, therefore, in no way unique. There ought to be consultation. There is no provision here that interferes with the right of the Government to give advice to the Governor-General, quite ignoring the view of the National Aboriginal Conference once it has been consulted. I think that the Minister has read too much into that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the most accurate points made by Senator Missen. The Minister asked whether this is a singular provision. It is by no means a singular provision. Senator Missen has referred to legislation prepared by the Government which contains a similar statutory responsibility to consult.
—Which Bill was that?

—Senator Missen referred to it. But I refer to legislation which has been enacted by this Government, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act which was enacted in 1979. It contains a statutory requirement for consultation to be made with the Leader of the Opposition. There is clearly a precedent for this consultation procedure. Obviously once the consultation has taken place the Federal Executive Council can do what it likes. But the requirement to consult is what we are providing for here. There is, already, an established precedent for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated during the Committee stage of the debate that I did not want to take time then in talking generally. Indeed some honourable senators who contributed raised some general matters. I thought would take the opportunity of the third reading to make the position of the Government clear. We opposed the Bill when it was introduced. We opposed during the second reading and although we have not pressed the matter to a division the Government is still opposed to the Bill for the reasons which we set out previously. It is really no more urgent now than it was last September when it was introduced in the run-up to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The fact there are now so many amendments necessary to the Bill, and that it still has so many loose ends shows just how hastily drafted the original measure was.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the amendmens will go some way towards removing the orginal objections, which incidentally were also commented upon by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. The legislation when it was introduced was defective by any test, including the test of the Senate's own Committee. The real question still remains as to whether the Bill is really necessary or appropriate at this time. To answer that I really have to advert to what several honourable senators referred to in their contributions during the Committee stage. The Queensland Government has quite recently announced in broad terms what its own proposals are. Although these proposals represent a move in the right direction towards obtaining secure tenure for Aboriginals in Queensland, we are still looking for clarification of Queensland's intentions on particular matters-either matters not spelt out or matters on which we have sought some modification. We have yet to see the details of any Queensland Bill. We have yet to see the fine print of the Queensland proposals. I think we should keep that Queensland announcement of 1 March in perspective.

A year ago, in January 1980, the Queensland Premier announced that he would abolish the Acts, abolish the reserves and leave the reserves as Crown land with Aboriginals to live as other Queenslanders. The recent statements by the Queensland Premier represent a major move from the position and are a major advance. They are certainly a big move along the right road. This is something we could not have imagined a year ago. As I said at that stage, Queensland was talking about abolishing the reserves without intending to do anything to provide a better scheme of land holding arrangements for the Aboriginals. Later on there was talk of granting 50-year leases and of maybe giving perpetual leases. Now there is an intention on the part of Queensland apparently to Aboriginals much more than this. I think it is inappropriate to pursue this Bill when the Queensland proposals still are being developed further and when the Senate does not know what those proposals are to be.

How this private member's Bill is handled is entirely up to the Senate. Surely the sensible course would be to wait until Queensland's proposal is known-with all its positives and with all its faults-to continue to discuss with Queensland Ministers and Torres Strait Islanders and Aboriginal people who live on reserves what it is they want and to reserve judgement on the final package. I believe that it will be a question af looking at the proposed amendments to the Queensland Act.Then, and only then, can we understand fully what it is that Queensland has proposed and in what ways, if any, that falls short of what the Senate would require.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it clear the reserves have only moved from being terrible to being bad?

—That is a value position. Aboriginal opinion still needs to be gauged through further consultation. The Commonwealth believes that it is highly desirable to find a solution in Queensland which is just to Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Queenslanders alike. I would rather see the Queensland Parliament develop its own solutions rather than to try to impose an artificially contrived scheme of the kind presented in this Bill. I assure the Senate that the Commonwelth is continuing to be very closely involved in the development of this matter. It is for that reason, because we do not know where the matter is going to end and because people-my colleague Senator Missen, for example-are making assumptions about what the end point will be, that we still find ourselves unable to support the honourable Senator Ryan's Bill. It is not, as people might want to suggest, that we are not seeking a just settlement. The only good settlement is a settlement that will be fair to the Aboriginal people of Queensland and to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we wish to see a Queensland solution to this matter does not mean that we are seeking any disadvantage to Aboriginal people. On the contrary, we hope that it is they who will benefit from any arrangements. If we can find arrangements which avoid confrontation between the Commonwealth and the Queensland Parliaments, we believe that will be in the longer term interests of all Aboriginals, and indeed all Australians. There is no need for urgency. When the Opposition was in government between 1972 and 1975 it was faced with exactly the same issues. The Labor Government of the day advocated that persuasion was more effective than confrontation. It took that view in this approach to Queensland. In 1973 the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gordon Bryant, told the International Commission of Jurists conference on Aboriginal rights and law:

We are going to be quite firm about the situation in Queensland. We are not going to tolerate the continuation there of the Queensland system but we are going to try to pursuade them first. There are a lot of advantages in persuading them because the Queensland apparatus in Education, Health and so on is what is going to operate across the board.

The Labor Government felt that legislation would not be appropriate then. I believe it is still inappropriate to try to find a federalist solution. We know that the exercise of such Commonwealth power would bring with it a test which would bring out all the doubts which exist as to the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of any legislation. Of course, if we had to move to confrontation we would have to move to the high cost of acquiring the reserves.

It is for the Senate to decide at what stage in the matter it wishes to relinquish control of this Bill. It should be made clear that once the Senate in its wisdom decides to give the Bill a third reading-that is a matter for the Senate-it loses all control over what happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a silly statement.

—It is a self evident statement. I say to the Australian Democrats, for example: 'You have no presence in the other place. You have a presence here. It is up to you whether, by passing this Bill, you are prepared to let its further course through the Parliament occur with no input from your party. You must be aware whether the Labor Party, knowing the state of the numbers, is prepared to give up the Bill'. I have already said that the Government opposes the Bill. I believe that what will come out of Queensland is significantly more advanced than people here know or believe. When that is known and when there is Queensland legislation that will be the time for people to pass judgment on it. I believe the Bill is premature. The handling of the third reading stage of the Bill is entirely in the hands of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) sounds something like a coach who has just lost a football match and who has gone inside to cheer up his troops, complaining about the referee, the ground, the weather and everything else because he has not got his own way. I rather wonder which is worse-a cashiered coach or a petulant politician. We have had a fair indication of this tonight. I mean that in all seriousness, because the sort of thing about which we have been talking all this time has been the spirit of co-operation which has existed in relation to this Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self- Management and Land Rights) Bill, the fact that it has gone to people and has been talked about. This is one of the features of the Bill about which the Minister was speaking only a short time ago-that it has been to people, that it has been spoken about and that there has been plenty of time for a good Bill to come before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate Senator Ryan on the way in which she has handled the Bill. Of course, other honourable senators have made contributions to it. She would acknowledge that. But as she is the shadow Minister doing the job, she is able to reap the benefit, and I certainly would not deny her any of her achievement tonight. I believe the Bill represents an enlightened approach. As one who has been concerned with Aboriginal affairs for many years I believe that this is the sort of Bill which we have been looking for for a long time. I do not believe it is appropriate for the Minister to say that it is not time for this legislation to come in. It is certainly not. It is overdue in coming to this place. When we hear the Minister say, 'Let us wait a little longer', does it not ring a bell? I seem to remember Senator Chaney saying: 'Let us wait a little longer'. I hear Mr Viner saying: 'Let us wait a little longer. Let us see what they will do in Queensland'. It is quite clear that we should not have waited. We should have moved before.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been saying the same thing about Ralkon for years. They have been pushing it under the carpet all the time.

—I will not enter into that part of the matter. That is a contribution from the side. We need to have positive action, as the Minister indicated just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. Once again, I commend the approach taken in this matter. I believe that the people who have been involved around Australia and on both sides of the chamber tonight have made a significant contribution. I commend those who have been involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to speak too long as I know we are going on to other business. I think we have to apply the test of what is best for the Aboriginal people. It is all very well for some of us to speak about the fact that there might be imperfections in the Bill. It is all very well for the Minister to say: 'Let us wait and see what Queensland will do'. We have a fair indication of what Queensland will do because we have seen its general attitude towards Aboriginal people. We have seen the legislation that it has introduced in the past. We have seen the legislation that it has introduced against the non-Aboriginal people of Queensland. So I do not think we need to wait too long for that. The legislation which has gone through tonight-I believe it is enlightened and is one of the most important pieces of legislation that has passed through this place in recent months, if not in recent years-is, in the opinion of the people on this side of the chamber and I believe a good number of people on the other side of the chamber, in the best interests of the Aboriginal people. I commend Senator Ryan for introducing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sympathise with what has been said by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I am aware of the enormous amount of work that the Minister has done in trying to convince the authorities in the State of Queensland to come up with a good deal. By the same token, when the Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders (Self- Management and Land Rights) Bill was introduced last year my colleague, Senator Missen, moved a motion on his own behalf and on my behalf. I am committed to that motion. I believe that what we are doing tonight is in accord with what we said at that time. We have given the Queensland Government an opportunity to do something. It has made a statement from which I quoted quite extensively the last time I spoke. I reiterate that that statement is totally and absolutely unacceptable in its present form.
—That is right. That is not the end of the matter.

—We have not reached the end of it. For the last few months the Queensland Government has been well aware that this Bill has been on the table. It was well aware that the Bill was deferred to give it an opportunity to come up with something positive. To date it has not done so. What it has come up with is completely and totally unacceptable. The Minister has talked about consultation. There has been consultation between the Minister, his Department, the Queensland Government, the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Advancement, the Premier and the Deputy Premier. But there has been no consultation with the Aboriginal community as a whole. One has to look no further than today's Courier-Mail editorial for proof of that. I wish to take up a little of the time of the Senate to quote from that editorial. I quote only the important part of that editorial, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is time for the State Government and representatives of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to try to reach agreement on the future of land reserves .

The State Government's plan for the reserves was released more than a fortnight ago. All interested parties have had time to study its major provisions, and to form opinions on its wisdom and fairness, or otherwise.
When the proposals were released the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, said that everyone would be happy and satisfied with them. But this has not turned out to be the case.

Most Aboriginals are not happy. The Archbishops and Bishops of the Anglican and Roman Catholic churches in Queensland are not happy. Many other white Australians who share a concern about the future of Aboriginals are not happy.
These differences over the proposed plan are no reason, however, for the State Government to see the issue as one for confrontation. Rather it is a matter for communication.

The Courier-Mail editorial is referring to communication with Aboriginal people. Despite what happened last year when this Bill was introduced and despite the fact that the Queensland Government was given time to come up with something, it has not done so. It has not consulted broadly with Aboriginal people. It has refused to do so. I have tried on five separate occasions to meet with the Premier of Queensland. I wanted to meet with him, his Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Advancement and the Deputy Premier. I have had no response from that Government at any time. I have made speeches in the Senate and have spoken everywhere about this whole issue but the Premier has refused to meet with me. If he will not meet with me-a fellow politician-what hope have the Queensland Aboriginal and Islander communities of having fair consultations on this important issue that affects not only them but also the lives of their children, grandchildren and their future generations? I think we have given the Queensland Government an opportunity to come up with something better. It has not. For that reason I am in total support of the passage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to answer some of the points made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). Firstly, I restate my reason for introducing this Bill as a private member's Bill. I did not do so, as has been suggested by the Minister tonight, for some irrelevant political motive. I introduced this Bill as a private member to implement the Australian Labor Party's policy on land rights for Aboriginal people in Queensland. We believed then and we believe now that land rights to Aboriginal reserves in Queensland will be secured only by action from the Federal Parliament. Nothing has happened in the several months that have elapsed following my introducing this Bill. The very extensive consultations and discussions that have taken place with people such as Senator Bonner and Senator Missen, and the announcements that the Premier of Queensland has made from time to time, have not altered my conviction, the conviction of the Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland and the conviction of many other people throughout Australia, that if land rights are to be secured for Aboriginal people in Queensland it will happen as a result of action by this Parliament. It will not happen unilaterally as a result of action by the Government of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is still asking us to wait to see what kind of proposal the Premier of Queensland will ultimately offer to his Aboriginal and Islander constituents. I point out to him that the legislation which will be passed through the Senate tonight is enabling legislation for the Federal Government. If this legislation goes into the House of Representatives next week and is passed it will merely enable the Federal Government to grant land rights to the people living on reserves in Queensland. It will not force any issue that the Federal Government does not want forced but it will enable the Government to secure that land for those Aboriginal and Islander people. If the legislation were passed through the House of Represenatives next week and if in the following week the Premier of Queensland came up with a suitable proposal, no harm would have been done.

The Minister is in a somewhat contradictory position. On the one hand he has said that he and the Government do not wish to proceed with this legislation because they believe that the solution can come from the Government of Queensland. On the other hand he claims that there has been some improvement, some progress, in the attitude of the Government of Queensland. If there has been any improvement-I must say that I tend to agree with Senator Bonner and Senator Missen that there has been very little indeed-surely it has been partly because of action in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And this Bill provides a further weapon.

—Exactly. If this Bill were to be passed through the House of Representatives next week that would be a further incentive to the Premier of Queensland to act in the interests of Aboriginal and Islander people. It would not force the issue. It would still give him the opportunity of doing it. The Minister shakes his head. Frankly, I would shake mine, because I do not believe that any solution will come from the Premier of Queensland. I must remark too on the Minister's criticism of the Whitlam Labor Government's action in respect of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. The Minister asked why we did not proceed to legislate.
—I did not criticise it; I just quoted Mr Bryant.

—The Minister quoted Mr Bryant, from I think 1973, expressing the view that a negotiated settlement was better than legislation. But by the time 1975 came around the Labor Government realised that negotiation was not to be the solution. In 1975 the Labor Government introduced and passed the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act. That legislation was passed through the Senate. That Act exists, yet the Fraser Government has not been prepared to use it for the protection of Queensland Aboriginal and Islander people. I think it is inaccurate for the Minister to suggest that the Labor Government was not prepared to legislate to take steps with regard to the situation of Aboriginal people in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to consultation, the Minister said that the Premier of Queensland will ultimately come up with a proposal, that there will then be consultation and that everything will be satisfactorily resolved. I suggest to the Minister that my Bill-and the way it has been handled in this Senate and with the communities involved-provides a model of the very consultation he is suggesting. I introduced the Bill some months ago after consultation with Aboriginal and Islander people. Having introduced the Bill we then engaged in extensive consultation. We had the benefit of suggestions from the Australian Democrats, from Senator Bonner and from Senator Missen. The amendments that have been moved and passed here tonight-I notice that the Minister did not try to change them- are the result of all of those people working in a co-operative manner towards a common goal, which is security of tenure for the Aboriginal people of Queensland . All the kinds of consultation that the Minister likes to advocate in other circumstances have in fact been carried out. This is why we have before us tonight a Bill with a number of amendments which, I believe, satisfies the requirements of Aboriginal people for their land in Queensland. I do not believe that there are any serious defects in the Bill. If there are the Minister has had his opportunity to move amendments to overcome those defects. I can assure the Australian Democrats, who were subjected to some sort of threat by the Minister that they will no longer have any influence on discussion of this Bill, that when the Bill goes into the House of Representatives next week, the Labor Party will be only too willing to listen to any comments they may wish to make with regard to its passage through the House of Representatives.

I thank the Australian Democrats, Senator Bonner, Senator Missen, members of the National Aboriginal Conference from Queensland and all the Aboriginal people and the vast range of community and church groups who have contributed to this discussion. I believe that the Bill is a better and more appropriate Bill for the rights of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland because all of those people bothered to participate. I say in conclusion that as far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned the settlement of this matter must be as a result of Federal parliamentary action. In our view human rights are more important than State rights. In our view the human rights of Aboriginal and Islander people must include secure title to their land. It is the purpose of this legislation to provide just that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF TAN SRI DATO' SYED NASIR ISMAIL

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with regret that I inform the Senate of the sudden death on 16 March of Tan Sri Dato' Syed Nasir Ismail, a most distinguished Speaker of the House of Representatives of Malaysia. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with me in an expression of sympathy to the family of the late Speaker of the House of Representatives of Malaysia and to the Parliament of Malaysia on this sad occasion.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for amendment of the Repatriation Act in four respects. The first is in relation to the control of the disability pensions for veterans suffering serious service related mental illness.

Mr President, the Prime Minister announced last year, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that deductions for maintenance from the pensions of a small number of mentally ill veterans to whom section 49 of the Repatriation Act applies, were to be discontinued and that the disability pensions of certain veterans should be handled in the same manner as all other disability pensions.

Section 49 of the Repatriation Act is a special provision that can be applied by the Repatriation Commission to withhold the pension of an unmarried veteran suffering severe mental illness. The severity of the mental illness must usually be such as to warrant long-term hospitalisation in a mental institution.

If a veteran recovers to the extent that he is able to control his own affairs, all retained money is paid to him. If he dies without recovering, the accumulated funds do not form part of his estate but are disposed of at the Commission's discretion to members of his family or to persons dependent on him, with any remaining funds being paid to Consolidated Revenue.

Mr President, the provisions of section 49, which had their origins in legislation enacted in 1920, are out-dated and create some significant differences between the way these mentally disabled veterans are treated and the way other disabled veterans are treated. For example, it has been the practice under section 49, for half the disability pension to be deducted as a contribution to the cost of their maintenance while in a mental institution, and to pay this deduction to Consolidated Revenue. It is the Government's view that, since no other veteran is required to make such a contribution when receiving treatment for a service-related disability, the practice is discriminatory and should cease.

This Bill, in repealing section 49, will provide for a veteran's pension and any accumulated money to become his property, in the same way that it is for every other veteran. As a result, if a veteran dies while still suffering from his disability, all of his accumulated pension will form part of his estate and be distributed in accordance with his wishes if a valid Will has been made, or otherwise, in accordance with the laws of intestacy.

If a veteran is in a mental institution his affairs are normally controlled by the State Public Trustee. Some of the veterans to whom section 49 applies are not the responsibility of State Governments, and these are generally those veterans who are no longer in mental institutions.

The Bill provides that upon the repeal of section 49, the accumulated moneys of these veterans will be transferred to the trusteeship of the Repatriation Commission under regulation 9 of the Repatriation Regulations or, if it is thought that the veteran is able to manage for himself, his pension will be returned to him with the interest earned. The Bill provides for these arrangements to come into effect on the date of the Royal Assent. Discussions have been held with the various State Governments with a view to transferring the appropriate funds to the respective State Public Trustees who would be responsible for the veterans' welfare. Agreement has been reached with five States on the proposed arrangements, and a reply is awaited from the other State .

These arrangements will mean that a Public Trustee would assume the responsibility which he would normally have in respect of these veterans but for the existence of section 49. In many cases the Public Trustee already has responsibility for the other assets or income of the veteran and therefore the current dual trustee arrangement would be removed.

The Bill also provides for transitional provisions to finalize the accounts of veterans who have died, or who die before Royal Assent. These provisions extend the benefits of the new proposals to those veterans.

The Bill also provides for the extension of Repatriation benefits to Australian members of the Multinational Force and Observers committed to the Sinai region. This is in accordance with the undertaking the Government gave last year when Repatriation benefits were extended to Australian representatives of peacekeeping, observation or monitoring forces. Repatriation benefits are to be extended on the same basis as applies to Australian members of other peacekeeping forces under Division 10 of the Repatriation Act.

Mr President, the Bill also provides for two other matters. The first is to facilitate the recovery of Commonwealth expenditure for medical treatment provided to patients eligible to receive either workers' compensation benefits or third party damages and to align such provisions with those in other Commonwealth Acts. The present provisions of the Repatriation legislation are restrictive in that they allow the recovery of medical treatment costs from the injured party only and not from a third party, such as an insurer. The cost recovery process would be far more efficient and less demanding on patients if the Repatriation Commission could act directly with third parties as is the case under the Social Services Act and the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. The Bill will achieve this.

The second, Mr President, is to enable Regulations to be prepared which will protect from legal actions those employees in Repatriation hospitals who may be required to carry out duties arising from State legislation. These employees, in order to comply with State law as part of their community service, require the full cover of that law in order to be properly protected in the execution of their duties. However, because of their status as Commonwealth employees and the separation of Commonwealth and State jurisdictions they do not have that protection in some instances. At this stage, the main concern is the taking of blood samples in accident cases for the purpose of blood-alcohol testing. As the protection of medical and ancillary staff is not extended by State legislation, Repatriation hospital staff have not been permitted to undertake these procedures.
These amendments are to come into operation from the date of Royal Assent.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY SUPPLY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962 to provide for the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority to restrict the use of electricity in the ACT following the declaration of a state of emergency by the Minister.

The Territory currently derives 60 per cent of its bulk supply of electricity from New South Wales, the balance coming from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. Due to the significant amount of total bulk supply of electricity that is purchased from New South Wales the Authority is particularly vulnerable to emergency situations occurring in New South Wales. Shortages of electric power and energy in New South Wales have resulted in emergency situations and requests to the Authority to reduce load.

In the past the Authority has sought to achieve this reduction by means of public appeal to its customers for voluntary restraint coupled with reduction of the supply voltage. These methods have not, however, resulted in a reduction as significant as that achieved in New South Wales by means of legislation enabling the supply to be restricted.

In order for the Authority to respond effectively to emergency situations and to provide an equitable distribution of the available supply, it is essential that the Authority has power to impose restrictions.
It is indeed unfortunate in the extreme that this action is necessary.

New South Wales has supplied a large part of the electricity requirements of the Territory since 1929. With the exception of the early postwar years and a short period in 1973, the Government has been able to rely with confidence on a continuation of adequate supply.
This, unfortunately and regrettably, is no longer the case.
Since June last year, the supply of electricity from New South Wales has been uncertain. We cannot be confident that the situation will improve.

The power supply problems in June 1981 were due to a combination of factors the principal one being the shutdown caused by plant difficulties in two large generating units combined with major industrial problems, this is, in fact, what the Electricity Commission of New South Wales has admitted in so many words. Failure of two more large units at Liddel power station in November 1981 exacerbated again by industrial problems caused the imposition of restrictions yet again.
Some relief was expected with the Commissioning of the first generator at the Eraring power station but this too has been now delayed for months-again due to further industrial disputes.
The Government believes that the chain of events is such that it must be fully prepared to deal with future emergencies-for the welfare of the National Capital and its residents.

The Bill makes a provision for the Minister to declare, by notice in the Gazette, that an electricity supply emergency will exist during a period, not exceeding 28 days, specified in the notice. The Minister may make such a declaration where he is satisfied that the supply of electricity available in the Territory is, or is likely to be, so inadequate for the needs of the Territory as to require restriction of use. The declaration may be revoked by the Minister by notice in the Gazette if the need for restrictions cease.

During a period of emergency the Authority may, by order in writing, restrict the use of electricity in the Territory. Details of the emergency orders to be made will be published in the Gazette and in a newspaper circulating in the Territory. Details may also be published by radio or television broadcast if the Authority considers it appropriate to do so. The orders will come into force on the date of gazettal or such later date as is specified in the Gazette. The orders will be subject to disallowance. They will be laid before both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days of their making and either House may then disallow them within a further period of 15 sitting days.

Honourable senators will recall that on 26 May 1981, my colleague, the Attorney -General, avowed the Government's commitment to the principle that delegated legislation and such like should be subject to review by parliament. In accordance with this principle, provisions for the disallowance of instruments of a legislative character should, unless there are good reasons for variation, incorporate the substance of certain traditionally accepted safeguards, such as requirements that they be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days of their making and that a motion for disallowance must be dealt with within 15 sitting days.

While, in accordance with this principle, emergency orders will be subject to disallowance, the very nature of emergency orders and the time constraints which an emergency imposes, necessitates, on this occasion, the incorporation of a further procedure in the Bill to make Parliamentary review more effective. Accordingly, in making the emergency orders the Authority will comply with guidelines made by instrument in writing by the Minister which have themselves been subject to disallowance by the Parliament. The guidelines will be laid before both Houses of Parliament and either House of Parliament may, within five sitting days after a copy of the guidelines has been laid before it, pass a resolution disallowing them. If neither House disallows the guidelines, they will come into force at the expiration of the five sitting days. The Authority cannot make an emergency order unless the guidelines are in force.

The period for disallowance has been limited to five sitting days because it is considered essential that the Authority be in a position to impose restrictions this winter. This might not be possible if the disallowance period were the usual 15 sitting days. In addition, it may be necessary for the Minister to amend the guidelines quickly if they prove inadequate to deal with the emergency at hand.
Persons, including bodies corporate, who without reasonable excuse contravene or fail to comply with an emergency order, shall be guilty of an offence.

During an emergency a Justice of the Peace may, where he is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that a contravention of, or a failure to comply with, an emergency order has occurred, grant a search warrant effective for a specified period, to an officer or employee of the Authority, authorising that officer or employee to enter and search the land or premises for the purpose of ascertaining whether such a contravention or failure has occurred.
The Bill will bind the Crown.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON MANAGEMENT AND OPERATION OF WILLIAMSTOWN NAVAL DOCKYARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The motto of the Williamstown Naval Dockyard is 'Deeds not words'. For the last 10 years or so the deeds have not been very satisfactory but there has been a flood of words about this dockyard. It has been described, I think with some accuracy, as inefficient, badly managed, strike plagued and just plain unworkable. There have been many reports in the last decade about this dockyard. They have been both secret and public. They have all identified problems that need solving if the dockyard is to be made efficient. The trouble is that very little has been done about it.

Until 1970 the dockyard was a small shipbuilding and refitting yard. It had a relatively good record. It was not perhaps a highly efficient dockyard by world standards, but by our shipbuilding industry standards it was quite efficient. Things started to go wrong in the early 1970s. The first problem was the cancellation by the Whitlam Government of the DDL project which was intended to give continuity of work to the Williamstown dockyard for many years. This was compounded by the decision of the then Minister for Defence in the Whitlam Government that despite the reduction of work there would be no redundancies. This has meant that the dockyard has been paying, for most of the recent years, at least 200 men a year to do nothing. This has had shattering effects both on the efficiency and the morale of the dockyard.

The situation has also worsened as a result of the defence reorganisation which has made even more cumbersome the management situation of the dockyard. This is a matter which the present committee of inquiry into the Defence Department, chaired by Mr Utz, should take note of. No warships have been built in the Williamstown dockyard since 1970, which is 12 years ago. A three stage modernisation program for the dockyard has been in place. The first two stages cost $44m. The aim of the project is to make it possible to build modern destroyers of the FFG type. We have ordered four of these destroyers from the United States and have received two. It is planned that the Williamstown dockyard should be capable of building such complex ships. I point out the size of the project. The present plan, if the dockyard proves suitable and the reorganisation is acceptable, is that it will certainly build two of these ships and probably four more. Each of these ships built at Williamstown will cost more than HMS Invincible. There has been great debate in the Senate about whether too much is being spent on HMS Invincible. Each of the six ships planned to be built at Williamstown will cost more than HMS Invincible and the total project cost will be in excess of $2 billion. We are talking about a major project at the Williamstown dockyard. We certainly need assurances that the dockyard will work efficiently.

The recent committee of inquiry into the Williamstown dockyard made what in my view was a shattering report on its organisation and efficiency. It identified four main areas of defect. The first is late material and equipment supply. Major items of government furnished equipment, normally ordered through the Department of Administrative Services, have arrived years late for ship construction projects. Some major items of equipment arrived after the relevant ship was scheduled to be completed. The whole structure of equipment supply is seriously awry. The second area of concern is the use of Public Sevice procedures in a shipbuilding organisation. This has had serious effects not only on the organisation of the dockyard but also on financial areas, industrial relations and general man management. In an organisation such as a shipyard, Public Service procedures are quite inappropriate. The third area of concern is the defence reorganisation introduced by the Whitlam Government. This has caused a serious loss of confidence and efficiency and a much less responsive head office. The final area of defect in the structure is the lack of separation between the producer and the customer. They have been in the same organisation and this has caused quite serious problems.

The recent committee of inquiry looked at all the inquiries that were made into the Williamstown dockyard during the 1970s. Its examination revealed that many sensible and appropriate recommendations were made. In some cases those recommendations were approved, but there has been practically no effective follow-up. The committee concluded that the present defence departmental system is much more effective in the identification of dockyard problems than it is in doing anything about them. The committee of inquiry, chaired by Mr Hawke from Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd-not from the House of Representatives-concluded that local dockyard management is currently deprived of the necessary level of control and flexibility with regard to the key areas of manpower, finance, information, materials and support services. In other words, they are deprived of all necessary areas of control and flexibility to run an efficient dockyard.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder they are in trouble.

—I am stating why they are in trouble. The report identified a number of areas. The committee looked at various possibilities for improving the operation of Williamstown dockyard within current Public Service operation and ownership by the Department of Defence. Its conclusions were that the dockyard must be made to operate as nearly as possible as a successful commercial shipyard producing warships. Taking this as a principle, it concluded that some movement towards a more appropriate organisation is theoretically possible within Public Service and departmental ownership. It could see that there was some possible way where suitable arrangements could be made for finance, material, information and support services although it considered-I am sure it is right-that they would be very difficult to achieve in practice. The committee said, and I would like to quote its words here because they are crucial:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have been given no encouragement to believe that Public Service Board control of manpower, management aspects, particular ceilings, structures, conditions of service and industrial relations could be delegated and replaced by controls of a more appropriate nature for a ship building yard.

It concluded that it could not recommend construction of destroyers at Williamstown dockyard under the circumstances because successful management of manpower was a fundamental requirement for any efficient shipbuilding.

The committee looked at various options and concluded that the only acceptable solution was to convert Williamstown dockyard to a statutory body operated by a management board responsible to the Miniser for Defence. Other options, it said, either were not available or fell short in one or more ways. Therefore the major recommendation-I repeat 'the major recommendation'-in relation to management was to take Williamstown dockyard out of the Department of Defence and to make the statutory body managed by a board responsible to the Minister for Defence. That, I think, is very clear. I am certain that from reading the report no one can doubt that that requirement is essential if Williamstown dockyard is to be successful. Yet the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, Mr Newman, in commenting on this report said that for the time being the Government had decided to retain the yard within the Department of Defence, to introduce new arrangements and to prosecute a program of sweeping reform. That is quite contrary to the whole thrust of the Hawke report. It misses the fundamental aspect. What is worse, it gives no explanation of why it is done. I urge that if there are cogent reasons why the Government has rejected the whole thrust of this report, which said that unless the committee's requirements were met it could not recommend the construction of destroyers at the Williamstown dockyard, they should be outlined. Why has this key recommendation been rejected?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: National Health and Medical Research Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am particularly interested in this report and believe that the Senate should take careful note of it. I regret that only two copies are available; the only way I could get a copy before me was to ask the Parliamentary Library to lend it to me for a few minutes. I find that regrettable. It is a very important report and its recommendations will affect the lives of many Australians.

I would like to speak of the disastrous effects of the health hazards of asbestos which are unknown and which the other day led to the death of a close friend of mine, Jim Roulston. Jim Roulston was prominent in the Australian Labor Party in Victoria. He was a member of our national Executive. He was a person upon whom many of us relied for advice and for friendship. He knew the true meaning of the word 'comrade' and he brought good sense into all the discussions in which he played a part. Because of that good sense good counsel prevailed in discussions which involved the workers in many occupations. He died as a result of coming into contact with asbestos as a boilermaker. Many people who have been engaged in this industry will die as a result, just as Jim Roulston died after a long and lingering period of ill health. If anyone were to appreciate how he suffered they would appreciate how necessary it is for this report and these recommendations to be endorsed.

Not only did Jim Roulston die but also others who work in the same area will die. It is a great tragedy that this should have happened. Since it has happened , surely we should take measures to prevent any further recurrence and at the same time we should take those measures to compensate those who suffer as a result of the death of those who are the wage earners. For that reason I believe it is necessary for this report to be before the Senate. I think Senator McIntosh wishes to speak next. I trust that when he is finished he will seek leave to continue his remarks so that this paper will remain before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather disgusted that this paper has not come before honourable senators. Although it is on the Notice Paper neither I nor anyone else has had an opportunity to read it. It is a most important document when one considers the economic and health suffering that is going on in the community through asbestosis. My colleague Jim Roulston died from working as a boilermaker. The health of my colleague, Gordon Grenville, is deteriorating rapidly. He was a boilermaker and worked with asbestos in boiler lagging. He worked with asbestos at a time when electro-welding equipment was covered with it. The people affected fought hard to get compensation. They had to fight very hard for the people who had been exposed to asbestos through their work to try to get some type of health coverage. This report is supposed to be before the Senate. I am very disturbed indeed that we have not had the opportunity to read it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later as I have quite a bit more to say on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak on a subject which I have spoken about very frequently since I came into this Senate, and which has been of great concern to the people of Australia. I refer to the cost of metric conversion. The Senate has before it the 11th annual report of the Metric Conversion Board which is, undoubtedly, its final report. This will probably be the final chance the Senate will get to talk about this problem. It is fascinating to see that this report continues in the same vein as the report from the Senate Select Committee on the Metric System of Weights and Measures which was brought up and ordered to be printed on 29 May 1968. The report sees nothing but good in connection with metric conversion in Australia and makes no mention of the costs to the nation other than to set out that the total expenditure for the decade by the Government on metric conversion was about $6m.

I want to make it perfectly clear that I am not critical of the members of the Committee who brought down this report. This report was brought down a decade ago when perhaps we saw the nation was in a period when people thought they had to be trendy, to be with it, to be involved in the so-called latest move, in order to ensure that Australia was up with the rest of the world. I am sure that the personnel of that Committee gave of their utmost. I see that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Laught from South Australia, died prior to the Metric Conversion Bill being introduced. I see that there was much praise for him. I quote from what Senator McManus said as reported in Hansard of 9 June 1970 on page 2157. He said:
I also join with them-
He was talking about other members of the Committee-

in what they have said about Senator Laught. He was a most conscientious Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on the Metric System of Weights and Measures. He was a lovable personality. We all have missed him since his death. We are sorry that he is not here today to see this legislation passed by the Senate.

As I said, I am sure that all members of the Committee were gravely concerned about this matter and did their utmost in bringing down this report. It is very interesting that Senator McManus went on to make reference to another person associated with the Committee. He said:
I also join in the tribute that has been paid to our expert adviser, Mr Harper. We found him most competent on all the occasions on which the Committee met and we found him most versatile . . .

Mr Harper, as is mentioned in the report of the Senate Select Committee, was brought in as the expert adviser to the Committee. I think there is much for Senate committees to learn in that little action. I understand that Mr Harper was well known as an advocate of metric conversion. With respect, that permeates the entire report. Mr Harper was the technical consultant. Subsequently, it is interesting to see-believe it or not-that the executive member of the Metric Conversion Board was the same Mr Harper.

In the report on the metric system of weights and measures brought down in 1968 one reads point after point in praise of metric conversion. But when one analyses the reasons that were put forward in the chamber one sees that it was all about being with it. For example, one of the major points and one about which great emphasis was made was that apparently 90 per cent of the world's population was using the metric system. Allegedly, 75 per cent of world trade was being carried on in metric measure and about 70 per cent of Australia's export trade was to metric countries. So, one can see that what was being proposed was: 'We have to be in it'.
When members of the Committee looked at cost advantages no money was put forward in the proposal. The report stated:
A cost advantage may be expected in the purchase of imported materials . . .

A decade on there is no evidence of that. Certainly, education authorities favoured the system because it was simpler. That may be but one has to look at what has been the cost to the nation. I read again from the summary of conclusions and recommendations. The Committee stated:

Although no meaningful estimate could be made of the cost and benefits which would result from the adoption of the metric system, the Committee is satisfied that the ultimate benefits would greatly exceed the costs of the conversion.

In other words, the Committee made no attempt whatsoever to assess the cost to the nation but it was firmly convinced that the benefits would exceed the costs. A predecessor of mine from Victoria, Senator Greenwood, summed up the reasons given in a couple of simple sentences. In speaking about the decision on metric conversion he said:

It was based . . . on significant broad considerations of utility. It should enhance our ability to export; increase our efficiency; provide a rationalising and modernising of industrial practices; and, as was said, reduce diversification in manufactured products. It should provide a simplification of teaching of mathematics and science.

The Committee could see nothing but good. This final report indicates nothing but good. As I said, there seem to me to be a number of lessons which the Senate ought to take from these reports. The first lesson is that Senate committees should be very wary of bringing on to the committees as advisers technical experts who have a particular point of view which they have expressed publicly. I think it is very wrong for any Senate committee to invite a person who has a particular point of view which he is trying to put forward to come on to the Committee as its technical adviser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone with a barrow to push.
—As Senator Bonner says, if someone has a particular barrow to push it is very difficult for senators with their busy activities to realise that they are having this barrow pushed at them.

SPEECH.PARA: The second lesson is-there are a number of times I feel like saying this-that even when a Senate bipartisan committee produces a unanimous report we must not treat that report as being sacrosanct, so that we do not question it. Some people seem to propound the view that because some Senate committee has brought down a report all of its recommendations ought to be implemented almost automatically. Some people say: 'After all, the Senate committee has had a look at it so the Senate committee report must be adopted.' I unequivocally reject that view.

Finally, I put forward the point about financial impact statements about which I was speaking last week. If only someone somewhere in the Government had tried to make a national assessment and draw up a financial impact statement of what it would cost us to convert our petrol tanks and our containers from gallons to litres, to change our road signs-all of that fantastic cost that this nation has had to suffer. If only someone had calculated whether it would be $100m or $500m or whatever. I suspect that the cost would have been more than the cost of a 35- hour week. If that had been done I believe the Bill would not have been introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Determination

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am quite surprised that this paper appears before the Senate to be discussed. Yesterday the Government cut back on road grants to the various States throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. I do not suppose that I could have any argument with the report itself; it talks about road construction prices and contains a review of various road construction price indexes which have been compiled by the former Commonwealth Bureau of Roads, the Bureau of Transport and Economics and the State road authorities. In addition, it presents newly compiled unput price indexes for national road construction activity. It appears to me somewhat of a farce for the Senate to discuss this report which has been placed before it when yesterday the Commonwealth Government said in the House of Representatives that it would give the States only $3,022m over the next three years, a 7 per cent increase in money terms on the original commitment but in actual fact 7 per cent or 8 per cent less than the 15 per cent actual increase in road building costs throughout Australia. It seems to me a great waste of time to have a report setting out road construction price indexes from 1969-70 to 1980-81 when the Commonwealth Government is cutting back its allocation to the States by 8 per cent.

It does not end there. Anyone who read a copy of today's Australian would have noticed that members of the National Party, including Senator Flo Bjelke- Peterson, have drawn to the attention of the Government the problems that this will cause in Queensland. The allocation of money for roads is very important to a State such as Queensland because the major employers of persons in country areas are the local and shire councils.
