TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue my remarks on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981 introduced as a private member's Bill by Senator Evans. I refer honourable senators to Senate Hansard pages 2032 to 2040 which contain the report of earlier debate on this subject-Senator Evans's second reading speech and a paper in relation to fixed term parliaments which I had incorporated at that stage. Since that time I have had an opportunity to examine the Bill as presented by Senator Evans. I wish to inform the Senate that I am totally opposed to the Bill. My opposition is based on its professed principle and on the provisions which, in my view, cripple the Parliament. By 'the Parliament' I mean the House of Representatives as well as the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The motivation for this Bill has quite clearly been put publicly by Senator Evans on a number of occasions. I would like to quote from some of those statements by Senator Evans. Firstly, in his paper given to the Australasian Study of Parliament Group he said that this proposal 'would be more likely to be politically acceptable in the short term as a solution to the constitutional problems shown up by 1974 and 1975 than either of the positions that have been taken so far by the major parties'. Then on 11 November 1981, as reported in Hansard, he said:

. . . the central and overriding advantage of the fixed term concept is simply that, as a possible solution to the constitutional problems of 1975, it is really, as an American might say, 'the only game in town' . . .What the Whitlam proposal sought to do directly, the fixed term parliaments proposal does very indirectly.

If we look at the effect of this Bill on the Senate, we see that the Senate will lose its independence, that the terms of the Senate will be tied to the House of Representatives, that the Senate will be virtually without legislative power, and that the Senate and therefore the Parliament will be at the mercy of the government of the day. That is perfectly obvious and I think Senator Evans would willingly admit those points, but I wonder whether the side effect is unintended . The side effect of his proposal is to cripple representative government by taking away the powers of the House of Representatives as well. Almost every provision of this Bill is fraught with danger. I have circulated in the chamber and to honourable senators' offices a paper which is headed: 'Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981, Observations on the Major provisions'. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the paper in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
OBSERVATIONS ON THE MAJOR PROVISIONS
Introduction
This Bill aims to make six major changes to the Constitution. It seeks to:
(1) provided a fixed term for the House of Representatives by ensuring that the House is not dissolved before the end of that term except in special circumstances;
(2) alter the terms of service of Senators, so that those terms will be dependent upon the duration of the House of Representatives;
(3) set fixed dates for the election of the House of Representatives, depending upon whether the House expires or is dissolved;
(4) alter the powers of the Senate in respect of legislation;
(5) make new provisions for the resolution of disagreements between the Houses in respect of legislation; and
(6) limit the powers of the Governor-General in respect of the appointment and dismissal of prime ministers and ministers.
These changes are not dependent upon each other; each of the six major alterations could stand independently, although they are of course in this Bill drafted so as to be compatible.
Each of the six major changes will therefore be discussed separately.
(1) The Fixed Term of the House of Representatives

The idea that the House of Representatives should have a fixed term, that is, that it should be dissolved before the end of its term only in special circumstances, has been put forward in a number of different forms. This Bill contains only one of the possible forms of the idea. It is obvious that as long as the executive government is to be in any sense responsible to the House of Representatives the term of the House cannot be absolutely fixed, because provision must be made for a House which cannot or will not support a government . The advantages of a fixed term House which have been put forward are:

(a) it might encourage more independence on the part of the Members of the House of Representatives, in that the House would be free to reject specific government proposals without the fear that the government might dissolve the House and send it to an election;
(b) it would prevent a government from holding elections at the time of its choosing, and would thereby deprive government of a powerful instrument which has been used to ensure its re-election; and

(c) it would prevent the Senate from seeking to force a government to go to an early election, in that a government would not have the power to do that which the Senate would be seeking to compel it to do.
The disadvantages of the fixed term proposal may best be discussed in the context of the specific version of the idea contained in this Bill.

Clause 2 of the Bill provides, in effect, that the House of Representatives cannot be dissolved, leaving aside the provisions relating to disagreements between the Houses, except where the House passes a motion expressing lack of confidence in the prime minister and the ministry, and does not, within seven days after such a motion is passed, pass another motion expressing confidence in a person if that person were appointed prime minister and in a ministry to be appointed by that person. In other words, the House of Representatives may be dissolved only when the existing government does not command the confidence of the House and the House is unable or unwilling to express its confidence in an alternative government.

There are two major disadvantages of this scheme, both of which fall into the area of its effect on responsible government. The Bill may be said to remove an essential element of responsible government as it has existed hitherto. Responsible government as it has been understood and expounded since the middle of the 19th century requires not only that the government is responsible to the lower house, but that that House is responsible to the electorate. The responsibility of the lower house to the electorate is enforced by the government's power of dissolution, a power of appeal, as it has been called. This element of responsible government was expounded, for example, by Bagehot:

'But a cabinet, though it is a committee of the legislative assembly, is a committee with a power which no assembly would-unless for historical accidents, and after happy experience-have been persuaded to entrust to any committee. It is a committee which can dissolve the assembly which appointed it; it is a committee with a suspensive veto-a committee with a power of appeal. Though appointed by one Parliament, it can appeal if it chooses to the next.'

This Bill removes this second element of responsible government. The first way in which the responsibility of the House to the electorate may be avoided, and the first major disadvantage of this part of the Bill, is that a House may choose not to pass a motion of no confidence, while at the same time preventing a government from effectively governing. In practical terms, there might, for example, be a split in the majority party in the House. The minority faction of the majority party may decline to pass a motion of no confidence, while at the same time joining with the opposition to frustrate major elements of the government's policies. It has been said that no group of members could be so irresponsible. But such a faction may have politically respectable reasons for such a course of action, and may say, for instance: 'We do not want the present Government to be turned out of office; we wish it to carry out parts of its policy which are valuable, and we do not want the Opposition to gain office. But we will prevent the Government from carrying out those parts of its policy which we regard as not in the best interests of the country'. Under the present constitutional arrangements a government in such a situation would be able to appeal to the electorate to give it a more co-operative majority in the House. In the past, considering all those jurisdictions which have responsible government, governments have often exercised this right of appeal, and successfully. Under this Bill a weak and debilitated government could be kept in office till the end of its appointed term, unable to carry out its major policies, and unable to resolve the situation.

The second way in which responsible government could be negated is by a House removing one government and installing another without the electorate being consulted. For example, a minority faction of the majority party could come to an arrangement with the opposition, or perhaps with only part of it, to turn out the existing government and install a coalition with policies which have never been put before the electorate. Under the present constitutional arrangements, a government from which the confidence of the House has been withdrawn may go to an election regardless of whether the House has expressed its confidence in an alternative government. In other words, it may appeal to the electorate to pass judgment on the proceedings in the House. Under this Bill a government which the electorate has never endorsed may be installed by a party manoeuvre, and the electorate left powerless until the end of the term of the House.

In order to consider these matters it is necessary to remember that Australian party politics has not always had its present stability of party allegiance and party discipline, and may not continue to have that stability in the future.

(2) Terms of Service of Senators Clause 5 of the Bill removes the present fixed term for Senators and provides that Senators' terms end upon the expiry or dissolution of the second House of Representatives to expire or be dissolved after the Senators' election, except when the Senate is itself dissolved and subsequently divided into two classes, so that those of the first class have a term corresponding to that of the House of Representatives elected at the same time.

Presumably the purpose of this clause is to ensure that Senate elections are held at the same time as House of Representatives elections. Such a proposition has previously been proposed and put to the electors in a referendum. The main argument against the proposition then was that it would make terms of Senators dependent upon the discretion of the executive government, in that the government could choose to have a House of Representatives election at any time. It may be urged in favour of this Bill that it removes this argument, because the House of Representatives may not be dissolved except upon a motion of no confidence not succeeded by a motion of confidence in a new government. It may be said, however, that the restriction on the dissolution of the House of Representatives greatly weakens the argument for interfering with the fixed term of Senators simply to ensure that Senate and House elections are held at the same time, because an early dissolution of the House is much less likely, and, if it does occur, it will be due to political circumstances in the House of Representatives which would have nothing to do with the composition of the Senate. If the electors are called upon to elect a new House of Representatives, there is no reason why they must at the same time elect one half of the Senate.

If it is desired to avoid separate Senate and House of Representatives elections, it would be more rational to provide that after an extraordinary House of Representatives election the new House continues only until the end of the term of the previous House. This proposition is supported by the consideration that any dissolution of the House of Representatives is likely to be caused by a party split which may be temporary and which almost certainly would not justify the selection of a new House for a full term.

(3) Fixed Dates for Elections Clause 6 of the Bill provides for the duration of the House of Representatives, and the most important innovation in it is that it provides fixed dates for elections, depending upon whether the House of Representatives expires or is dissolved.

It should be noted that the provision of a fixed term for the House of Representatives does not necessarily entail fixed election dates: it would be possible to provide for elections to be held within a period of time rather than on a particular day.

The fixing of particular days for elections in the Constitution has the disadvantage that it is impossible to avoid holding an election during some temporary internal or external crisis or at the same time as some other event.

The reasons for wishing to vary the election date may be relatively mundane, for example, to avoid the day of a State election or a celebratory event-or highly significant, for example, to avoid a period of civil disturbance or international crisis.

(4) Powers of the Senate in Respect of Legislation Clause 8 of the Bill inserts a new provision in the Constitution which provides that an appropriation or taxation Bill which is delayed by the Senate for one month may be passed into law without the consent of the Senate.

The practical effect of this provision would be to completely remove the legislative powers of the Senate and to place it in a position inferior to the British House of Lords in respect of legislative powers.

The reason for this is that there is no attempt to define an appropriation Bill , nor to limit the provision to particular appropriations, such as those for the ordinary annual services of government.

There would be no impartial officer, such as the Speaker of the House of Commons in the British context, to determine what is an appropriation Bill. The determination would be made by the executive government by advising the Governor -General to sign into law any Bill which the government deemed to be an appropriation Bill.

Moreover, every Bill could be made into an appropriation Bill, as that distinction is presently understood, simply by the insertion of a clause having the effect of appropriating moneys, and there would be no security against the ' tacking' of other matters on to any appropriation Bill.

(5) Disagreements between the houses Clause 9 of the Bill remakes the provision in the Constitution for the resolution of disagreements between the Houses over legislation. At present, a government may dissolve both Houses simultaneously when the Senate has failed to pass legislation, subject to certain restrictions. The new provisions would, in effect, allow a government a choice of putting the legislation in dispute to a joint sitting of the two Houses, or of holding a double dissolution. This would greatly strengthen the hand of a government in relation to the Senate. A government whose majority in the House of Representatives was sufficient to override any adverse majority in the Senate could pass any legislation it chose simply by holding a joint sitting.

Considering these provisions in the context of the whole Bill, however, it is highly unlikely that the provisions would ever be used at all, because a government would have in the new section 53 in clause 8 a much simpler method of ignoring an adverse Senate, by making every Bill an appropriation Bill. With this simple mechanism at its disposal, it is highly unlikely that any government would ever bother to hold a joint sitting or risk itself in a double dissolution .

There is, however, one use to which these provisions might be put. They could be used by a government to subvert the supposedly fixed term of the House of Representatives and hold an election, not only for the House of Representatives but also for the whole Senate, at a time of that government's choosing. A government in a minority position in the Senate could ensure that a deadlock, as defined by the Bill, arose, and at any time thereafter could hold a double dissolution, providing such a dissolution did not take place within six months of the expiry of the House of Representatives.
It may well be said, therefore, that the new section 57 does nothing except subvert the supposed main purpose of the Bill, namely the fixed term of the House of Representatives.

(6) Powers of the Governor-General Clause 10 of the Bill provides that a Governor-General may not dismiss from office a prime minister except when the House of Representatives has expressed lack of confidence in the prime minister and has expressed confidence in another person as prime minister and the prime minister has not resigned.

The effect of this provision would be to greatly strengthen, not necessarily a government, but a prime minister. The Bill ignores the fact that there are other circumstances in which a prime minister may be dismissed, and present constitutional usage is that the Governor-General may correctly dismiss a prime minister in certain circumstances other than those which appear to be contemplated or which are sought to be prevented by this Bill. For example, a prime minister may be deposed from the leadership of his party, perhaps at a time when the House of Representatives is not sitting, and may refuse to resign his office. Present constitutional usage is that in these circumstances a Governor-General may properly consult the other Ministers of State and may dismiss the prime minister in order to bring about the change desired by the majority party. Under this Bill, the Governor-General would be powerless to act in the absence of the required resolutions of the House of Representatives. But in a parliamentary recess the prime minister may refuse to advise the Governor- General to summon the House of Representatives. Thus an absurd deadlock would be created, and could only be broken by the Governor-General either ignoring the Constitution by dismissing the prime minister or acting against the prime minister's advice by summoning the House of Representatives.

While it may seem unlikely that a prime minister would act in this way, the possibility of his so acting would provide him with a powerful weapon against his party colleagues, because he could threaten to act in this way if deposed by his party. At present a majority party can be almost certain that, through the Governor-General, they can change their leader and by the same act change the prime minister without having to engage in protracted, embarrassing and possibly dangerous proceedings in the House of Representatives. Under this Bill they could never be certain that they would not be exposed to such proceedings should they attempt to change their leader.

There is also the possibility of a prime minister suffering sudden and apparently permanent disability, which would require the Governor-General to terminate his appointment, with the advice of the Ministry. In December 1967 the Governor-General determined the appointment of Mr Holt; if this Bill had then been in force, how would the circumstances of that time been resolved?
The Bill may well be said to replace responsible government with a quasi- presidential, prime ministerial government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I am sure that will save a considerable amount of time. I sincerely ask honourable senators to read these observations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp-I even read them with interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. When one analyses these proposals one will see that the Bill removes the main check against a government's mismanagement, corruption or incompetence by curtailing the legislative powers of the Senate. The proposals in the Bill have all been rejected earlier-in a Senate select committee of 1950, the 1959 Joint Committee on Constitutional Review, and the 1976 Whitlam proposal. These provisions are unacceptable to our founding fathers and I suggest that they are equally unacceptable today. The provision, which supposedly affects only money Bills, could, as draft, be used to ensure the Senate's veto and amendment power over all legislation would be lost. All Bills that are introduced into the Senate could in some way or other have a money section attached to them. Yet the double dissolution mechanism was preserved. One asks: Why would that be so? It was obvious that that could be only so that the Government could subvert a fixed term concept.

SPEECH.PARA: In the provisions of the Bill there would be only one circumstance in which a government or a Prime Minister might be dismissed. Of course what it is all about is what happened in 1975. I would like to offer my diagnosis of 1975. I recognise that this is a matter of great controversy within the country and the Parliament. Nevertheless, I think that it is reasonable to restate my view on the matter, which is a view which has been put by many legal technicians. Firstly, one looks at what Mr Whitlam was happy to accept in 1970 and 1974 when he had no objection to the Senate's powers in relation to money Bills. He accepted the principle that a government denied Supply by Parliament cannot govern constitutionally and should either resign or advise an election. But in 1975 he rejected that proposal. The reason he rejected the proposal was that the polls told him that he could not win an election so he did not want to have one. I put it to the Senate that the constitutional crisis was not of the Senate's making; it was not of the Governor-General's making; it was of Mr Whitlam's making because he refused to resign. The question for consideration before this Parliament is: Should we have a strong States-based Senate with power to discipline incompetent or corrupt government and ensure that the electorate has a say or should the executive government, with strongly entrenched bureaucracy, be supreme?

This Bill validates illegal actions of a Prime Minister and, in my view, tries to rectify a situation created by Mr Whitlam, who attempted to govern unconstitutionally. In effect, what is proposed by Senator Evans's Bill is that we will have an elected dictatorship. I am quite intrigued by the attitude of editorial writers in the newspapers. Senator Evans has been kind enough to circulate to us a number of extracts from newspapers. He quite rightly says that all of them, except one minor one, support him. I find that fascinating. I will refer to extracts from two newspapers that Senator Evans did not bother to circulate, perhaps because they occurred later. One is an article by Mr Claude Forell which appeared in the Age yesterday. Of course, Mr Forell is well known as one who supported the Labor Party's views on what happened in 1975. Nevertheless let us see what he says. He states:

The best solution would be for Federal Parliament to adopt and seek popular approval for the proposal put forward by Labor's leading constitutionalist, Senator Evans, for fixed term-and preferably 4-year-Parliaments.

At one stroke this would neutralise the Senate's power to force a government prematurely to the polls and eliminate a Prime Minister's prerogative to call an early election whenever he perceives this to be to his government's advantage.

What fascinates me is that that is all he can see. With respect to Mr Forell, I wish he would do more than read the heading on the Bill. I hope that he might take the time to read the paper which I have just incorporated in Hansard and which sets out some of the other problems which arise as a result of this proposal. The Canberra Times today produced an editorial in which it admits its point of view. It states:
. . . The Canberra Times, are strongly of the opinion that the Senate should not continue to have the power to refuse or block Supply to the elected Government.

That is as it may be. Maybe there are many people in the community who are of that view. Maybe many honourable senators from both sides of this chamber have that view. There is no question in my mind that if the Senate does block Supply the Constitution should be altered to ensure that the Senate also goes to the people. What fascinates me is that the Canberra Times, having announced that it does not think the Senate should have power to refuse or block Supply, then indicates that this is what Senator Evans proposal does and therefore the Government should pick up this proposal and support it. Clearly these people have not analysed the Bill. If honourable senators look at Senator Evans's amendments they will see that this proposal takes away the constitutional right of the Parliament to deal with the executive government. If the people who wrote these articles-perhaps Mr Forell would be one-want to abolish the Senate, that is a point of view which they may adopt. Let them forget the Senate and just look at the effect the Bill would have on the House of Representatives and the parliamentary process. The inevitable consequences of a fixed term for the Senate and a fixed term for the House of Representatives, so far as practical politics are concerned, would be that the Executive would become totally supreme at the expense of the Parliament. We would have an elected dictatorship. There would not be the slightest doubt about that. The Government would serve its term , whether it be for three years or four years, regardless of its behaviour.

Let us look at the United States of America where there is a fixed term government. Let me remind the Senate that the United States people had to wait four and a half years after Watergate before they had an opportunity at the ballot box to express their views about the Republican Government. Surely that was a reprehensible action but there was no way the Congress-do not worry about the people-could get rid of that Government. The Congress could not cope with the situation. The result of a fixed term would be that the executive government would reign supreme.

Forgetting the Senate for the moment, the House of Representatives will just merely be at the whim of the executive government. Of course, no person who is on the Government side, whichever party is in power in the House of Representatives, will dare to throw out its own reprehensible government. Of course they will not. They know that the result would be that they would immediately face an election and they would lose their own seats. So, from a practical political point of view, there would be no way that the executive government could be taken to the people. That is a question of practical politics, not some airy fairy academic approach to the Constitution.

While we are discussing what happened in 1975, let us look at what former Senator John Wheeldon said in Quadrant magazine as recently as March 1982 in relation to the problems of the Australian Labor Party. He said:

. . . I don't think that one can really look back to what happened in 1975 as being part of some uniform pattern of conspiracy or that too many conclusions can be drawn from it. In fact I am reminded of something that Lord Melboure said when he was dismissed by King William IV. He said: 'I hate to be considered ill used. I have always thought complaints of ill usage contemptible, whether from a seduced, disappointed girl or a turned out Prime Minister'. This is a view to which I also tend to subscribe. I think that a large part of the problems in 1975 were of our own creation.
I say to Senator Evans in relation to the newspapers that not all of the newspapers have followed his point of view. In an editorial in the Australian on 17 February this year it was stated:

Of all of the nations which have a bicameral system none has a more powerful upper house than the Australian Senate. It can initiate any bills other than money bills and it can reject any bills sent to it from the House of Representatives, including, as we were dramatically reminded in 1975, those bills whose passage is necessary to provide the Government with its day-to-day income.
The editorial in the Australian continued:

There are sound historical reasons for the Senate having so much power. They have maintained much of their validity until the present day. With Australia's vast area and small population there are good reasons why there should be limitations on the concentration of power in the hands of a simple majority.
Senator Tate-What date was that?

TALK.START.PARA: —That editorial appeared in the Australian on Wednesday 17 February 1982. Senator Evans was courteous enough today to give me an advance copy of his statement that he proposes to incorporate in Hansard this evening. That statement foreshadows amendments to take account of certain objections covered both in the paper which he has previously circulated to honourable senators and in other discussions he has had. I have not had time to analyse these proposals in great detail. Of course, I want to look at the wording of the proposed amendments. But one thing is clear to me: Apart from some minor changes , the purpose of the Bill will remain the same-that is, to destroy the Senate and destroy representative government in the House of Representatives. I say sincerely to the Senate that I am reminded of the ambit claims made by certain trade unions, which are well known to us in industrial relations, where they go for broke initially and then come along and put forward proposed amendments to indicate that there is a degree of consideration for other people's points of view. Senator Evans-It is a good faith attempt to find compromise.

—Senator Evans said that it is a good and faithful attempt to find compromise. He lays his heart on the Senate table and says that he is being very genuine about this. The fundamental principle of this legislation is a fixed term. He is not, in any way, trying to change that principle. The fixed term concept is a fundamental principle of his Bill. The fixed term concept in fact castrates the House of Representative and the Senate. It makes a eunuch of this place. In effect, it hands over government to the Executive. Despite Senator Evans' claims to the contrary, this fixed term concept, so far as I can see in his proposed amendments tonight, can still be subverted by a government which uses, for its own purposes, the section 57 double dissolution provisions. A prime minister would still be firmly entrenched in power with all the sanctions he has at his disposal against his removal by his own colleagues and by the House of Representatives as a whole. The safeguard against an elected dictatorship is still non-existent. It is very interesting to see that Professor Geoffrey Sawer, who attended the conference that I referred to before in relation to fixed term and four-year parliaments, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble with the fixed-term proposal is that it would, unless qualified by other provisions, put an end to a major principle of the Westminster system, namely that the Cabinet chosen from a majority group in the popular House should be able to seek the view of the electorate if at any time its majority is lost through party splits or the withdrawal of marginal minor-party support.

That is a matter of considerable importance in this debate. In effect, the executive government of the day will be put in a position where it cannot be thrown out of office. Either it will be completely in control of its own chamber or, if some sort of party split occurs, some minority group will keep it in power and it will act in the way that the minority group wishes for its own political preservation. These are the proposals as I see the debate up until these amendments were circulated by Senator Evans. I am really not in a position to go on and deal in total with those proposed amendments but I hope I get an opportunity to speak at some later stage. Could I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage?
Senator Evans-Not if it puts an end to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it would put an end to the debate if I were to seek leave to continue my remarks later.

The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT BY SENATOR GARETH EVANS ON RESUMPTION OF SECOND READING DEBATE

When I introduced this Bill on 11 November 1981, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, I indicated our intention to allow it to lie on the table until the Autumn Session, in order to ensure ample time for reaction to flow back in from politicians in other parties and from the community at large.

Subsequently, although the Government itself has remained uncommunicative, I have had representations from, and substantial discussions with, a number of individual Senators from all parts of the Chamber, as to various aspects of the Bill in its original form.

It may assist the Senate debate on the Bill if I indicate at this stage those aspects of the Bill which, in the light of those discussions, we are now prepared to amend. The proposed amendments, the text of which I shall circulate after further consultation with the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, fall into three categories.

First, it is proposed that following any extraordinary early elections, the newly elected Parliament not to commence a new three year cycle, but rather merely serve out the remainder of the original term.

This will meet the objection that the original Bill, despite contrary claims, did not in fact ensure that the Government of the day would lose its present power to freely manipulate election dates to suit its own political advantage: given the ease of cocking the double-dissolution trigger mechanism, early elections could still, under the original Bill, be called at the whim of the Government of the day simply by means of it contriving a deadlock situation. The proposed amendment would clearly operate as a disincentive to use of the double- dissolution mechanism, especially later in the life of a Parliament; at the same time it would still allow ample practical scope for a Government facing an unworkable situation in the Senate to bring about a double-dissolution early in the life of the Parliament, eg. within the first 12 to 15 months.

Secondly, it is proposed that Section 53 of the Constitution be amended only to the extent necessary to remove the Senate's power with respect to major money Bills-viz. those crucially important appropriation and taxation measures the passage of which is indispensable to a Government's capacity to continue to govern. The present constitutional provisions in relation to lesser appropriation and tax measures would remain untouched.

This meets the objection that the original Bill, which explicitly sought to remove the power of the Senate to block any kind of taxation or appropriation Bill, major or minor, went further than was necessary to solve the immediate problem to which the Bill as a whole is directed-viz. the capacity of a Government to survive in Office so long as it retains the confidence of the House of Representatives.
Thirdly, it is proposed that the provision relating to the holding of a joint sitting as an alternative to a double-dissolution be deleted.

This meets the objection that the provision (based on the recommendation of the 1959 Joint Committee on Constitutional Review) is unnecessary to the basic scheme and object of the Bill-which, again, is to ensure the survival of a properly elected Government, rather than going the whole way toward ensuring that the will of the House of Representatives more or less invariably prevails.

The general effect of these three amendments will be to remove some of the more potentially far-reaching aspects of the original Bill, to confine its subject matter to that which is strictly necessary to achieve a workable fixed term Parliaments system, and to make the primary effect of the Bill a guarantee of the capacity of an elected Government to survive in Office so long as it retains the confidence of the House of Representatives-rather than a guarantee that the will of the Government will always, or at least usually, prevail.

I make it clear that this amounts to very much a compromise on the part of the Australian Labor Party, made in the interests of clearing away at least the most devisive and destabilising features of the legacy of 1975. Our longer term goal- which may take more time to find Parliamentry and general community acceptance- remains the creation of a Senate which will operate as a genuine, constructive House of Review, and has no destructive powers to block the passage of any money Bill, or to do more than delay-for six months-the passage of any other class of Bill.

I hope that the proposed amendments will now ensure that the Bill receives clear majority support in the Senate. Even more importantly, I hope that they will persuade the Government of the Labor Party's genuine desire to find a compromise, consensus solution to what is obviously a crucially important constitutional problem, and will encourage the Government to reconsider its general attitude to the proposed constitutional amendment accordingly.
Attached to this statement is a paper setting out in more detail the proposed amendments, and describing how they fit into the scheme of the present Bill.
MAIN ELEMENTS IN PRESENT BILL
(1) Basic Rule: Future elections for House of Representatives and half-Senate to be held at fixed three yearly intervals, on the third Saturday in November.

(2) Exception A: An extraordinary election for the House of Representatives ( and also for the half-Senate, to preserve simultaneous elections) is to be held when the Government is defeated in the House, and no alternative Government with the confidence of the House can be formed within seven days.
(3) Exception B: A double-dissolution may be advised by the Government when a 90 day deadlock occurs between the House and the Senate (though not within six months of the due election date).

(4) Restoration of Cycle: If an extraordinary early election (Exception A) or double-dissolution (Exception B) occurs the newly elected Parliament has a three year term, subject to the adjustment necessary to bring the next election date back to a third Saturday in November. (If the extraordinary election occurs within the six months following November in any year, the new term is '3-minus' years; if it is in the six months preceding November, the new term will be '3- plus' years).
(5) Section 53 is amended by removing the power of the Senate to block any kind of taxation or appropriation Bill, major or minor.

(6) Section 57 is modified to provide that (in accordance with the recommendation of the 1959 Joint Committee on Constitutional Review) in the event of a deadlock between the House and the Senate, the Government can seek to resolve it by advising either a joint sitting (without a double-dissolution) or a double-dissolution.

(7) The powers of the Governor-General to appoint and dismiss the Prime Minister and other Ministers are codified (in particular, it is made clear that the only circumstances in which a Government may be dismissed are if it is defeated on a formal no confidence motion in the House, if an alternative Government does then receive a vote of confidence, and the original Government does not then resign).

Basic Arguments for Bill (i) The Government of the day, so long as it retains the confidence in the House of Representatives, will be guaranteed its full term of office and not be able to be forced against its will to an early election.
(ii) At the same time-as a politically realistic trade-off-the Government of the day loses its present power to manipulate election dates to suit its own political advantage.

(iii) Inherent advantages of a more stable electoral cycle from the point of view of Government planning, of policy implementation, of Opposition policy development, of party campaign coffers, and of voter sanity.
PROPOSED AMENDMENTS

(1) Restoration of Cycle: It is proposed that, following extraordinary elections, the newly elected Parliament do no more than serve out the remainder of the original term, rather than commencing a new three year (plus or minus) cycle. This means that:

In the event of an 'Exception A' election following the defeat of a Government in the House of Representatives, only the House of Representatives would go to the polls-with the next House of Representatives and half-Senate elections occurring at the ordinary scheduled time.

In the event of an 'Exception B' double-dissolution, both Houses would go to the polls. (The 'short-term' Senators thus elected would be due for re-election at the House of Representatives/half-Senate election at the next ordinary scheduled time.)
Arguments for: (i) Better preserves 'fixed term' principle in that extraordinary elections to not throw out the basic election cycle.

(ii) Overcomes an obvious flaw in the original Bill in that early elections could still be called at the whim of the Government of the day simply by deliberately setting in train the deadlock double-dissolution mechanism. The proposed amendment would operate as a disincentive to use of the double- dissolution mechanism.

(iii) Still allows ample practical scope for a Government facing an unworkable situation in the Senate to call a double-dissolution early in the life of the Parliament-e.g. within the first 12-15 months. (Double-dissolutions in the latter part of the Parliamentary term would become impractical, but note the original Bill, like the present Constitution, rules out double-dissolutions anyway in the last six months.)
(iv) Does not reduce the full six year terms of Senators except-which is the situation at the moment-in the case of a double-dissolution.

(2) Section 53. It is proposed that Section 53 be amended only to the extent necessary to remove the Senate's powers with respect to major money Bills-viz. those crucially important appropriation and taxation measures the passage of which is indispensable to a Government's capacity to continue to govern. The present constitutional provisions in relation to lesser appropriation and tax measures would remain untouched.
Arguments for: (i) Bill would continue to explicitly deal with-and remove-the most important and obnoxious of the Senate's powers.

(ii) The basic objective of the original Bill was to deal with the central problem-squarely raised by the blocking of supply in 1974 and 1975-of the capacity of a Government to survive in office. The removal of other classes of Senate power might be a desirable objective (certainly it remains the Labor Party's ultimate policy goal), but it is not necessary to the achievement of the object of this particular Bill.
(3) Section 57. It is proposed that the provision relating to the holding of a joint sitting as an alternative to a double-dissolution be deleted.
Argument for:

This is unnecessary to the basic scheme and object of the Bill-which is to ensure the survival in office of a properly elected Government, rather than going the whole way (which remains the Labor Party's ultimate policy goal) toward ensuring that the will of the House of Representatives prevails in all matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I make my approach to the debate on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981 different from the approach of Senator Lewis. There is nothing novel about that in this place. In fact, in the four years I have been here I cannot remember a case where he and I have agreed on anything. Contrary to Senator Lewis's view I want to commend Senator Evans in particular and the Australian Labor Party in general and my own colleague Senator Macklin for the enormous amount of work that has been put into the Bill, the amendments proposed to it and the discussion that it has already generated and, one hopes, will continue to generate in the weeks ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are committed to constitutional reform. I have the honour of sharing patronage of, I think, several organisations with Senator Alan Missen and Senator Gareth Evans. These are organisations committed to discussion of constitutional change. All of us know that this is a process that needs community discussion. The three of us thought that by having a tripartite approach we might at least take party politics out of the whole debate. I would like to think that the getting together of Senators Missen, Evans, Chipp and others might well have contributed to the very valuable documents now before the Senate in the form of the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill.

I commend Senator Evans and the Labor Party for introducing this Bill on 11 November 1981. One finds evidence of Senator Evans's impish sense of humour in choosing that date. I am sure it was not fortuitous. I also thank him for the accommodation that he and the Labor Party have given people in the community, particularly the Australian Democrats, in bringing forward the various amendments incorporated in the document before the Senate at the moment. We believe that those proposed amendments now bring the Bill to a stage where it can be usefully discussed in this place, where possibly a second reading can be agreed to and this chamber can go into Committee to iron out the details. I think, and I know Senator Evans would agree, that there is likely to be a long, tortuous, at times tedious but useful debate in Committee on each of the clauses .

I would not want it thought that the Labor Party and the Democrats are unanimous about all clauses of the Bill. Personally I am as keen about altering the Constitution to ensure fixed terms of Parliament as Senator Lewis is against it. In that respect I can say I am absolutely at one with the Labor Party and with Senator Evans. I have, in my normal fashion of making extreme statements from time to time, called obscene the practice of some political leaders and I do not mean just Liberal leaders. From time to time these political leaders have manipulated the electorate to a certain point and then sought a dissolution six months, 12 months, 18 months-I think at one stage it was 20 months-before due time to suit their own party political purposes. In political terms I believe that is an obscenity. As far as I am concerned, I will do all I can to assist the Labor Party in this chamber in bringing about fixed terms of Parliament. That is how strongly I feel about the matter. We have inbuilt in the present parliamentary system certain possibilities. I want to put to Senator Lewis a purely hypothetical situation. I listened to his arguments and I read his paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were good, weren't they?

—I thought they were worthy of commendation; they were worthy of consideration. I do not know whom Senator Lewis had in mind. It is a pity he had to incorporate his paper in Hansard. For those listening to every word I have to say they would now be wondering what was in Senator Lewis's paper. He painted a hypothetical picture of a political party-I do not know which party he had in mind-that was split. Let us assume, just to make the situation easy to understand, that the party is split into a Fraser faction and a Peacock faction and that the Peacock faction is in the minority. Under the original proposals before Senator Lewis he said that that political party, while it had a majority in the House of Representatives, could continue to combine to vote against a motion of no confidence in the leader but at the same time fragment on almost every major vote put before it. Chaos and instability would be the result. As I said to Senator Archer that was an argument worthy of commendation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I believe the arguments in favour of a fixed term for Parliament are overwhelming, as I will say when I am able to continue my remarks at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to consult your members or just put the point of view of individual Democrat senators?

—We will be doing both. We have had discussions with Senator Evans over the last several days, particularly on the proposed alterations to clause 53 of the Bill. I say quite frankly that I and my Party are not satisfied with the present formula for emasculating or reducing the Senate's powers in that respect. I think our good faith is shown by the pledge that Democrat senators took not to block Supply. To do that is one thing; to change the Constitution is another. I will give one example.
—Everybody else.

—A member of the Labor Party should not make such a cowardly smart -alicky remark and then walk out of the chamber. I thought Labor Party senators would be the last to be smart-alicky about blocking Supply at this stage of the game. I am sorry that Senator Coates should make a remark such as that. I will give an illustration of why we want more discussion. A proposed amendment to clause 53 of the Bill proposes that the Senate not have power to amend those Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government in office, or Bills for the ordinary annual services of the Government. On the surface that looks a very respectable proposition.
—Very vague, though.

—It is very vague. We already have evidence of the practice or tacking for which this Government seems to have developed an enthusiasm. For example, we could well have a Bill to reintroduce conscription. I am taking what is maybe an extreme case to illustrate the point. This Bill may be rushed through by the weight of party numbers in the lower House, brought to the Senate and tacked on to a money Bill. That would mean essentially, according to my advice, that the Senate would be powerless to amend the Bill. It would also be powerless to refuse it. I am no constitutional lawyer, as the Senate knows, but those are the sorts of things that we want to consult on. I believe that in a relatively short time frame we can come to the point where we can carry a second reading vote on the Bill, and then move into a Committee debate which I think could be only useful and productive.

QUESTION.PARA: How many (a) senators; and (b) Members of the House of Representatives receive their salary in the form of payment: (i) to a personal bank account; (ii) to a personal building society account; (iii) to a family trust; (iv) to a private or family company or partnership; and (v) by cheque.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Payments of salary to senators and members are made by the Department of the Senate and the Department of the House of Representatives respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Was an advertising dodger for the 'Automatic Payroll Savings Service' of the Victorian Building Societies Association included in the pay envelopes of Commonwealth public servants in October 1981, or at any other time; if so, bearing in mind that this gives the building societies concerned a substantial advantage over other finance-seeking institutions which the Minister would have more cause to promote, such as Commonwealth Government Bonds or the Commonwealth Public Service Credit Union, why were the dodgers included, and on what basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourble senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes; the Victorian Building Society Association's brochure was one of a number of approved publicity inserts included in pay envelopes in or around October 1981. For many years it has been the practice to allow the representative organisations of banks, credit unions and building societies to provide publicity brochures for inclusion in the cash-pay packets of staff who are employed under the Public Service Act by Commonwealth departments. Following the Government's decision in 1981 to reduce the incidence of the cash mode of pay, the practice was extended to include individual banks, credit unions and building societies; this avoided disadvantage to institutions which had no particular affiliation with representative organisations.

Publicity of this kind has provided a useful supplement to normal departmental sources of information aimed at informing employees of institutions approved to accept pay deposits, and has been approved on that basis rather than with a view to the promotion of particular investment opportunities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the regulations relating to the use of dieldrin in the wool industry.

(2) What progress has been made in co-ordinating the collection of information on this subject with the States in an effort to inform the Japanese government of regulations over the use of dieldrin in Australia.
(3) What effect has the Japanese decision to prohibit the importation of wool containing dieldrin had on Australia's wool exports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The regulatory control of agricultural chemicals in Australia is an individual State responsibility with national co-ordination by subsidiary committees of the Australian Agricultural Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council. In the case of dieldrin, a national policy prohibiting use on animals has been in operation for some twenty years. Commercial use of dieldrin in mothproofing woollen fabrics and carpets has virtually phased itself out in recent years due to developing insect resistance.
(2) Advice on the Australia-wide situation relating to the use of dieldrin in scoured wool and wool tops was passed to Embassy of Japan on 13 November 1981.
(3) There is no indication that the Japanese decision has adversely affected Australian wool exports to Japan or is likely to do so in the future.
